article: (CNN)Share, and your gift will be multiplied. That may sound like an esoteric adage, but when Zully Broussard selflessly decided to give one of her kidneys to a stranger, her generosity paired up with big data. It resulted in six patients receiving transplants. That surprised and wowed her. "I thought I was going to help this one person who I don't know, but the fact that so many people can have a life extension, that's pretty big," Broussard told CNN affiliate KGO. She may feel guided in her ge
summary: A woman named Zully Broussard donated one of her kidneys to help six other people receive new kidneys, thanks to some amazing technology. This helped make it possible for these six people to have new kidneys and live longer lives. Broussard thought she was only helping one person, but this helped others too. People were really happy to hear about this and said thank you for helping others.

article: (CNN)On the 6th of April 1996, San Jose Clash and DC United strode out in front of 31,683 expectant fans at the Spartan Stadium in San Jose, California. The historic occasion was the first ever Major League Soccer match -- a brave new dawn for the world's favorite sport in a land its charms had yet to conquer. Summarizing the action for ESPN, commentator Ty Keough eagerly described the momentous "birth of a new era for American soccer." Looking back at footage from that balmy evening now it's ha

(CNN)French striker Bafetimbi Gomis, who has a history of fainting, said he is now "feeling well" after collapsing during Swansea's 3-2 loss at Tottenham in the Premier League on Wednesday. The worrying incident occurred in the first half at White Hart Lane -- after Tottenham scored in the seventh minute -- but the 29-year-old left the pitch conscious following about five minutes of treatment. The Guardian added that he was wearing an oxygen mask. Play was temporarily stopped before resuming. As
summary: French striker Bafetimbi Gomis, who has a history of fainting, said he is now "feeling well" after collapsing during Swansea's 3-2 loss at Tottenham in the Premier League on Wednesday. The incident occurred in the first half, but Gomis was conscious after about five minutes of treatment. The Guardian reported that he was wearing an oxygen mask. Play was briefly stopped before resuming. Swansea tweeted that Gomis was "fine," with manager Garry Monk using the same word to describe Gomis' condition. Gomis spent the night in hospital as a precaution. After spending

article: (CNN)It was an act of frustration perhaps more commonly associated with golf's fictional anti-hero Happy Gilmore than the world's reigning No 1. player. But when Rory McIlroy pulled his second shot on the eighth hole of the WGC Cadillac Championship into a lake Friday, he might as well have been channeling the much loved Adam Sandler character. Before continuing his round with a dropped ball, the four-time major winner launched the 3-iron used to play the offending shot into the water as well. "
summary: Rory McIlroy, the world's top golf player, made an error during a round at the WGC Cadillac Championship. He played a shot with a 3-iron into a lake, which was considered a mistake since he did not need such a long shot for the rest of the round. McIlroy later expressed regret for his action, saying it was a result of his frustration and not intended to be a mistake. Despite this, he finished the round with a score of 70, placing him one under par for the tournament and eight shots behind the leader.

article: (CNN)A Pennsylvania community is pulling together to search for an eighth-grade student who has been missing since Wednesday. The search has drawn hundreds of volunteers on foot and online. The parents of Cayman Naib, 13, have been communicating through the Facebook group "Find Cayman" since a day after his disappearance, according to close friend David Binswanger. Newtown Police say Cayman was last seen wearing a gray down winter jacket, black ski pants and hiking boots. He could be in the Radn
summary: A missing 13-year-old student named Cayman Naib has been searched by hundreds of volunteers in Pennsylvania. The search is ongoing and the parents of Cayman have been communicating on a Facebook group. They believe he might be in the Radnor-Wayne area or near Philadelphia. His phone is out of power, and his backpack and wallet were not found. The family is appealing to Cayman to come home, and the schools have offered support.

article: (CNN)My vote for Father of the Year goes to Curt Schilling. The former Major League Baseball pitcher recently fired off a series of fastballs and mowed down a group of Twitter trolls who made the mistake of tweeting vulgar and sexually-explicit comments about Schilling's teenage daughter. The drama started, innocently enough, on February 25, when Schilling played the role of a proud father. He sent a tweet congratulating his daughter, Gabby, on being accepted to Salve Regina University, where sh
summary: Curt Schilling, a former Major League Baseball pitcher, has been recognized as the Father of the Year for his actions towards Gabby Schilling, a 17-year-old girl who received vulgar and sexually-explicit tweets from strangers. After the tweets were deleted and the accounts were closed, Schilling captured some of the images and posted them on his blog. He believes that this is an example of cyberbullying and plans to take legal action against the perpetrators. Schilling's response to the situation demonstrates his commitment to holding individuals accountable for their words and actions. This incident highlights the importance of accountability, protective parenting, and the need

article: (CNN)Another one for the "tourists behaving badly" file. Two American women have reportedly been arrested for carving their initials into a wall with a coin inside Rome's Colosseum. Daily Italian newspaper La Stampa says the women, aged 21 and 25, were spotted carrying out the act by fellow tourists, who then told security. The two letters -- J and N -- were about eight inches in length and scratched on a brick wall at the historic Roman amphitheater. The women, both from California, reportedly
summary: Two American women, aged 21 and 25, were arrested for carving their initials into a wall with a coin inside Rome's Colosseum. They were spotted by fellow tourists who then told security. The two letters - J and N - were about eight inches in length and scratched on a brick wall at the historic Roman amphitheater. The women, both from California, reportedly took a selfie with their initials before they were arrested. They may now face a fine for "aggravated damage" on a building of historical and artistic interest. One similar incident happened in 2014 when five tourists carved graffiti

article: (CNN)Following last year's successful U.K. tour, Prince and 3rdEyeGirl are bringing the Hit & Run Tour to the U.S. for the first time. The first -- and so far only -- scheduled show will take place in Louisville, Kentucky, the hometown of 3rdEyeGirl drummer Hannah Welton. Slated for March 14, tickets will go on sale Monday, March 9 at 10 a.m. local time. Prince crowns dual rock charts . A venue has yet to be announced. When the Hit & Run worked its way through the U.K. in 2014, concert venues we
summary: Prince and 3rdEyeGirl will bring their Hit & Run Tour to the U.S. for the first time, with a scheduled show in Louisville, Kentucky, on March 14. Tickets will go on sale on March 9 at 10 a.m. local time, with portions of the ticket sales donated to various Louisville charities.

article: (CNN)A shooting at a bar popular with expatriates in Mali on Saturday killed five people, including French and Belgian citizens, authorities said. One French citizen, one Belgian and three Malians were killed in the attack in the capital of Bamako, said Gabriel Toure, director of a local hospital. An additional eight people were wounded, he said. Authorities called the shooting a "criminal and terrorist act." "Mali remains committed to seeking peace and will not be intimidated by those who have
summary: A shooting at a popular bar in Mali, attended by foreigners, resulted in the deaths of five individuals, including two French and one Belgian citizens, as well as injuring eight others. The incident was attributed to a criminal and terrorist act, with the perpetrators claiming responsibility for it through an audio message. Mali declared its commitment to peace and unity, while the French government condemned the attack and urged its citizens to stay vigilant. The United States and France have expressed solidarity and support for the Malian government in its efforts against terrorism.

article: (CNN)Manchester United defender Jonny Evans and Newcastle United striker Papiss Cisse have been charged by the Football Association for allegedly spitting during an altercation in Wednesday night's Premier League game at St James' Park. In a statement, English football's governing body said the players had been charged "in relation to an alleged breach of FA Rule E1[a] in that in or around the 38th minute of the game the two players spat at each other. "The incidents were not seen by the match o
summary: Manchester United defender Jonny Evans and Newcastle United striker Papiss Cisse have been charged by the Football Association (FA) for allegedly spitting during a Premier League game at St James' Park. The players were charged "in relation to an alleged breach of FA Rule E1[a]" in which they spat at each other. The incidents were caught on video and both players have until 6pm GMT on Friday to respond to the charge. If found guilty, they could face six-game bans. Former Liverpool midfielder Dietmar Hamann, now a TV pundit, believes that the behavior towards each other and the referee is deteriorating on a

article: March 10, 2015 . We're truly international in scope on Tuesday. We're visiting Italy, Russia, the United Arab Emirates, and the Himalayan Mountains. Find out who's attempting to circumnavigate the globe in a plane powered partially by the sun, and explore the mysterious appearance of craters in northern Asia. You'll also get a view of Mount Everest that was previously reserved for climbers. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Student
summary: The article discusses an upcoming visit to various countries such as Italy, Russia, the United Arab Emirates, and the Himalayan Mountains. The trip aims to circumnavigate the globe in a plane powered partially by the sun. Additionally, it explores the mysterious appearance of craters in northern Asia and provides a unique perspective on Mount Everest. The show transcript can be accessed at the provided link, and a chance to be featured on the CNN Student News Roll Call is offered to teachers and students aged 13 or older.

article: (CNN)Nine foreign workers are believed to be in the hands of ISIS-affiliated militants after an attack on a Libyan oil field, according to officials. Libya's internationally recognized government has blamed "ISIS militias" for the attack Friday in which the Al-Ghani oil field was set on fire. The kidnapped foreigners were working for VAOS, an Austrian-owned oil services company whose headquarters are in Tripoli, the Libyan capital. They include four Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech and a Ghanaian
summary: Nine foreign workers, including Filipinos, Austrians, Czechs, and Ghanaians, have been kidnapped by ISIS-affiliated militants in Libya, as the internationally recognized government blames "ISIS militias" for the attack on the Al-Ghani oil field. The abductions come amidst Libya's deteriorating security situation, where Islamic militias, some of which pledge allegiance to the extremist group ISIS, have thrived. Egypt has carried out airstrikes against ISIS militants in Libya, killing Egyptian Christians who had been kidnapped while working in a Libyan city. The kidnapping of the nine workers comes after a recent spate of violence by militants targeting oil fields

article: (CNN)Think back to your high school's senior prank. Maybe you and your pals slipped a pig into the building or greased all the door handles or turned all the chairs upside-down. So it's no surprise that Wichita high school Principal Sherman Padgett was reluctant to play along last week when a student showed up and told him to stand in the hallway holding a bucket. "She didn't say anything about why. She just said 'hold the bucket,' " the North High School principal told CNN affiliate KWCH. "I'm
summary: A high school principal in Kansas was surprised to receive heartfelt notes from students thanking him for making their high school experience so special. Principal Sherman Padgett, who has been at North High School for over a decade, was initially hesitant to accept the gifts, but eventually agreed to keep them. The notes came from students who had experienced various challenges throughout their time at the school, including overcoming eating disorders and seeking help for mental health issues. The principal found the experience emotionally rewarding and felt grateful for the opportunity to make a positive impact on the lives of his students.

article: (CNN)The search for a comic book artist missing in the Cayman Islands since Thursday is now being called a recovery mission. Norman Lee, an artist for DC and Marvel comics, went missing while snorkeling with his wife off the eastern coast of Grand Cayman, CNN affiliate WCVB reported. Strong currents hindered the search, which lasted until Friday evening, Cayman 27 reported. "It is unlikely that we will make any recovery at this stage," Chief Inspector Brad Ebanks told Cayman 27. Lee, 47, of Weym
summary: A 47-year-old comic book artist named Norman Lee was missing after going snorkeling with his wife in the Cayman Islands. His disappearance has been called a "recovery mission" due to strong currents making the search difficult. Lee, from Weymouth, Massachusetts, was known for creating characters like Wolverine and Starman. People have shared their love for him on social media and he had many friends, fans, and colleagues in the comic book industry.

article: March 9, 2015 . This week marks the anniversary of several historic events: a civil rights march to Selma, Alabama's Edmund Pettus Bridge, the disappearance of a Malaysia Airlines flight, and the commemoration of International Women's Day. We'll cover all of them this Monday on CNN Student News, and we explain why the latest U.S. unemployment report is a mixed bag. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Student News Roll Call. TRANSCRIP
summary: This week marks the anniversary of several historic events including a civil rights march to Selma, Alabama's Edmund Pettus Bridge, the disappearance of a Malaysia Airlines flight, and the commemoration of International Women's Day. CNN Student News will cover these events in detail on Monday and discuss the latest US unemployment report as a mixed bag. The show's transcript and a request form are available on the same page.

article: (CNN)Jessie Usher, the lead of Starz's series "Survivor's Remorse," has been cast in Fox's sequel "Independence Day 2." Liam Hemsworth has also been cast in a lead role and Jeff Goldblum will reprise his role as David Levinson from the original. It has been nearly 20 years since the Will Smith-starring sci-fi film hit theaters, grossing more than $800 million worldwide at the box office. Director Roland Emmerich will return to helm the film. "Independence Day 2" is set for release on June 24, 20
summary: Jessie Usher, from the TV series "Survivor's Remorse," has been cast in the sequel to the sci-fi film "Independence Day 2." Liam Hemsworth and Jeff Goldblum have also been cast in lead roles. "Independence Day 2" will be released on June 24, 2016, which marks 20 years since the original movie's release.

article: (CNN)Former Vice President Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic on Saturday after being admitted with influenza, hospital spokeswoman Kelley Luckstein said. "He's doing well. We treated him for flu and cold symptoms and he was released today," she said. Mondale, 87, was diagnosed after he went to the hospital for a routine checkup following a fever, former President Jimmy Carter said Friday. "He is in the bed right this moment, but looking forward to come back home," Carter said duri
summary: Former Vice President Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic due to influenza, with his condition improving after treatment for flu and cold symptoms. He had been hospitalized following a fever for a routine checkup. Mondale, 87, was named Geraldine A. Ferraro's running mate when he served as President under Jimmy Carter.

article: (CNN)The only thing crazier than a guy in snowbound Massachusetts boxing up the powdery white stuff and offering it for sale online? People are actually buying it. For $89, self-styled entrepreneur Kyle Waring will ship you 6 pounds of Boston-area snow in an insulated Styrofoam box -- enough for 10 to 15 snowballs, he says. But not if you live in New England or surrounding states. "We will not ship snow to any states in the northeast!" says Waring's website, ShipSnowYo.com. "We're in the busines
summary: A man named Kyle Waring offers to sell snow from Massachusetts for $89, claiming that it's not just a fun way to spend the winter but also a way to help people in colder areas. He sells 6 pounds of snow in an insulated Styrofoam box, which can make 10 to 15 snowballs. However, shipping snow to states like New England is not allowed, so Waring's business is limited to warmer states. Some customers have been buying snow as a joke, while others are using it for seasonal decorations.

article: (CNN)Farah fled the civil war in Syria with her husband in the middle of the night, hitching rides on trucks until they finally crossed into Jordan. Two days later, she gave birth to a girl in a country where they hold no status. Like 70,000 other refugees from Syria, Iraq, Sudan and the Palestinian Territories, Farah (her name and the others in this article have been changed to protect their anonymity) now lives with her family in Zarqa, a poor Jordanian city teeming with factories and crumblin
summary: Farah and other Syrian and Iraqi refugees living in Jordan face numerous challenges due to their lack of legal status and restricted access to employment opportunities. Despite these obstacles, some women have managed to establish small home-based businesses and gain economic independence. The Near East Foundation has supported these women by providing access to vocational training, financial resources, and social networks. However, there remains a significant need for continued advocacy and support for refugees to ensure their rights and opportunities are protected.

article: (CNN)Real Madrid fell to a lacklustre 1-0 defeat at the hands of Athletic Bilbao Saturday, potentially handing the La Liga advantage to arch rival Barcelona. A stunning header from Aritz Aduriz shortly before half time was enough to win the day for an organized and impressive Bilbao. Real piled on the pressure for much of the second half but couldn't find a way past a staunch opponent despite finishing the match with four strikers on the park. Gareth Bale struck a post with an extraordinary shot
summary: Real Madrid suffered a 1-0 defeat to Athletic Bilbao on Saturday, potentially giving Barcelona the advantage in the La Liga standings. Bilbao's Aritz Aduriz scored a stunning header early in the second half, while Real Madrid struggled to score despite having four players on the pitch. Real Madrid's manager Carlo Ancelotti expressed frustration over the team's lack of efficiency up front, as the club is currently without a win in two league games. Meanwhile, Bayern Munich secured a 3-1 win over Hannover, with Thomas Müller scoring twice to help them maintain their unbeaten streak. Paris Saint-Germain won

article: Tokyo (CNN)Police in Japan say they have arrested a 40-year-old man accused of fatally stabbing five neighbors in a farming community in Sumoto city. The man has admitted stabbing three women aged 59, 76 and 84, as well as two men aged 62 and 82, Deputy Police Chief Keizo Okumoto told CNN. He said the accused refused to comment further as he was awaiting his lawyer. The victims -- two couples and the 84-year-old woman -- lived within 100 meters (330 feet) of the suspect's home, police said. Acco
summary: A man in Japan, who is 40 years old, was caught by the police for killing five people. These people were living near him and they were all older than 50. They killed three women and two men, including one person who was 84 years old. The man didn't want to talk to the police about what happened, so he waited for a lawyer.

article: (CNN)A suicide attacker detonated a car bomb near a police vehicle in the capital of southern Afghanistan's Helmand province on Tuesday, killing seven people and injuring 23 others, the province's deputy governor said. The attack happened at about 6 p.m. in the Bolan area of Lashkar Gah city, said Mohammad Jan Rasoolyar, deputy governor of Helmand. Several children were among the wounded, and the majority of casualties were civilians, Rasoolyar said. Details about the attacker's identity and mot
summary: A suicide bomber detonated a car bomb in the capital city of southern Afghanistan's Helmand province on Tuesday, resulting in seven deaths and 23 injuries. The incident occurred at around 6 pm in the Bolan area of Lashkar Gah city, with several children among the injured. The attacker's identity and motive remain unknown.

article: (CNN)Pakistan's highest court Friday ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind behind the Mumbai attacks, calling his detention illegal. Lakhvi, a top leader of the terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba, was not present at Friday's court proceeding. The terror attacks in India left more than 160 people dead in November 2008. In the attacks, heavily armed men stormed landmark buildings around Mumbai, including luxury hotels, the city's historic Victoria Terminus train station
summary: The Pakistani Supreme Court has ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind behind the Mumbai attacks, calling his detention illegal. Lakhvi, a top leader of the terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba, was not present at the court proceedings. The terror attacks in India resulted in over 160 deaths in November 2008. In response, India's home minister, Rajnath Singh, expressed disappointment over the bail decision. Lakhvi was previously granted bail by the court, but the Pakistani government had challenged the decision. India executed the last surviving gunman from

article: (CNN)An officer, responding to reports of a suspicious person, shot and killed an unarmed man who was running around in a metro Atlanta apartment complex naked. The officer fired two shots when the man charged at him, said Cedric Alexander, the public safety director of DeKalb County. But given that the man was not carrying a weapon, the police department immediately turned over the case to the Georgia Bureau of Investigations for an independent probe. "What I have requested here [is] a result o
summary: A white police officer shot and killed an unarmed black man in DeKalb County, Georgia, after being reported by someone shouting at a naked man running around in a metro Atlanta apartment complex. The officer fired two shots at the man, who was struck twice in the upper body and died. The officer had access to a stun gun and pepper spray during the incident, and it is still unknown why he chose to draw his weapon.

article: London (CNN)A photo of a weasel hitching a surprise lift on the back of a flying woodpecker near London has gone viral on Twitter, with more than 7,000 users retweeting the original post of the image. It was first posted by photographer Jason Ward on Monday and credited to Martin Le-May. After #WeaselPecker gained momentum, British media soon picked up the story, and television channel ITV interviewed Le-May. The amateur photographer from Essex, near London, told the broadcaster he had been walk
summary: A photo of a weasel hitching a ride on a woodpecker has gone viral on Twitter, with over 7,000 users retweeting the initial post. Photographer Jason Ward found the unusual encounter while walking with his wife in Hornchurch Country Park, Essex. The weasel, known as a least weasel, appeared to struggle to keep hold of the woodpecker, which was likely a green woodpecker. The incident prompted ITV to interview Martin Le-May, who claimed the weasel took on the woodpecker after hearing a distress call. Mammal Society chief executive Marina Pacheco believes that

article: (Rolling Stone)Kanye West fans are used to seeing thousand-dollar price tags attached to the rapper's Air Yeezy sneakers when they're put up for sale on eBay, but the auction site is now being overrun by sellers offering up plastic bags full of air allegedly captured at West's concerts. The gag started Friday when one ambitious seller attempted to sell a Zipperseal bag with "Air From Kanye Show," with 90 bidders driving the price tag to over $60,000, the Telegraph reports. While that auction was
summary: The story discusses how thousands of dollars have been spent on selling bags filled with air supposedly taken during Kanye West's concerts on eBay, with the original auction reaching over $60,000. However, due to the overwhelming demand, eBay has stopped trying to shut down these new "bagged air" auctions. The article also mentions a similar auction offering flatulence, and other items such as Yeezy 750 Boost sneakers, which are currently priced between $1,700 to $5,000 on eBay. Kanye West aims to make his Yeezy Boosts affordable, but some buyers are

article: (CNN)The flight crew of the Delta Air Lines plane that skidded into a fence at LaGuardia Airport last week cited brake issues during the landing, according to an update on Monday from the NTSB. The crew said they did not sense any deceleration from the wheel brake upon landing, despite the auto brakes being set to "max," according to an ongoing investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board. The runway appeared all white in the moments before landing, according to the report. They bas
summary: A Delta Air Lines plane crashed into a fence at LaGuardia Airport due to malfunctioning brakes during landing. The crew reported no deceleration from the wheel brakes, despite setting the auto brakes to "max". The plane suffered significant damage, including the left wing, flight spoilers, nose, and left wing fuel tank. The captain couldn't stop the aircraft from drifting left, leading to a crash. The NTSB is investigating the incident, which occurred due to weather conditions and malfunctioning brakes.

article: (CNN)More than 100 schools in Pakistan have been renamed in honor of the children killed in a Taliban siege at a Peshawar school last year. According to the provincial government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, 107 local schools now bear the name of a student killed during the December 16 attack on the Army Public School. Government spokesman Mushtaq Ghani told CNN that the gesture was a way to remember the bravery of the students who were taking exams in an auditorium  when Taliban militants strapped wi
summary: In honor of the victims of the December 2014 Taliban siege at the Army Public School in Peshawar, more than 100 local schools in Pakistan have been renamed to commemorate the brave students who lost their lives during the attack.

article: (CNN)The Salvation Army in South Africa is using #thedress to spread a different kind of message about the colors black and blue. The organization is using the viral sensation to spread awareness about domestic violence. An ad shows a model wearing a white and gold dress resembling the one that caused an Internet meltdown last week as people debated whether the garment wasn't actually black and blue instead. The model also sports bruises on her face and body. The caption reads "Why is it so hard
summary: The Salvation Army in South Africa uses the viral #thedress controversy to raise awareness about domestic violence. A campaign featuring a model wearing a dress similar to the controversial piece, which was initially perceived as either black and blue or white and gold, reveals that the actual color scheme is black and blue. The ad's caption highlights the difficulty in seeing these colors and emphasizes that the only illusion occurs when individuals assume the dress was chosen by the model. This campaign aims to shed light on the issue of domestic violence.

article: (CNN)NASCAR announced Wednesday that it has lifted its suspension of driver Kurt Busch, making him eligible to return to the sport immediately -- albeit "under indefinite probation." Busch was suspended after a Delaware civil court found that he probably committed domestic violence against his former girlfriend, Patricia Driscoll. She accused the standout driver of grabbing her by the throat and slamming her head against a wall in his motor home at Delaware's Dover International Speedway in Sept
summary: NASCAR has lifted Kurt Busch's indefinite suspension, making him eligible to return to the sport immediately, though under "indefinite probation." Busch was suspended after a Delaware civil court found him guilty of domestic violence against his former girlfriend. The case was resolved when the Delaware Department of Justice decided not to file charges against him.

article: Kuala Lumpur (CNN)The initial hours after the disappearance of flight MH370 were characterized by confusion and chaos, as air traffic controllers struggled to comprehend the situation and radar operators failed to take notice, according to data contained in an interim report. The report -- released one year after the disappearance of the Boeing 777 and its 239 passengers and crew --- provides a detailed picture of delays and protocol violations before the launch of the search and rescue. An asto
summary: One year after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, the initial hours after the plane's disappearance were marked by confusion and chaos among air traffic controllers and radar operators. This led to delays and protocol violations, resulting in a five-hour gap between the last communication from the flight crew and the first distress signal. The report released by Malaysian investigators on Sunday highlights the importance of improved communication and cooperation between air traffic controllers and radar operators to prevent such incidents in the future.

article: Naypyidaw, Myanmar (CNN)Twenty-one people are dead and 21 missing after a ferry capsized in the Southeast Asia nation of Myanmar. Myanmar's Ministry of Information said in a statement that the ship capsized Friday night as it sailed, in bad weather conditions, around the city of Sittwe. That's when a large wave crashed into the ferry, causing it capsize near Myaybone and Myaukkyine islands. Authorities have managed to rescue at least 167 people, according to the information ministry for Myanmar,
summary: A ferry in Myanmar has capsized in bad weather conditions, resulting in 21 deaths and 21 missing. The ferry was sailing near the city of Sittwe in the Southeast Asian country. Rescue efforts have been ongoing, with authorities managing to rescue at least 167 people. The ferry capsized due to a large wave crashing into the ferry, causing it to capsize near Myaybone and Myaukkyine islands. The ferry capsizing occurred during a weekend weather forecast that called for some cloudy skies and clear skies, with high daytime temperatures expected to be in the 30s Celsius.

article: (CNN)Myanmar warplanes fighting rebels dropped a bomb at a sugarcane field in China, killing four civilians, the latter's state media reported Saturday. In addition to the fatalities, nine others were wounded, according to Xinhua news agency. Shortly after the incident Friday, China sent fighter jets to patrol over their shared border. The jets are there to "track, monitor, warn and chase away" Myanmar military planes, China's air force told state media. China summoned Myanmar's ambassador in Be
summary: Myanmar's warplanes dropped a bomb in a sugarcane field near China, killing four people and injuring nine. The incident occurred in Lincang, a border city with Myanmar, and prompted China to send fighter jets to patrol the border. The Myanmar government is currently investigating the attack and has requested that those responsible be brought to justice.

article: (CNN)When I was a child, a pale specter used to call our house most evenings, eager to chat with my doctor father about her myriad medical concerns. We called her the "White Bread Lady," a moniker she earned for one particularly inane call in which she panicked to my father after consuming white bread. She wasn't breaking out in hives or having any adverse effects to the bread. No, she was just concerned that some future illness could befall her given that one particular dietary decision. Althou

(CNN)A grand jury in Clark County, Nevada, has indicted a 19-year-old man accused of fatally shooting his neighbor in front of her house last month. Erich Nowsch Jr. faces charges of murder with a deadly weapon, attempted murder and firing a gun from within a car. Police say Nowsch shot Tammy Meyers, 44, in front of her home after the car he was riding in followed her home February 12. Nowsch's attorney, Conrad Claus, has said his client will argue self-defense. The Meyers family told police tha
summary: A 19-year-old man, Erich Nowsch Jr., has been indicted by a Grand Jury in Clark County, Nevada, on charges of murder with a deadly weapon, attempted murder, and firing a gun from a car. Nowsch allegedly killed his neighbor, Tammy Meyers, 44, after she was driving home in the same car as him and was followed by another car. Nowsch's attorney, Conrad Claus, claims his client will argue self-defense. Meyers's family reported a road rage incident and subsequent gunfire, leading to her death two days later. Nowsch was arrested five days

article: (CNN)With the ongoing protests over the shooting death by police of black teenager Tony Robinson in Madison, Wisconsin, the racist chanting of fraternity members at the University of Oklahoma, and now the inexcusable shootings of two police officers in Ferguson, Missouri, it's safe to say that the always-strained race relations in this country are being pushed to the breaking point. And the point with the most stress is the delicate relationship between police forces and the minority communities
summary: The article discusses the strained relationships between police forces and minority communities, particularly focusing on the ongoing protests and incidents in Ferguson, Missouri. It highlights the need to address these issues positively, encouraging responsible individuals to say the right things and engaging citizens in the community to bring about meaningful change. The author suggests various approaches, such as increasing police presence on the streets, involving officers in community activities, and using mediators to bring communities together, to foster trust and improve relations. The article emphasizes the importance of addressing the root causes of racial tension and building bridges between police and the communities they serve.

article: New Delhi, India (CNN)The North Korean ambassador in Bangladesh issued an apology after one of the embassy's diplomats was caught carrying 27 kilograms (59 pounds) of undeclared gold into the country's main airport in Dhaka, according to officials in Bangladesh. North Korean officials could not be reached for comment. Meanwhile, state media in the largely isolated communist country has not yet reported on the incident. Kazi Muhammad Ziauddin, a top official in Bangladesh's customs agency, told C
summary: North Korean Ambassador in Bangladesh apologizes for bringing 27kg of gold into Dhaka, violating customs regulations. No official comments from North Korea were made. Diplomatic immunity granted by the Vienna Convention may complicate investigation.

article: (CNN)The father of baby Lily, found by rescuers after her mother's car flipped into a river, says she's doing great and that he feels blessed. Rescuers found the toddler Saturday hanging upside down in the car, which had crashed into a frigid Utah river a day before. Lily's mother, Lynn Jennifer Groesbeck, died in the crash that had landed their car on its roof in the Spanish Fork River. She was 25. Deven Trafny, 34, was out of town on a job at the time of the accident, CNN affiliate KUTV report
summary: A father of a 2-year-old girl named Lily, who was found hanging upside down in a car that flipped into a cold Utah river, says his daughter is doing well. The father, Deven Trafny, rushed to her side when he heard the crash and is now by her side every day. Lily is awake and singing nursery rhymes, but doctors say it's amazing how much she knows after being inside the car for 14 hours. The father describes his wife, Lily's mother, as the love of his life, and while he misses her, he feels blessed to have her safe and sound.

article: (CNN)A medical helicopter carrying at least three people crashed late Thursday in Eufaula, Oklahoma, the Federal Aviation Authority  said. It was flying from Tulsa to McAlester when it went down west of Lake Eufaula, near the Canadian River. Three employees from medical air transport company EagleMed LLC were on board, according to FAA spokesman Lynn Lunsford. FAA investigators are headed to the crash scene. The McIntosh County Sheriff's Office is handling the crash for local law enforcement, bu
summary: A medical helicopter carrying three people crashed in Oklahoma on Thursday, with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) confirming the incident. The aircraft, flying from Tulsa to McAlester, went down west of Lake Eufaula, near the Canadian River. The FAA has sent investigators to the crash site. The crew consisted of employees from medical air transport company EagleMed LLC. Local authorities, including the McIntosh County Sheriff's Office, are handling the situation for law enforcement. A similar accident occurred earlier this week in Florida, where an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed into the Santa Rosa Sound, resulting in the loss of all 11 personnel

article: (WIRED)Screens are rectangles. Even the 3-year-old playing with your iPad could tell you that. But what would the digital world look like through a different sort of frame? Say... a circular one? Monohm, a startup based in Berkeley, California, was founded around this very idea. For the last year, the three-person team has been working a circular, palm-sized device dubbed Runcible. They cheekily refer to it as the "anti-smartphone," a description that goes for both its form factor and its value

(CNN)If you feel a ripple in the Force today, it may be the news that the official Star Wars universe is getting its first gay character. According to the sci-fi website Big Shiny Robot, the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith" will feature a capable but flawed Imperial official named Moff Mors who "also happens to be a lesbian." The character is the first gay figure in the official Star Wars universe -- the movies, television shows, comics and books approved by Star Wars franchise owner Disney --
summary: The upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith" will feature a capable but flawed Imperial official named Moff Mors who is also a lesbian. This makes him the first gay character in the official Star Wars universe, according to Big Shiny Robot and Random House's Del Rey Books.

article: Karachi, Pakistan (CNN)Suicide bombers attacked a Christian community in eastern Pakistan on Sunday, setting off two blasts that killed at least 14 people and wounded dozens more, officials said. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the deadly attack and warned of more to come. The explosions, which struck the Nishtar Colony area in the city of Lahore, wounded at least 78 people, said Dr. Muhammed Saeed Sohbin, medical superintendent at Lahore General Hospital. Video from the scene a
summary: Suicide bombers attacked a Christian community in eastern Pakistan, killing at least 14 people and injuring dozens more. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack and warned of more to come. The suicide bombings occurred in the Nishtar Colony area of Lahore, where video showed twisted metal, shattered glass, and panicked residents. The Pakistani military has been waging a campaign against the militant group in North Waziristan. Pope Francis condemned the attacks, calling for peace in Pakistan and urging that the persecution of Christians, which the world tries to hide, might end.

article: (CNN)They are very convincing when they call. They have a Washington phone number and can cite your financial history down to the cent. They say you're under investigation, in danger of losing your home, or worse, your freedom -- unless you pay thousands of dollars on the spot. But they're not real.  And you're not in trouble.  Not unless you take it seriously.  This is a scam. Email your story ideas and tips to CNNtips@cnn.com. A big one. Federal authorities say it's the largest IRS impersonati

(CNN)The attempts by some in the GOP to undermine President Barack Obama's Iranian policy certainly seem extraordinary. First, the Republican leadership invited Benjamin Netanyahu to speak to Congress without consulting the White House, and he duly warned against softening of the West's line on Iran. Now, 47 senators have written an open letter to the Iranian regime to advise that any deal agreed to with Obama could be reversed after the 2016 presidential election. It is an astonishing move. But
summary: Some Republicans in the US have tried to weaken President Obama's policies on Iran by inviting Benjamin Netanyahu to speak at a meeting with Congress and writing a letter to the Iranian government suggesting that any deal made with Obama could be changed after the 2016 presidential election. This is unusual because both parties have taken similar actions in the past.

article: (CNN)Pope Francis, who succeeded a resigning pontiff exactly two years ago, told a Mexican television network Friday that he expects his pontificate will be brief. "Four or five years," he told Televisa. "I do not know, even two or three. Two have already passed. It is a somewhat vague sensation. Maybe it's like the psychology of the gambler who convinces himself he will lose, so he won't be disappointed and if he wins, is happy. I do not know." Francis, who was elected in March 2013 after Pope
summary: Pope Francis, succeeding a resigning pope, stated that his reign will likely be brief, expecting it to last four or five years. He expressed interest in retiring at some point, citing a gambling mentality where one believes they will lose, thus avoiding disappointment and ensuring happiness upon winning. Francis also expressed his preference for the papacy not being limited by an age restriction, as he feels God only intended for him to serve briefly. He further mentioned missing the opportunity to engage in public appearances without drawing attention, preferring solitude with a wise elder figure like a grandparent.

article: (CNN)A Facebook post by actor Ashton Kutcher lamenting the lack of diaper changing tables in public men's rooms has parents talking. The new father -- he and partner Mila Kunis welcomed baby Wyatt Isabelle in October -- complained to his followers that he had yet to encounter a changing table in the public bathrooms he visits. He offered to give a social media shout-out to the first business where he found a diapering table in the men's room. The post had logged more than 230,000 comments as of
summary: An actor, Ashton Kutcher, posted about his struggle to find diaper changing tables in public men's rooms and received over 230,000 comments. Many people suggested locations, such as Walmart and Cracker Barrel, where changing tables are common. Some dads said they don't have issues finding changing tables since they visit more down-to-earth establishments. A mother also praised Kutcher for bringing the issue to light, saying it's not just a problem for him, but for many families. No update has been made on whether Kutcher has found a diapering station in a men's room.

article: (CNN)Closed for over a decade, a trail that's been described as "the world's most dangerous path" will no longer be off limits to the public thanks to a massive reconstruction project. Due to reopen March 26, Spain's stunning Caminito del Rey features a cliff face boardwalk that hangs 100 meters above the Guadalhorce River. The trail, which begins in the village of El Chorro in southern Malaga province, has been around since the early 1900s, originally built to provide access to two waterfalls f
summary: The Caminito del Rey trail, once closed for over a decade, will reopen to the public in March 2021 after a massive reconstruction project. Originally built in the early 1900s for access to two waterfalls, the trail was demolished due to fatal accidents in 1999 and 2000. The trail, now spanning 7.7 km, includes a 2.9 km boardwalk and famous sections like the Balconcillo de los Gaitanes bridge. The provincial government allocated 5.5 million euros for the project, and the reopening coincides with Spain

article: (CNN)Outside of Israeli politics, Isaac Herzog is not a well-known name. That may change on March 17, when Israelis head to the polls for election day. In the final round of polling before the elections, Herzog's Zionist Union party is in the lead, holding a four-seat edge over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party. "I believe in a certain type of leadership that is not always customary in this region. I'm not a general. I don't give orders. I know how to work together," he says. Throu
summary: Israeli politician Isaac Herzog is running in the final round of elections for Prime Minister. The Zionist Union party has a four-seat advantage over Likud party led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Herzog, who previously served as the leader of the Labor Party and the opposition leader, promises to take a different approach to leadership compared to Netanyahu. He emphasizes social reform and working with other nations to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

article: (CNN)Hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered in cities across Brazil this weekend, incensed by serious economic woes and a massive scandal involving the country's oil company. The demonstrators have called for President Dilma Rousseff to be impeached. CNN correspondent Shasta Darlington, who lives in Sao Paulo, explains who the demonstrators are, why they're mad and what could be in store for the President and the country. What do the protesters want? They're angry about the country's econo
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Brazil have gathered to demand the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, citing severe economic issues and allegations of political corruption at the country's oil company, Petrobras. The demonstrators accuse Rousseff of having ties to corrupt politicians and executives who allegedly bribed Petrobras officials to secure lucrative contracts. Despite Rousseff's denials, the protests have gained momentum, with the next demonstration set for April 12. The Petrobras scandal has been ongoing for several years, and while Rousseff has not been directly implicated, her support from the Workers' Party, which includes some lawmakers, has made it a significant issue

article: Jakarta (CNN)Turkish officials have detained 16 Indonesian citizens who confessed they were planning to cross the border into Syria, Indonesia's foreign ministry said. The group comprises a man, four women, three girls and eight boys, said spokesman Arrmanatha Nasir. The ages of the children have not been released. Nasir told reporters on Friday that the group was stopped in the southeastern Turkish city of Gaziantep, just north of the city of Aleppo in Syria. They admitted to officials they pla
summary: Indonesia has detained 16 Indonesian citizens who confessed to planning to cross the border into Syria. The group includes a man, four women, three girls, and eight boys, aged between 20 and 40. They were found in the southeastern Turkish city of Gaziantep, near the Syrian border. The Indonesian government will send a security team to investigate their objectives and plans and improve cooperation with Turkish security officials. This group is different from another 16 Indonesians who reportedly deserted their tour group in Turkey recently.

article: New Delhi (CNN)Thankfully, no one was wounded after crude bombs were hurled at a Tamil news station in India on Thursday. But the loud explosions injured a vital part of the world's largest democracy: free speech. Last week, when India's government and a British documentarian faced off over a film featuring a man imprisoned for a 2012 gang rape in South Delhi, a little-known channel hundreds of miles away in southern India was waging its own battle. Hardline Hindu groups were angry with broadcas
summary: A Tamil news station in India was attacked with crude bombs that injured a staff member and damaged its facilities. The attack occurred on International Women's Day, and the broadcaster cancelled a program that would have aired on that day due to protests against a film depicting a traditional necklace. Despite the attack, the broadcaster defended its right to free speech, stating that the content of the program was not offensive to Hindu culture. The incident highlights India's ongoing debate on free expression and the government's role in regulating media.

article: (CNN)"This is going to be a test for Serena Williams. We're going to find out what she's made of. How mentally tough she really is." Those were the words of tennis analyst Mary Joe Fernandez in 2001, early into Serena Williams' decider with Kim Clijsters in the final of one of tennis' most prestigious tournaments. The match was being televised on one of the biggest sports networks in the world, ESPN. The then 17-year-old Clijsters had just held to love amid vociferous cheers and -- in a breach o

(CNN)Could mobile technology turn the tide in the fight to eliminate racism from football? Anti-racism organization Kick It Out (KIO) says there's been a 35% rise in fans reporting abusive behavior committed by other fans -- and that's largely due to a new phone app. "The app has had a massive impact," KIO media and communications manager Richard Bates told CNN, noting that it accounted for 27% of all complaints. "Self-policing is so important when it comes to stamping out racism in football. Pe
summary: A mobile app called Kick It Out (KIO) has helped increase the number of people reporting racist behavior in football games. This has happened because the app helps fans tell about any bad things happening on the field without revealing their names. This makes it easier for the police to find the people who did these bad things. The app has been used for about five months now, and it has helped with 27% of the complaints.

article: (CNN)The news was stunning to hear: A young woman, 18-year-old Michelle Carter, was charged with involuntary manslaughter for allegedly sending text messages urging her friend to commit suicide. How could a young person -- who was a close friend of the deceased, Conrad Roy, 18 -- allegedly do such a horrifying thing? And what are the legal ramifications of what a teen says online or in a text? But a lesser discussed point this tragic story raises is how quickly a teen can go from normal everyday

(CNN)Thirty years ago, a journey across Europe meant a passport full of stamps, a wallet full of different currencies and plenty of time spent waiting in line to be glared at by border officials. That all began to change in June 1985, when the continent's countries began signing up to the Schengen agreement -- a deal that lifted frontier controls between cooperating neighbors. Today, 20 years after it came into force, with more than 26 states now participating, Schengen has completely altered th
summary: This article talks about how a long time ago, when going through Europe, people needed a lot of things like passports and money from different countries. But now, thanks to something called Schengen, there are fewer barriers and people can travel more easily across Europe without needing to show their passports or money from different countries.

article: (CNN)When man relies on machine, there is always something that can go wrong. And there is no more unforgiving environment than the high-stakes world of Formula One. "Racing is one of those... probably a crueler sport in that there's so many other variables," says Red Bull's No.1 driver Daniel Ricciardo, ahead of Sunday's season-opening Australian Grand Prix. "Unfortunately it's not like tennis where all the racquets are pretty much the same and you can't blame anyone but yourself." Ricciardo ex
summary: Formula One racing, known for its high stakes and unpredictable nature, can be particularly cruel due to numerous variables that can affect the outcome. Daniel Ricciardo, the No.1 driver for Red Bull, experienced this firsthand at last year's Australian Grand Prix, when he was disqualified for exceeding the maximum fuel flow rate. This rule change aimed to make the sport more fuel-efficient, but it also led to frustration among drivers, as it wasn't uncommon for the best cars to struggle with performance issues. However, technical mishaps do not always result in catastrophic failures, as evidenced by Lewis Hamilton's victory in Italy and Valterri Bottas

article: (CNN)"Cinderella," the latest live-action retelling of a classic, sparkled like a glass slipper in its opening weekend, with an estimated debut of $70.1 million. That's well above expectations of $50 to 60 million, and it tops last year's $69.4 million opening for "Maleficent," another take on the classic fairy tale, which featured Angelina Jolie and a darker tone. This version, however is sweetness and light, thanks to veteran director Kenneth Branagh. Small-screen stars Lily James ("Downton Ab
summary: "Cinderella" is a successful live-action adaptation of the classic fairy tale that performed exceptionally well in its opening weekend. With an estimated debut of $70.1 million, the film exceeded expectations of $50 to 60 million. This marks a significant improvement over last year's $69.4 million opening for "Maleficent." The film features veteran director Kenneth Branagh and small-screen stars Lily James and Richard Madden, who portray Ella and her Prince. Critics have praised the film, with a current Rotten Tomatoes rating of 83%, and it has been well-received among audiences. The film

article: (CNN)The march toward publication of another book by the reclusive "To Kill a Mockingbird" author continues forward. Many people who know her have raised questions about 88-year-old Harper Lee's ability to consent to publish another book, while others have said she knows what she's doing, according to a New York Times report. Alabama officials have found Lee wants to publish the book. Since Lee wrote "To Kill a Mockingbird" in 1960, she had steadfastly refused to publish another book. Lee now li
summary: Harper Lee, who wrote "To Kill a Mockingbird," has been making headlines recently after expressing interest in publishing another book called "Go Set a Watchman." Many people are curious about whether Lee is able to give her consent to publish this new book. Some believe she may not be able to make decisions due to her age and memory issues, while others think she knows exactly what she's doing. Lee's friends and family have expressed their support for her decision to publish the book. HarperCollins, the company responsible for publishing the book, has announced that they will release it in July.

article: (CNN)It's a striking image: a new baby cradled in the American flag, held by a Navy sailor whose face we can't see. But is it a patriotic photograph or desecration of the American flag? Navy veteran Vanessa Hicks, a Virginia Beach photographer whose website is filled with sweet images of babies and their parents, shot the picture of the sailor and his baby and posted it to her Facebook page. "I do believe that this picture right here shows what it means to be an American," Hicks told CNN affilia
summary: A mother of a Navy sailor took a photo of him holding his baby while wearing an American flag around his neck. Some people criticized the photo as desecration of the flag, but others saw it as a way to show patriotism and love for the country.

article: (CNN)I'm Candida Moss and I am professor of New Testament and Early Christianity at the University of Notre Dame. I was an adviser on the "True Cross" episode and served as one of the many on-camera experts in CNN's "Finding Jesus" series, which currently airs on Sundays. Viewers were invited to tweet and post their questions on the "Finding Jesus" Facebook page during the show. Below are some of the more interesting questions and my answers to them. My apologies to everyone I didn't get to. Fee

Andre Spicer is Professor of Organizational Behavior, Cass Business School at City University London. The views expressed in this commentary are solely those of the writer. CNN is showcasing the work of The Conversation, a collaboration between journalists and academics to provide news analysis and commentary. The content is produced solely by The Conversation. LondonApple CEO Tim Cook has released the much-anticipated Apple watch -- his company's first new product since the iPad. Cook said the

(CNN)Police raided millionaire heir Robert Durst's home in Houston, Texas, on Tuesday, a day after he was charged with first-degree murder. Dick DeGuerin, Durst's attorney, confirmed that investigators were searching the home. It was not immediately clear what they were looking for inside Durst's 14th-floor condo, where he has lived for many years, CNN affiliate KTRK reported. The raid comes days after FBI agents arrested Durst in a New Orleans hotel. The Los Angeles County District Attorney fil
summary: A wealthy man named Robert Durst was arrested in Houston, Texas, and his house was searched by police. They found some things that might help solve a mystery about his past. People are still trying to figure out why someone hurt Susan Berman, who was a close friend of Durst's, and why he is accused of doing it.

article: (CNN)America may be growing less hateful. That's according to an annual Southern Poverty Law Center report that says the number of hate groups in the United States remains on the decline for the second year in a row. In the "Intelligence Report" released Tuesday, the SPLC says the number of hate groups operating in the U.S. declined 17% between 2013 and 2014. They are now at their lowest levels since 2005, the watchdog organization said. "Patriot groups, which are animated by a series of conspir

(CNN)The Rev. Fred Craddock, the pulpit giant who was "like no other preacher you have ever heard," has died, his church announced. Craddock, who redefined the art of preaching, died Friday in Blue Ridge, Georgia. The cause has not been disclosed. The 86-year-old had been in declining health due to Parkinson's disease in recent years, according to the United Methodist Reporter. "Fred Craddock was a national treasure and a devoted servant of the church and Jesus Christ. His impact on preaching --
summary: The Rev. Fred Craddock, a renowned preacher who revolutionized the art of preaching by incorporating conversational styles and unique storytelling techniques, passed away on Friday at the age of 86. Known as a "preaching genius," Craddock was widely regarded as one of the most effective preachers in the English-speaking world. He faced his toughest challenge converting those who thought he was overly simplistic, as exemplified by his ability to relate complex theological concepts to everyday life.

article: (CNN)The State Department only last month started automatically preserving dozens of high-level officials' emails, according to a department spokeswoman, a revelation that comes amid the controversy surrounding former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's own email use. This is key because Clinton, in her news conference on Tuesday to answer questions about why she exclusively used a private email address to communicate during her tenure, told reporters she'd thought her communications to senior
summary: The State Department started automatically saving the emails of many high-level officials, including former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, in February. However, Clinton initially claimed that her communications with senior officials were always saved, but later admitted that this wasn't true. This revelation has sparked controversy, with some Republicans calling for Clinton to turn over her personal email server, which contains sensitive information. Clinton has asked for these emails to be made public, and the State Department is currently reviewing them to determine what information should be kept confidential.

article: (CNN)Two more American aid workers who had high-risk exposure to Ebola in Sierra Leone arrived back in the United States on Monday for monitoring. Neither is sick or known to be infected with the disease. Eight of their colleagues have already been flown back to the United States, where health authorities are watching them closely for signs of the disease, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The returning workers are clinicians for Partners in Health, a Boston-based aid

(CNN)Former Manchester United star Danny Welbeck returned to haunt his old side to send holders Arsenal into the semifinals of the FA Cup with a 2-1 victory at Old Trafford Monday. The England striker was surplus to requirements at Louis van Gaal's United, but was quick to capitalize on a mistake by Antonio Valencia to grab the winner just after the hour mark. A disappointing night for United was compounded by a late red card for Argentina international Angel Di Maria, who was given his marching
summary: Manchester United lost 2-1 to Arsenal in the FA Cup final. Danny Welbeck scored a crucial goal in the 76th minute, giving Arsenal a 2-1 win. This win sent Arsenal into the semifinals, where they will face either Reading or Bradford City. Liverpool or Blackburn Rovers will also play Aston Villa in the other semifinal. Arsenal's victory was made possible by a penalty kick awarded to them after an incident involving Angel Di Maria. This marks the first time Manchester United has lost in the FA Cup final since 2009.

article: Ferguson, Missouri (CNN)Loistine Hoskin cared for her old car as a sentimental possession, missing a tire while parked beside her home, until one day the city ticketed her for having a "derelict vehicle in driveway." A tow truck took it away in 2009. So began an odyssey with Ferguson police, municipal court and city hall that left her with $1,200 in fines that to this day she still doesn't fully understand. She paid the sum because endless court hearings about the car wore her down. "I don't hav

Moscow (CNN)Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in a series of photos released by the Kremlin on Friday after a week in which canceled engagements led to speculation over his health. The three images showed Putin meeting with the head of the Supreme Court in Moscow on Friday, the Kremlin said. State broadcaster Russia 24 also aired video footage of the meeting. CNN cannot independently confirm that the meeting took place as stated. Presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov sought to quell the r
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin was photographed in a series of photos released by the Kremlin after a week in which canceled engagements led to speculation over his health. These photos showed Putin meeting with the head of the Supreme Court in Moscow on Friday. President Putin's last public appearance was on International Women's Day, and since then, he has had a number of meetings without video being released.

article: (CNN)Thiago Silva's path to redemption took a mere 12 minutes. For that short period of time the Brazilian must have been panicking that his needless error had cost his Paris Saint-Germain side a place in the last eight of the European Champions League. His handball had gifted English Premier League leaders Chelsea a 2-1 aggregate advantage in extra time, but this was one tale that would be adorned with a Silva lining. Seconds after being denied by a world class save from Thibaut Courtois, Silva

(CNN)The UK's Metropolitan Police has summoned five football fans to answer allegations of racism. It relates to an incident captured on camera, prior to Chelsea's European Champions League match with Paris Saint-Germain last month. In the French capital before the match an apparent group of Chelsea fans are caught on camera, appearing to prevent a black man boarding the Paris Metro. The video, widely shared on social media, also depicted the group of men chanting: "We're racist, we're racist an
summary: Five football fans have been summoned to answer allegations of racism after an incident captured on camera at the Paris Metro before a match between Chelsea and Paris Saint-Germain. The man in the video was blocked several times from boarding the train and shoved off at least twice. The incident was widely shared on social media and led to a police appeal for help to identify the perpetrators. Chelsea and the Metropolitan Police Service have also condemned the incident.

article: (CNN)If you enjoy laughing at the England football team -- calling all Germans and Scots -- and you have a spare $900,000, then Sotheby's has the very thing for you. The auction house is offering an untitled work by Italian sculptor Maurizio Cattelan that chronicles -- in painstaking and painful detail if you are English -- every defeat suffered by the England team between 1874 and 1998. Cattelan has carved all the defeats into a large (and it would have to be, wouldn't it?) piece of black grani
summary: Sotheby's is selling an unusual artwork that shows every defeat England has suffered in soccer from 1874 to 1998. The sculpture is made of black granite and is called "untitled." The artist, Maurizio Cattelan, created it as a way to remember moments when England lost games and to show how they could improve. The sculpture is currently on display at Sotheby's New Bond Street galleries until March 10th. If you buy it, you'll always have a reminder of these disappointing moments.

article: (CNN)A crowd of tens of thousands filled Yitzhak Rabin Square in Tel Aviv on Saturday evening, calling for a change in Israeli leadership amid growing discontent with the current administration. The rally, called "Israel Wants Change," was put on by One Million Hands, a grassroots movement that focuses its efforts on two major issues: a two-state solution and a reduction in the cost of living. On both of these topics, founder Dror Ben-Ami says, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has failed. "We t
summary: A large crowd of tens of thousands gathered in Tel Aviv on Saturday night, calling for changes in Israeli leadership, especially due to the current Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's perceived failures regarding a two-state solution and reducing the cost of living. Organized by the grassroots movement "One Million Hands," the rally aimed to push for the resignation of Netanyahu and encourage voters to support alternative candidates. Despite Netanyahu's popularity in Israel, the protest highlights growing discontent and calls for change among Israelis.

article: (CNN)Paul McCartney, Patti Smith, Beck, and John Legend are ready to rock Cleveland. On Wednesday the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame announced an array of A-list presenters and performers for its 30th Annual Induction Ceremony, which takes place at Cleveland's historic Public Hall on Saturday, April 18. Seven artists and musical groups will be honored with induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame during the ceremony. The newly announced presenters list includes: . Paul McCartney (inducting form
summary: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame has announced the lineup for its 30th Annual Induction Ceremony, set to take place at Cleveland's Public Hall on April 18. Seven artists and musical groups will be inducted into the Hall of Fame during the ceremony, including Paul McCartney (Ringo Starr), Stevie Wonder (Bill Withers), Patti Smith (Lou Reed), Peter Wolf (The Paul Butterfield Blues Band), Fall Out Boy (Green Day), John Mayer (Stevie Ray Vaughn), and Steve Cropper (The 5 Royals). The ceremony will feature performances by Beck, John Legend, Jimmie

article: (CNN)A U.S. Air Force veteran who allegedly tried to join ISIS in Syria but was turned back by Turkish authorities before he could get to the war-torn country entered a not guilty plea to terror-related charges Wednesday in a federal court in New York. Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh, accused of making the foiled attempt in January, was indicted by a grand jury on charges of trying to give material support to the terror group and obstruction of justice, the U.S. Justice Department said in a two-count

(CNN)We have no problem taking Wall Street executives to task for decisions that leave American families financially devastated, yet we give Silicon Valley billionaires a pass when they do the same thing. America needs to realize that instead of creating jobs, Silicon Valley is erasing them, leaving millennials financially stranded before their careers can get off the ground. Silicon Valley is tossing millennials aside like yesterday's laptop. The commonly held belief is that with hard work and

(CNN)Life on a Civil War ship in the Deep South was no pleasure cruise. Heat, humidity, the rigors of military life and bouts of boredom could frustrate a fella. So it may be no surprise that among the first artifacts to be brought up from the wreck of the CSS Georgia in Savannah are two sets of leg irons. "We all know about discipline in the Navy," said Jim Jobling, a project manager with Texas A&M University's Conservation Research Laboratory.  "It is for restricting the mobility of a prisoner

(CNN)Vigilante motorists in New Zealand have taken to snatching the car keys of foreign drivers amid rising concern over dangerous driving by tourists. New Zealand media have reported five cases this year of locals forcibly taking the keys of foreign motorists after witnessing driving that concerned them. All the incidents -- which have been condemned by authorities -- took place in the South Island, which draws tourists from around the world for its rugged scenery, including lakes and mountains
summary: In New Zealand, vigilante motorists have taken the car keys of foreign drivers due to concerns over dangerous driving by tourists. Five cases have been reported this year, and the situation has led to heightened public concern over tourist driving standards. The key snatchings have even prompted Prime Minister John Key to advise against taking the law into one's own hands. While there may be exceptional circumstances where taking someone's keys could be legally justified, such as preventing drunken driving, it is generally not recommended. The New Zealand Transport Agency later revealed that Robert Penman, a diesel mechanic in Dunedin, took the keys of a Chinese couple who had stopped their car

article: (CNN)Relief workers reported "unbelievable destruction" after Tropical Cyclone Pam smashed the capital of Vanuatu, the Australian Red Cross said Saturday. The Australian Red Cross said via Twitter that "humanitarian needs will be enormous. Many people have lost their homes. Shelter, food and water (are) urgent priorities" in Port Vila. Meteorologists said the storm has weakened some, but it was still pounding the islands after hours of fierce winds and torrential rain. "#CyclonePam still tearing

Esfahan, Iran (CNN)If you're looking for the Jewish community in the Iranian town of Esfahan, you won't have to search for long. The main synagogue is on Palestine Square, right in the heart of Iran's third largest city. There are public prayers several times a day -- sometimes with more than a hundred people in attendance. The Jewish community in Iran does not hide its heritage. At the synagogue, Michael Malakon leads the prayer service. He says he is proud of his Jewish identity. And even in a
summary: The Jewish community in the Iranian town of Esfahan consists of about 1,500 people, with public prayers held daily and the Star of David prominently displayed in various locations. Despite facing hostility from the Islamic Republic, the community practices freely and maintains strong ties with other Iranians. With multiple synagogues and a prominent Jewish representative in Iran's parliament, the community remains active and engaged within the country. The majority of Esfahan's Jews work in business, and while they avoid discussing current political tensions, they still aim for peace and unity.

article: (CNN)Are the upcoming elections in Israel crucial? Will the results -- a fourth term for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or a first for opposition leader Isaac Herzog -- change Israel's policy in a significant way? As Israelis prepare to go to the polls, the answer seems to be negative. Many observers in Europe and the United States seem to be under the impression that during Netanyahu's time in power, Israel was hijacked by right wing zealots -- and that Herzog, leader of the Zionist Union op

(CNN)A video purportedly shows three British schoolgirls preparing to cross the Turkish border last month into Syria, where the teens are believed to have traveled to join ISIS, a Turkish TV network reported Friday. If authentic, the video would represent the first publicly released images showing the girls at the Turkey-Syria border. The video, released by Turkish TV network A Haber and distributed by Reuters, shows three warmly dressed females who resemble the missing teens standing with lugga
summary: The BBC reports that a video allegedly showing three British schoolgirls crossing the Turkish border into Syria to join ISIS has surfaced. If true, this would mark the first public image of the girls at the border. The video was captured in Gaziantep, Turkey, and features the girls wearing coats with hooded fur, possibly indicating they were dressed like ISIS members. The footage was reportedly filmed February 19th and released by Turkish TV network A Haber. Despite being claimed by the network, CNN could not verify its authenticity. The video was obtained by A Haber, although it's unclear how.

article: (CNN)Kerry Washington is headed for HBO. The "Scandal" star has signed on to play Anita Hill and executive produce a TV movie for the premium cable network, The Hollywood Reporter has learned. Called "Confirmation," the telepic — which is in development from HBO Films — will detail the explosive 1991 Clarence Thomas-Hill Supreme Court nomination hearings, which brought the country to a standstill and forever changed the way people think about sexual harassment, victims' rights and modern-day rac
summary: Kerry Washington, known for her role in the popular TV show "Scandal," has signed on to play Anita Hill, an important figure in the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Hill Supreme Court nomination hearings that brought significant changes to the country's views on sexual harassment, victims' rights, and modern-day race relations. The TV movie titled "Confirmation" is set to be produced by HBO Films and is currently in development. The project is being written by Academy Award-nominated screenwriter Susannah Grant and executive produced by Kerry Washington, Michael London (ABC's "Astronaut Wives Club"), and Janice Williams, along

article: (CNN)Just when you didn't think Republicans could top themselves in finding ways to disrespect the President of the United States, on Monday, 47 Republican Senators -- that is, all but seven -- sent a letter to Iran that appeared aimed at scuttling President Obama's diplomatic efforts to prevent Tehran developing nuclear weapons capacity. The move comes on the heels of House Republicans inviting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address Congress -- without even informing the White Hou
summary: Republican senators sent a letter to Iran, which appeared aimed at scuttling President Obama's diplomatic efforts to prevent Tehran developing nuclear weapons capacity. The move came after House Republicans invited Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address Congress without notifying the White House. The letter was carefully drafted to avoid crossing the line of legality, specifically by not explicitly taking a position against the Iran negotiations. The incident reflects a pattern of deep disrespect towards President Obama and a broader anti-Obama sentiment within the Republican Party.

article: Aberdeenshire, Scotland (CNN)The Scottish Highlands on a wintry morning in January made for an awe-inspiring interview setting. We traveled along narrow roads winding among snow-capped mountains, eventually arriving at Birkhall -- the Scottish home to Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall. I had pitched for interviews with the couple several times over the years and finally Prince Charles accepted. I wanted to speak to them about their 10 years of marriage and their upcoming
summary: Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, spent a day in their Scottish home at Birkhall with CNN reporters. The couple discussed their 10-year marriage, their upcoming US tour, and their character. The visit provided a rare opportunity for journalists to get a closer look at the royals, despite the restrictions placed on them.

article: (CNN)University of Virginia student leaders have scheduled a campus forum with police Friday to discuss allegations of brutality following the bloody arrest of a 20-year-old student that prompted protests at UVA. The incident early Wednesday involved uniformed alcohol control agents and Martese Johnson, an African-American student at UVA. It made headlines around the country and prompted Gov. Terry McAuliffe to order an independent Virginia State Police investigation into what happened. The on-c
summary: University of Virginia student leaders have scheduled a campus forum with police Friday to discuss allegations of brutality following the bloody arrest of a 20-year-old student that prompted protests at UVA. The incident early Wednesday involved uniformed alcohol control agents and Martese Johnson, an African-American student at UVA. It made headlines around the country and prompted Gov. Terry McAuliffe to order an independent Virginia State Police investigation into what happened. The on-campus forum is scheduled for 1 p.m. Friday. In a Facebook post, the university's Student Council said representatives from Charlottesville, Virginia, police, Albemarle County police and the state

article: (CNN)I met Kelly Gissendaner in January 2010 in a nondescript classroom at Metro State Prison for Women in Atlanta. She arrived for class beaming with excitement about the journey she was about to begin -- participation in a yearlong academic theology program sponsored jointly by four Atlanta seminaries.
