Since she has been sentenced to the death penalty and lives in solitary confinement, Kelly was particularly eager to share community with others, if only one morning a week. And she was grateful

Boston (CNN)Eight minutes of sheer terror. That's what police officers from Watertown, Massachusetts, described in heart-stopping detail Monday, revealing details of a chaotic shootout with the Boston Marathon bombing suspects. One of the suspects, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, died from injuries he sustained that day -- wounded in a gun battle, then run over by his brother, Dzhokhar. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev managed to escape, but was later caught by police. Now he's on trial, facing 30 charges for the marathon

(CNN)All 11 service members aboard an Army Black Hawk helicopter that crashed in waters off the Florida Panhandle two days ago are believed dead, and the operation has transitioned from rescue to recovery, an Air Force official said Thursday. The military is now focused on recovering the helicopter, which searchers found at the bottom of the Santa Rosa Sound near Eglin Air Force Base, and the bodies of all seven Marines and four Louisiana Army National Guard members who were aboard, Air Force Co
summary: On Tuesday, a Black Hawk helicopter carrying 11 soldiers crashed into the Santa Rosa Sound near Eglin Air Force Base in Florida. All 11 service members, including seven Marines and four Louisiana Army National Guard members, are believed dead. The military is now focusing on recovering the helicopter and the bodies of all seven Marines and four Louisiana Army National Guard members. The military is also trying to determine why the helicopter crashed in thick fog during a training mission. The Coast Guard suspended active search and rescue operations due to the dense fog, and the remains of at least two National Guard members were recovered on Thursday. The military has not yet released

article: Tunis (CNN)The bodies of four Italian tourists slain in a terror attack on Tunisia's Bardo Museum three days ago arrived back in Italy on Saturday, an official with the Tunis Crisis Center told CNN, but 14 victims' remains still lie in the morgue. As Tunisia gets back on its feet, the investigation into Wednesday's shooting at the Tunis landmark continues. Most of the 23 victims were foreigners, making the process of identification more complicated. Nineteen of them were tourists who'd been on t

Ferguson, Missouri (CNN)Ferguson's police chief and other city officials are already out. Now some residents have told the Missouri city they'll try to oust the mayor, too. Five residents Friday filed an affidavit saying they'll try to force a referendum on whether to remove Mayor James Knowles -- capping a tumultuous week in a community grappling not only with last year's fatal shooting of teenager Michael Brown, but also Wednesday's wounding of two police officers shot during a protest. A grou
summary: Five residents of Ferguson, Missouri, have filed an affidavit stating their intention to try to force a referendum on whether to remove Mayor James Knowles from office, following a tumultuous week in the community that includes the fatal shooting of teenager Michael Brown and the subsequent Justice Department report alleging institutionalized racism within the local government, including the police department.

article: (CNN)Her murder shocked a nation, but according to the slain woman's father, it also woke Turkey up. Ozgecan Aslan's body was found last month, burned and abandoned, just days after her family reported her missing. She allegedly fought off a sexual assault before being killed by the driver of a bus she'd taken to go home. Her death sparked widespread protests. "A country woke up," Aslan's father, Mehmet Aslan, told CNN in a phone interview. "There was no way for so many people to come together o
summary: Turkey woke up after the murder of Ozgecan Aslan, a 20-year-old student who was brutally attacked and killed by the driver of a bus she took home. The incident sparked widespread protests demanding Turkey take action to protect women. Since her death, hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets and online, calling for better protection for women. However, Mehmet Aslan, the father of the murdered woman, believes that this tragedy was meant to awaken people and bring attention to the issue of gender-based violence. He plans to use the funds raised from donations to establish a rehabilitation center for men who commit crimes against women

article: (CNN)Lindsey Vonn may have missed out on gold at last month's world championships, but the American skier has set her sights on end-of-season glory after claiming a record-extending 65th World Cup win on Sunday. Vonn's victory in the super-G event at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in Germany gave her the outright lead in the speed discipline ahead of this month's finals in France. Having finished seventh in Saturday's downhill, the 30-year-old rebounded by coming home 0.2 seconds ahead of overall World
summary: Lindsey Vonn, an American skier, won a record-extending 65th World Cup win in the super-G event at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in Germany. This win gave her the outright lead in the speed discipline ahead of the finals in France. Vonn's performance helped her edge past Tina Maze, who had claimed the world championship in Colorado earlier, and take the bronze medal in the downhill event. Despite this, Vonn is still 35 points behind overall World Cup leader Anna Fenninger.

article: (CNN)Melissa was sold into the sex trade by a family member when she was only 12 years old. Her life became a prison: Chained to a bed in a warehouse, she endured regular beatings, rapes and once was even set on fire by her captors as she was forced to serve 5 to 30 men every day. The experience was enough for her to wish she was dead. And this all took place in Texas -- right here, in our own country. Melissa miraculously escaped her captors but, as is the case with so many other victims, she s
summary: A 12-year-old girl named Melissa was sold into the sex trade by her family member. She endured beatings, rapes, and even being set on fire. Melissa escaped but struggled to distance herself from her past. Thousands of children across America are victims of sex trafficking, and the current system does not treat them well. Two bills, the Justice for Victims of Trafficking Act and the Safe Harbor Law, aim to help victims and bring criminals to justice.

article: (CNN)"I will come to Tunisia." It's a bold pledge, some might say. But people across the globe are making that vow despite the deadly attack in the Tunis on Wednesday. Twenty-three people, most of them tourists, were killed after gunmen opened fire inside the Bardo Museum, a stone's throw from the parliament building. The "I will come to Tunisia" social media campaign is aimed at protecting the North African nation's tourism industry -- which is critical to the country's economy. The social medi
summary: In response to the deadly attack at the Bardo Museum in Tunisia, a social media campaign called "I will come to Tunisia" has emerged, urging people around the world to visit the country as a way to protect its tourism industry, which is vital to the economy. The hashtag #JeSuisBardo, #JeSuisTunisien, and #PrayForTunisia trended on Twitter, with tens of thousands of users expressing support and solidarity with the victims. Tourism is a crucial source of income for Tunisia, with an estimated 40% of the population relying on it for their livelihoods. However

article: (CNN)To come back or not come back? That is the question former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli posed on Twitter, prompting a raft of replies and retweets. The Frenchwoman was crowned champion at the All England Club in July 2013, but announced her retirement a mere one month later due to persistent injury problems. But now it appears the former world No. 7 is pondering a return to the court, with eight-time grand slam champion Jimmy Connors warning Bartoli to only consider it if she is fully
summary: Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli has been asked whether she should come back to tennis, with some fans urging her to take the opportunity if she really wants to play. Bartoli, who retired from tennis a month after winning the championship in 2013 due to injuries, was recently questioned by Jimmy Connors about returning to the court. While some players have chosen to come back after retiring, Connors advised Bartoli to only consider it if she is truly committed. Bartoli's decision could potentially pave the way for other women's stars to come back into the game.

article: (CNN)Actress Liza Minnelli has entered a rehab facility for her addictions, a spokesman said. "Liza Minnelli has valiantly battled substance abuse over the years and whenever she has needed to seek treatment she has done so," said spokesman Scott Gorenstein.  "She is currently making excellent progress at an undisclosed facility." The 68-year-old has struggled with addictions to alcohol and painkillers in the past. Minnelli won an Oscar in 1973 for her performance in "Cabaret." CNN's Topher Gauk
summary: Actress Liza Minnelli has entered a rehabilitation facility due to her ongoing battles with substance abuse. She has previously faced addiction issues with alcohol and painkillers. Currently, Minnelli is making positive strides at an undisclosed facility. Her accomplishments include winning an Oscar in 1973 for her role in "Cabaret."

article: Moscow (CNN)The primary suspect jailed in connection with the shooting death of Boris Nemtsov withdrew his confession Wednesday, saying he had been under duress during his admission and isn't guilty. Zaur Dadayev told two members of Russia's human rights council that he pleaded guilty after being detained because he was scared. He told Eva Merkacheva and Andrey Babushkin he had been tortured and the well-being of his family and friends were threatened. Dadayev was one of two suspects recently ch
summary: A man who was once accused of being the main suspect in the murder of a prominent Russian opposition leader, Boris Nemtsov, now says he didn't confess to the crime and is not guilty. He claims he was forced to admit his guilt after being held and threatened with harm to his family and friends. Two human rights activists who spoke with him were arrested and face charges of interfering with the investigation, raising concerns about the fairness of the case.

article: (CNN)Empathy. Confidence. Passion. These are the traits the next police chief in Ferguson, Missouri, will need to shrink the ocean of distrust between community and police. So says Cecil Smith. And maybe he should know. Smith is the police chief in Sanford, Florida, another community rocked by racial tensions and poor police-community relations after the high-profile shooting of a black teenager -- the 2012 death of Trayvon Martin. And if Smith's experience is any guide, it will take "a lot of p

(CNN)There can be no March without the madness. When it comes to college basketball, the first month of spring ushers in a frantic slew of games to determine seedings for one of the most fervently watched sporting events in the U.S., known simply as the NCAA Tournament, or more often, March Madness. Like English soccer's FA Cup, much of the 68-team tournament's appeal is its egalitarian system of pitting traditional powerhouse programs like Duke, UCLA and Kentucky against relative minnows like S

(CNN)This week, Google CFO Patrick Pichette made headlines when his resignation memo announcing his retirement surfaced in the media. But the uproar wasn't that Pichette was quitting so much as why. "After nearly seven years as CFO," he began, "I will be retiring from Google to spend more time with my family." What he wanted now was to enjoy life at home and abroad with his wife, to "grab our backpacks and hit the road -- celebrate our last 25 years together by turning the page and enjoy a perfe

(CNN)A.J. Pero, a longtime drummer for the metal band Twisted Sister, has died, the band posted on its Facebook page. "The members of Twisted Sister are profoundly saddened to announce the untimely passing of our brother, AJ Pero," said the post. "The band, crew and most importantly the family of AJ Pero thank you for your thoughts and prayers at this time." Pero was 55. Pero died of what appears to be a massive heart attack, his longtime agent Dan Stanton told CNN. "He had been complaining of a
summary: Twisted Sister drummer A.J. Pero, who had been touring with them, passed away at the age of 55 due to a massive heart attack. He was found in his tour bus and taken to a hospital where he died. The band, along with his family and friends, are deeply saddened by his loss.

article: (CNN)The world of Mexican wrestling wrestling has been deeply shaken by the death of star fighter Hijo del Perro Aguayo, who collapsed after being kicked during a bout. The lucha libre fighter, whose real name is Pedro Aguayo Ramirez, was left slumped against the ropes after a flying kick from one of his opponents, Rey Mysterio, during the match Friday night. The other wrestlers continued with the fight as Aguayo's limp body slid down onto the mat, according to video footage of the bout posted o
summary: Mexican wrestling star Pedro "Hijo del Perro Aguayo" died after collapsing during a match, leaving behind a legacy as a decorated wrestler. His death sparked a nationwide outpouring of grief and tributes, including a tribute from WWE wrestler Mark Henry. The cause of Aguayo's death remains unclear.

article: (CNN)New Zealand police have revealed a threat to contaminate infant formula and other dairy formula with poison, in an apparent attempt to blackmail the government over its pest control policies. Police appealed for public help to find the alleged blackmailer, at a press conference in Wellington Tuesday. They revealed an investigation had been underway since November, when anonymous letters were sent to giant dairy cooperative Fonterra and a farmers' lobby group. The letters were accompanied by
summary: A man is threatening to contaminate infant formula with poison, specifically 1080, which is used to control introduced pest species like possums and rats. The threat is aimed at the government and involves sending anonymous letters to Fonterra and a farmers' lobby group. The letters claim the poison will be released unless the government stops using it for pest control by March. New Zealand's Ministry for Primary Industries and police are investigating the threat, and there is a low likelihood that it will be carried out. However, the government has assured consumers that the threat does not pose a real danger to the safety of their baby formula.

article: (CNN)Sigma Alpha Epsilon is under fire for a video showing party-bound fraternity members singing a racist chant. SAE's national chapter suspended the students, but University of Oklahoma President David Boren took it a step further, saying the university's affiliation with the fraternity is permanently done. The news is shocking, but it's not the first time SAE has faced controversy. SAE was founded March 9, 1856, at the University of Alabama, five years before the American Civil War, according
summary: Sigma Alpha Epsilon (SAE) is facing criticism for a video showing partying fraternity members singing a racist chant. The national chapter suspended the students, and University of Oklahoma President David Boren decided to permanently end the university's affiliation with the fraternity due to its history of controversy. Founded in 1856, SAE has been involved in numerous controversies, including hazing incidents and member deaths. The fraternity has faced suspension or disapproval from several universities, and its previous insurer has stopped insuring it.

article: (CNN)Comic books of the past few years have seen a lot of changes (a female Thor, anyone?) but not quite so many at one time. Three major characters -- Superman, Wonder Woman (both of DC Comics, a Time Warner company, like CNN) and Archie Andrews -- came out with new looks (and costumes in two cases) Thursday. Superman and Wonder Woman are no stranger to change over time, but these are pretty different from what we're used to. Wonder Woman is back to wearing pants (similar to her style circa 201
summary: Three major comic book characters, Superman, Wonder Woman, and Archie Andrews, have undergone significant changes in their appearance and costume design in recent years. Wonder Woman has returned to wearing pants and a turtleneck, while Superman now looks more casual, sporting a shorter haircut. Meanwhile, Archie Andrews has adopted a modern look suitable for a television show, making it easier to understand why he has been romantically pursued by Betty and Veronica for years.

article: Jerusalem (CNN)Either Benjamin Netanyahu just staged the most dramatic political comeback in Israeli history and beyond, or something was very wrong with the polls before and during the election. Polls predicted a tight race coming down to the wire, with Netanyahu in a virtual tie with his main challenger, Isaac Herzog of the Zionist Union party. Only four days before the election, polls showed Herzog taking a four-seat lead into the final weekend before the election. Exit polls on the night of

(CNN)More than 20 years after his death from suicide, Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain continues to fascinate. On Wednesday, the trailer was released for an eagerly anticipated HBO documentary on the singer's life. "Montage of Heck" is directed by Brett Morgen and offers an intimate portrayal of one of the architects of grunge music. The trailer features bits of interviews with those closest to the performer, including family members; his wife, musician Courtney Love; and Nirvana bassist Krist Novos
summary: Kurt Cobain, the late frontman of the band Nirvana, has been featured in a new HBO documentary titled "Montage of Heck." The film aims to provide an intimate portrayal of Cobain's life, featuring interviews with close associates like his wife Courtney Love and bassist Krist Novoselic. The documentary's soundtrack includes a previously unreleased 12-minute acoustic track from Cobain.

article: (CNN)U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said Saturday that "we need to close ... gaps" with Iran in talks about its nuclear program, adding that those negotiating with Iranian officials "are deeply committed to ensuring that Iran does not obtain a nuclear weapon." Iran faces a March 24 deadline to reach a deal about its nuclear program. Several interim agreements have been made in recent months, though a long-term pact so far has been elusive. Speaking in Paris alongside French Foreign Minister
summary: Secretary of State John Kerry stated that the U.S. needs to address gaps in negotiations with Iran regarding its nuclear program. He emphasized that the parties involved are committed to preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Kerry mentioned that while progress has been made, there still exist differences between the parties. The secretary acknowledged that the deadline for a deal is approaching, but he stressed that there is no urgency to reach an agreement. All members of the P5+1 group agreed that Iran should not pursue nuclear weapons and should focus on developing a peaceful nuclear program. Iranian Minister, however, has publicly stated their intention to pursue nuclear energy for civilian purposes.

article: (CNN)They were known for their quiet professionalism and dedication. One recently received a high military honor for rendering aid to a wounded comrade in Afghanistan while under enemy fire. One had served a tour in Kosovo. The 11 service members who died in an Army Black Hawk helicopter crash Tuesday off the Florida Panhandle weren't only a loss to their country. They leave behind wives, fiancees, parents, children and friends. They will be missed. And remembered. Seven of those on the helicopt

Washington (CNN)If it looks like a treaty, walks like a treaty and talks like a treaty, is it a treaty? According to the White House, only if the President of the United States says it is. That's infuriating Republicans and even some Democrats, who are demanding that the Obama administration submit any final nuclear deal with Iran to Congress for approval. "This is clearly a treaty," Arizona Sen. John McCain told reporters Tuesday. "They can call it a banana, but it's a treaty." Kerry denounces

London (CNN)Top Gear presenter Jeremy Clarkson was suspended for allegedly hitting a producer, the BBC reported on Wednesday. The BBC said Clarkson, one of the corporation's highest earners, had "a fracas with a BBC producer" in a statement released yesterday. "Jeremy Clarkson has been suspended pending an investigation," they said. "No one else has been suspended. Top Gear will not be broadcast this Sunday." The BBC reported that the next two episodes, and possibly the third and final show of t
summary: Top Gear presenter Jeremy Clarkson was suspended by the BBC for allegedly hitting a producer, leading to the cancellation of the next three episodes of the show. Clarkson has been the BBC's highest earner and the show's co-host, James May, has also taken to social media to express support for Clarkson. The BBC statement mentioned that no one else has been suspended.

article: (CNN)Dolce & Gabbana went familial for fall at its fashion show in Milan on Sunday, dedicating its collection to "mamma" with nary a pair of "mom jeans" in sight. Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana, who are behind the Italian brand, sent models down the runway in decidedly feminine dresses and skirts adorned with roses, lace and even embroidered doodles by the designers' own nieces and nephews. Many of the looks featured saccharine needlework phrases like "I love you, mamma" and "Per la mamma pi
summary: The Dolce & Gabbana fashion show in Milan on Sunday was dedicated to the family, featuring mostly feminine dresses and skirts adorned with rose, lace, and embroidered doodles. The designers also sent models down the runway wearing saccharine needlework phrases such as "I love you, mamma" and "Per la mamma più bella del mondo." The front row, which is usually stoic, couldn't help but applaud and smile as a few models carried their own high-fashion progeny down the runway.

article: (CNN)An Israeli Arab man who is shown being shot by a child in a recent ISIS video has no connections to Israeli intelligence, the country's defense minister said Wednesday. In the video released Tuesday, ISIS claims the man, 19-year-old Mohamed Said Ismail Musallam, is an Israeli spy. But Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Ya'alon denied the allegation on Israeli radio. The ISIS video shows Musallam's Israeli passport and claims he's an agent sent to infiltrate the group. Musallam's family on Tuesd
summary: An Israeli Arab man named Mohamed Said Ismail Musallam, who is shown in a recent ISIS video, is not connected to Israeli intelligence. ISIS claims he is an Israeli spy, but Israel's defense minister, Moshe Ya'alon, denies this claim. Musallam's family claims he had no ties with Israel's spy agency, the Mossad, and was actually recruited by ISIS. He is an Israeli citizen of Palestinian descent and his family believes he was coerced into lying about his ties to Israeli intelligence. This is not the first time ISIS has used children to promote their message, and they have also featured children as fighters

article: (CNN)Ferguson is crumbling. The cowardly and reprehensible shooting Wednesday night of two police officers came in a tumultuous seven days for the Missouri town, which had already seen Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson announce his resignation after a damning Justice Department report on its police department. The report, which was ordered in the wake of the killing of Michael Brown last year, highlighted a predatory policing problem and a department that was biased, prejudiced and that has r
summary: Ferguson has been hit hard by recent events, including the controversial shooting of two police officers. The community is demanding justice, but the problems with Ferguson's police department extend beyond one incident. The city has a disproportionate number of white officers compared to the local population, and many residents are frustrated by the use of military-grade weapons by police departments. The author argues that police departments must become more representative of their communities, adopt community policing models, and reduce the use of military-grade weapons. The author also calls for Congress to pass legislation to stop the flow of military equipment to police departments.

article: (CNN)Two Chinese men have been jailed for selling military intelligence, including hundreds of photos of China's first aircraft carrier, to foreign spies, state media reported. According to the Dalian Daily, the two men, surnamed Han and Zhang, were sentenced to eight and six years in prison respectively earlier this year. The report said that Han, 30, was approached by a person claiming to be a journalist via the instant messaging app WeChat. The "reporter" assigned Han to work in a military ba
summary: Two Chinese men, Han and Zhang, were sentenced to eight and six years in prison respectively for selling military intelligence, including photos of China's first aircraft carrier, to foreign spies. They were approached by a person claiming to be a journalist via WeChat and assigned to take photos of sensitive areas of a major military project. They were then detained and sentenced after passing recordings and photos to their employer. The two men are reportedly also accused of sending over 500 photos of the Liaoning aircraft carrier to a foreign magazine. Some questioned if it was really espionage to take photos of the carrier.

article: (The Hollywood Reporter)Melissa Benoist is suited up and ready to fly in CBS' "Supergirl." Producer Warner Bros. Television has released the first-look photos of the "Glee" and "Whiplash" breakout in the official costume as DC Comics character Supergirl. See more: The Faces of Pilot Season 2015 . The costume was designed by three-time Oscar-winner Colleen Atwood, who also served in the same capacity for WBTV/The CW's DC takes 'Arrow" and "The Flash." "In designing Supergirl, I wanted to embrace
summary: Melissa Benoist, a breakout star from shows like Glee and Whiplash, is now part of the cast of CBS' Supergirl. She wears an official costume inspired by DC Comics character Supergirl and designed by Oscar-winning Colleen Atwood. The production started filming this week in Los Angeles. The drama follows Kara Zor-El, who escaped from Krypton years ago, and her journey on Earth with her cousin, Superman.

article: (CNN)For those who hoped that the coming presidential election would usher in the dawn of a new, more inspiring politics, this past week has been deeply discouraging. In two key moments, leaders from both sides of the aisle have acted like the Bourbons of France, who famously remembered nothing and forgot nothing from battles of their past. The first and substantively more important moment was the sending of that letter by Republican senators to the Iranian regime. The second, and perhaps more i

(CNN)By the time Cynthia Falardeau read about Alex Pring, a little boy who got a battery-powered robotic arm last summer, she had made peace with her son Wyatt's limb difference. Her premature baby had been born with his right arm tangled in amniotic bands. At a week old, doctors amputated his dead forearm and hand. They were afraid his body would be become infected and he would die. Falardeau mourned her boy's missing arm for years but, in time, embraced her son as he was. Wyatt also learned to

(CNN)I grew up watching "Leave It to Beaver." Most episodes, Ward Cleaver would come home from work in his suit and tie and there would be his wife June, always in the kitchen, her apron as white as the picket fence outside.  June made dinner, of course, and Ward and Wally and the Beav sat at the table and ate.  As I recall, June usually cleaned up.  Maybe once or twice the boys helped with dishes.  Maybe. I would watch the black and white show during dinner, sitting on the couch with a plate of

(CNN)This weekend marked the official opening of "Fish in the Dark,"  the Broadway debut of Larry David of "Seinfeld" and "Curb Your Enthusiasm" fame. Of course, the odd conventions of live theater mean that "Fish" wasn't quite fresh-to-table at its premiere: It's been playing for several weeks now to sold-out preview crowds, to build buzz and iron out production kinks. And sold out really means sold out: The show has destroyed box office records for the vintage Cort Theatre and might yet set ne

(CNN)Everyone's favorite male models made a surprise appearance at Tuesday's Valentino show at Paris Fashion Week. And, no surprise, they were really, really ridiculously good-looking. Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson reprised their roles as the vacuous models from the popular 2001 film "Zoolander" at Tuesday's women's couture show. There was no mistaking Stiller for anyone other than the fierce Zoolander as he sashayed down the runway in a Valentino trench, casting Blue Steel in every direction. He
summary: Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson, known as the vacuous models from the movie "Zoolander," made a surprise appearance at the Valentino show at Paris Fashion Week. They both wore gorgeous outfits, with Stiller in a Valentino trench and Wilson in pajamas. This was part of their upcoming movie "Zoolander 2," which is scheduled to be released in February 2016.

article: (CNN)As a controversy over a racist video continues, the University of Oklahoma is announcing a plan to hire a vice president who will oversee diversity programs. A video of a racist chant by the university's now-disbanded Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity made headlines nationwide this week. It shows students on a bus clapping, pumping their fists and laughing as they chant, "There will never be a ni**** SAE. You can hang him from a tree, but he can never sign with me. There will never be a ni****
summary: The University of Oklahoma is appointing a new vice president to oversee diversity initiatives. Following the release of a racist video by a now-defunct fraternity, the university plans to hire an African-American individual for this position.

article: (CNN)A well-heeled employer goes back to his hotel after a hard(ish) day's work and finds no hot dinner on the table. He snaps, lashing out (allegedly) at the nearest underling who could be held responsible. Within days, almost 1 million people sign a petition for him not to lose his job, while the suspension of the TV program he presents loses the BBC 4 million viewers. Why is this man so popular that he can be accused of abusing his staff (not to mention members of other ethnic groups and nati
summary: The article discusses the popularity of a well-known celebrity, Jeremy Clarkson, despite being accused of abusing his staff and members of different ethnic groups. Despite facing criticism and protests, Clarkson continues to gain support from his fans, who believe that he deserves a chance to redeem himself. The author suggests that Clarkson is skilled in rebranding himself as the victim and using controversies to increase his popularity. The article also mentions that Clarkson's behavior has become a source of inspiration for others, such as former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho.

article: (CNN)A video appears online. In it, fraternity members from your university are chanting a hateful, racist song about lynching African-Americans. The video goes viral. You're president of the university. Imagine being in that situation. What would you do? There are two ways to answer the question. The first is in the moment of crisis. The second is about the long term. As most everyone knows by now, David Boren,  president of the University of Oklahoma, faced just this situation Monday. And I've
summary: David Boren, President of the University of Oklahoma, faced a crisis when fraternity members from his university chanted a hateful, racist song about lynching African-Americans. Boren responded quickly, expressing a decisive, judgmental view and following through with action. His swift response has resonated across the country, leading to a shift in social norms for all. Boren's actions have sparked debates over legal authority to expel students based on free speech, while others question his focus on the students' actions rather than the students themselves. However, the bigger picture highlights the need to challenge societal norms of racism and promote inclusivity. Leaders, including

article: (CNN)A  Palestinian man rammed into a cyclist and four Israeli border police while he was driving in Jerusalem on Friday, authorities and first responders said. Witnesses said the man drove off the side of the road to hit his victims. They were taken to the hospital with light to moderate injuries. Authorities are treating the incident as a terror attack, according to police spokesman Micky Rosenfeld. The suspect tried to escape, but was shot by a security guard and severely wounded before being
summary: A Palestinian man rammed into a cyclist and four Israeli border police in Jerusalem on Friday, resulting in minor injuries. The suspect fled after hitting his victims and was later shot by a security guard and captured. Authorities have classified the incident as a terror attack, and Hamas has praised the attacker for his heroic act. The incident is seen as a response to Israeli occupation-related crimes.

article: (CNN)Want to take a self-portrait using your snazzy new selfie stick in front of London's National Gallery? That's fine. But don't try to use it inside the museum. The National Gallery has become the latest museum to ban the handy (or irritating, depending on your point of view) device. Selfies turn museums into playgrounds for a day . The British museum joins the Smithsonian, New York's Museum of Modern Art and a host of institutions around the world banning what the New York museum calls "came
summary: The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, citing concerns about invading personal space and damaging artwork. Other museums like the British Museum and the Smithsonian have also imposed similar restrictions. Despite Mar Dixon's support for photos in museums, she believes selfie sticks are more problematic than tripods or umbrellas.

article: (CNN)Last November, the American people placed a great amount of trust in Republicans when they gave them complete control of Congress. Voters bought the illusion that a Republican Congress would govern effectively, help the middle class and focus on important issues like jobs and the economy. Now, after two months, that illusion has been shattered. Over the last two weeks, we have seen the Republican Congress manufacture, then escalate, a political crisis by threatening to shut down the Departm
summary: The American people trusted Republicans with complete control over Congress in November, hoping they would govern effectively, help the middle class, and focus on important issues like jobs and the economy. However, over the past two months, they have been let down by the Republican Congress, which has manufactured a political crisis by threatening to shut down the Department of Homeland Security and hold it hostage with demands that the legislation roll back the President's immigration actions. This has left the livelihoods of more than 240,000 men and women who serve as employees of the Border Patrol, Transportation Security Administration and other DHS agencies at risk. The Republican Congress

article: (CNN)Cody Simpson just wants to make the world happy. That's why the Australian-born pop star is in Austin, Texas, this week, where he will be performing at a United Nations/MixRadio brunch at the SXSW festival. Simpson, 18, is the spokesman for the #HappySoundsLike playlist, promoting the U.N.'s International Day of Happiness on Friday, March 20. The singer and other celebs selected tracks for the playlist. "There is honestly nothing I can think of that I like to do more than make other people
summary: Australian singer Cody Simpson, aged 18, will be performing at a United Nations/MixRadio brunch at the SXSW festival in Austin, Texas. Simpson is the spokesman for the #HappySoundsLike playlist, which features tracks selected by celebrities to promote the U.N.'s International Day of Happiness on March 20. The singer and other artists will perform at the event, and Simpson will showcase his own cover of Bob Marley's "No Woman No Cry."

article: (CNN)President Barack Obama shared jokes about pot and Hillary Clinton's email controversy at the annual Gridiron Club dinner in Washington on Saturday. The club's dinner brings together Washington's media elite, with noteworthy politicians typically attending, as well. Despite being held by a media organization that raises scholarship funds for journalism students, the dinners are generally closed to cameras. Organizers only allowed a select few pool reporters to enter while the President spoke
summary: President Barack Obama shared jokes about pot and Hillary Clinton's email controversy at the annual Gridiron Club dinner in Washington on Saturday. Despite being held by a media organization that raises scholarship funds for journalism students, the dinners are generally closed to cameras. Obama also touched on the controversy over the archiving of Clinton's emails while she was secretary of state.

article: (CNN)Chinese relic experts claim that a 1,000-year-old mummified monk encased in a Buddha statue was stolen from a village temple in Eastern China in 1995, state media reported. The mummy made international headlines last year when it first showcased at Drents Museum in the Netherlands. The Cultural Relic Bureau in Fujian province launched an investigation and found photos and historical records suggesting the statue belonged to a village temple where it was worshiped as an ancestor. The bureau
summary: A 1,000-year-old mummified monk in a Buddha statue was stolen from a village temple in Eastern China in 1995, and is now in possession of a Dutch private collector. The Cultural Relic Bureau in Fujian province is investigating the theft and plans to seek repatriation in compliance with normal procedures. The statue, which was being housed at the Hungarian Natural History Museum, was purchased illegally in 1996.

article: (CNN)A Pennsylvania State University fraternity has been suspended after allegedly posting on a private Facebook page compromising photos of women, including some who appeared to be asleep or passed out. The suspension of Kappa Delta Rho (KDR) fraternity comes as State College Police as well as university officials investigate the fraternity's alleged use of the online page with up to 144 active members, including current and former students. "No arrests are being made at this time," State Colle
summary: A Pennsylvania State University fraternity, Kappa Delta Rho, has been suspended due to the posting of compromising photos of women on a private Facebook page, including those who appeared to be asleep or passed out. The fraternity used the page to post "highly inappropriate photographs" of activities and events in violation of the standards and values of a recognized student organization. The university's investigation is ongoing, but it has suspended the fraternity for one year and is considering the possibility of reinstating it. The incident highlights concerns over the fraternity system and its impact on men's behavior.

article: March 25, 2015 . Featured this Wednesday: The U.S. announces it will maintain its troop levels in Afghanistan through the rest of the year, Israel denies accusations that it spied on U.S.-led negotiations with Iran, a passenger plane crashes in the French Alps, and we feature a Character study involving a CNN Hero who's helping young people keep their eyes and ears healthy. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Student News Roll Call.
summary: The U.S. plans to keep troops in Afghanistan until the end of the year, while Israel says it didn't spy on talks with Iran. A plane crashed in the French Alps, and we featured a character study about a CNN Hero helping young people keep their eyes and ears healthy. This week's show included transcripts, a request form for students, and a place for teachers to suggest mentions on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

article: (CNN)In fairy tales, it's usually the princess that needs protecting. At Google's headquarters in Silicon Valley, the princess is the one defending the castle. Meet Parisa Tabriz, the 31-year-old with perhaps the most enchanted job title in engineering -- "Google Security Princess." Her job is to hack into the most popular web browser on the planet, trying to find flaws in the system before the "black hats" do. Indeed, much like the good and bad witches of the Wizard of Oz, hackers are described
summary: Parisa Tabriz, a 31-year-old Google engineer, is known as the "Security Princess" because she defends the company's website against cyberattacks. She thinks like hackers to find vulnerabilities in the system before they're exploited. She helps keep a billion Chrome users' data safe and protects them from government surveillance over emails. Google pays rewards for finding these glitches, and the company has set up a program to encourage more women to work in cybersecurity.

article: (CNN)A previously unknown group calling itself the Islamic State Hacking Division posted the names, photos and addresses of about 100 U.S. troops online, calling for attacks against them. Whoever created the file, posted online Saturday before being removed, claimed to have hacked military databases and said it was leaking 100 names "so that our brothers residing in America can deal with you." The possibility of lone-wolf attacks in the United States, the type that this message calls for, is a t
summary:
A group claiming to be the Islamic State Hacking Division posted the names, photos, and addresses of around 100 U.S. troops on the internet, threatening attacks against them. This group, however, has not been confirmed by the Defense Department or the FBI. The possibility of lone-wolf attacks in the United States, which pose a significant threat to national security, is something that the attorney general, Eric Holder, takes very seriously. While the group's claims remain unverified, the Navy and the Army have advised their members to limit the amount of personal information they share online. The FBI is also investigating the matter.

article: (CNN)Serena Williams has won 19 grand slam singles tennis titles, including six U.S. Opens and five Wimbledons. She has four Olympic gold medals. For years, she's had a reputation as one of her sport's top players. Yet for all her myriad accomplishments, Williams says one of her "biggest ... and proudest moments" came Friday night -- in the second round of a tournament in Indian Wells, California. It's not who she was playing, but where. The Indian Wells Tennis Garden is where Williams was booed
summary: Serena Williams, one of the most successful tennis players, returned to the Indian Wells Tennis Garden in 2001 after receiving negative treatment from fans. Despite her initial hesitation, she decided to attend the tournament and received a warm welcome from the audience, which made her feel proud and emotional. Williams has won 19 Grand Slam singles titles, including six US Opens and five Wimbledon championships, and has four Olympic gold medals. Despite the negative experiences she faced in 2001, Williams has continued to be a prominent figure in the sport and has not let her past issues affect her performance.

article: (CNN)There was a street named after Chuck Norris, but they had to change the name because nobody crosses Chuck Norris and lives. Chuck Norris counted to infinity. Twice. Death once had a near-Chuck Norris experience. Chuck Norris is celebrating his 75th birthday -- but the calendar is only allowed to turn 39. That last one is true (well, the first part, anyway). The actor, martial-arts star and world's favorite tough-guy joke subject was born March 10, 1940, which makes him 75 today. Or perhaps
summary: Chuck Norris celebrates his 75th birthday, but the calendar only turns 39 due to his legendary abilities.

article: (CNN)Serena Williams had a big decision to make earlier this year, and she wanted to run it by her parents. She was nervous. She wanted to see whether they would support her going back to Indian Wells, California, to play in a tournament she had skipped 13 times since winning in 2001. The last time she was there, she had been booed loudly and lustfully. The fans were upset and sensed some sort of conspiracy that she didn't have to face her talented older sister in the semifinals. Venus Williams
summary: Serena Williams decided to go back to Indian Wells, California, after years of boycotting the tournament due to the way she was treated. Her parents supported her decision, despite being criticized by some fans who felt she should stay away from the event. Serena won the tournament in 2001 and has not returned since, but she is now set to compete again in the BNP Paribas Open.

article: (CNN)Pi Day is going to be extra special this year, as 2015 stretches the symbolic March 14 celebration out a little longer to 3.1415. And if you mark pi at 9:26.53 in the morning or night, you're just a little more in line with the celebrated irrational number that never ends. To 31 decimal places, pi is 3.1415926535897932384626433832795. A few more tidbits about pi and Pi Day: . About pi . Pi is the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter. It's not equal to the ratio of any two
summary: Pi Day is coming up on March 14, 2015, which is an extra-special day because it shows the number pi (3.1415...) in its full, never-ending form. If you remember the time when pi is exactly 9:26.53 in the morning or evening, you'll be even closer to the real pi! Pi is a special number that helps us understand circles and is used by people who work with buildings and houses. People have known about pi for thousands of years, but it wasn't called pi until the 1700s. On March

article: London (CNN)The discovery of the remains of Richard III beneath a car parking lot in the English city of Leicester in 2012 sparked excitement around the world. Now those bones are to be reburied following a series of commemorations full of the pomp and circumstance befitting of a royal farewell. In the years since it was exhumed, the King's skeleton has given up plenty of secrets -- and research continues to find out more. Say the name Richard III to most people, and the image that will spring t

(CNN)We had no idea how much we would really, really, really, really like Tom Hanks lip-syncing to a Carly Rae Jepsen song, but we really do. Hanks shows up in the new video for "I Really Like You," "singing" Jepsen's part throughout. The Oscar-winning actor is apparently playing himself, signing autographs for fans, and generally being a very cheery movie star, before he and Jepsen take part in a flash mob. So what exactly is Tom Hanks doing in this video in the first place? Turns out he is goo
summary: Tom Hanks lip-syncs to Carly Rae Jepsen's song "I Really Like You" in a new video, as he plays himself and sings along to the tune during an appearance at a flash mob event. The video showcases Hanks' love for music and his close friendship with Jepsen, as well as his past experience with performing at Jepsen's wedding.

article: (CNN)A federal judge has ordered the Defense Department to release photos that allegedly show detainees being abused in detention centers in Iraq and Afghanistan during the Bush administration. The photos won't be made public right away. In an order issued Friday, U.S. District Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District of New York granted the government 60 days to appeal. The ACLU sued the Defense Department in 2003 to have the photos made public. It's not clear how many photos are inv
summary: A federal judge ruled that the Defense Department should release photos showing alleged abuse of detainees in Iraq and Afghanistan during the Bush administration. However, the photos will not be released immediately and the government has 60 days to appeal. The ACLU initially sued to make the photos public but the judge blocked release due to ongoing military operations in Iraq. The judge argued that the government failed to prove that releasing the photos would endanger American soldiers or civilians. The ACLU argued that the photos provide evidence of the Bush administration's detention practices and could help the public understand the implications of those policies.

article: (CNN)Singer-songwriter David Crosby hit a jogger with his car Sunday evening, a spokesman said. The accident happened in Santa Ynez, California, near where Crosby lives. Crosby was driving at approximately 50 mph when he struck the jogger, according to California Highway Patrol Spokesman Don Clotworthy. The posted speed limit was 55. The jogger suffered multiple fractures, and was airlifted to a hospital in Santa Barbara, Clotworthy said. His injuries are not believed to be life threatening. "Mr
summary: Singer-songwriter David Crosby accidentally hit a jogger with his car in Santa Ynez, California, causing multiple fractures but no life-threatening injuries. The accident occurred on the same side of the road as the jogger and Crosby was driving at 50 mph when he struck him.

article: (CNN)Airstrikes started Wednesday in Tikrit, where Iraqi and coalition forces are battling to wrest control from ISIS. "These strikes are intended to destroy ISIL strongholds with precision, thereby saving innocent Iraqi lives while minimizing collateral damage to infrastructure," said Lt. Gen. James L. Terry, commanding general of the international coalition, led by the United States. "This will further enable Iraqi forces under Iraqi command to maneuver and defeat ISIL in the vicinity of Tikri
summary: Airstrikes were launched in Tikrit, Iraq, by the international coalition led by the United States, targeting ISIS strongholds with precision to save Iraqi lives while minimizing damage to infrastructure. These strikes are part of the effort to retake control of Tikrit and surrounding areas from ISIS, which has captured significant territories in Iraq and Syria. The airstrikes are being carried out by the coalition in cooperation with Iraqi Security Forces under the command of Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi. This operation aims to facilitate the Iraqi forces' ability to regain control of the city and potentially lead to the eventual capture of Mosul.

article: (CNN)Denise Huskins, who was reported kidnapped two days ago in Vallejo, California, has been found safe more than 400 miles away, authorities and her father said Wednesday. Huskins' boyfriend Monday afternoon called police and said she had been abducted that morning from his home in the Bay Area. About 48 hours later, she was located an hour south of Los Angeles. Officers from the Huntington Beach Police Department found Huskins at her father's apartment complex, department spokeswoman Jennifer
summary: A woman named Denise Huskins was kidnapped two days ago in Vallejo, California, but she was found safe over 400 miles away. She was picked up by her father at his apartment complex. Police are still trying to figure out what happened, but they hope to get more information later tonight.

article: (CNN)Retired NFL star Darren Sharper changed course and pleaded guilty Monday to one count of sexual assault and one count of attempted sexual assault. Sharper has been in jail in Los Angeles since last year, but this case was in Arizona. Sharper and his attorney had a telephone meeting with Judge Warren Granville, where the former player and television analyst changed his plea. The judge sentenced Sharper to nine years in prison with no eligibility for early release, Maricopa County Attorney's
summary: Retired NFL star Darren Sharper, who was arrested in California on charges of drugging and raping two women in that state, pleaded guilty to one count of sexual assault and one count of attempted sexual assault in Arizona. He has been in jail in Los Angeles since last year, and the judge sentenced him to nine years in prison with no eligibility for early release, along with lifetime probation. Sharper is currently serving time in California for the original charges and will get about 300 days credit for time already served. He played for the Green Bay Packers, Minnesota Vikings, and New Orleans Saints from 1997 through the

article: (CNN)A quick descent. No distress call. The pilot's actions. It will be months, or longer, before the causes behind Tuesday's crash of Germanwings Flight 4U 9525 are known, but there are initial clues that aviation experts say will be the most important to investigators. Speculation comes in the wake of any tragedy such as this, but experts say certain facts can be significant for those who want to know what happened. The most useful clues so far: . One of the plane's "black boxes" has been reco

(CNN)The National Institutes of Health said Thursday that it plans to admit to its Maryland hospital an American health care worker with Ebola. The person was volunteering at an Ebola treatment center in Sierra Leone, and will be flown back to the United States on a chartered aircraft and admitted Friday, the NIH said. No other details were immediately available. The patient will be the second with Ebola admitted to the NIH hospital. Nina Pham, a nurse at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dalla
summary: The NIH hospital in Maryland will admit an American health care worker with Ebola, who volunteered at an Ebola treatment center in Sierra Leone. The patient will be flown back to the United States on a chartered aircraft and admitted on Friday. This is the second person with Ebola to be admitted to the NIH hospital. The patient will be the second with Ebola admitted to the NIH hospital. The first patient, Nina Pham, a nurse at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas, recovered and was released free of disease. She was also the first person to contract Ebola while treating Liberian national Thomas Eric Duncan, who later died.

article: (CNN)Last summer, amid startling news reports of manipulation, mismanagement and possibly death caused by failures at the Department of Veterans Affairs, Congress came together and passed legislation to overhaul veterans' access to health care. I was proud to sponsor the Veterans Access, Choice and Accountability Act of 2014 (the Choice Act), and deliver good news to veterans: They would have a choice when it comes to accessing health care they deserve, and many would have the option of seeing t
summary: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is attempting to take away the choice of veterans regarding health care they deserve due to its flawed implementation of the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 (Choice Act). The VA is denying access to local physicians and local hospitals for veterans who cannot receive the care they need from VA facilities within 40 miles of their homes or wait more than 30 days for an appointment. Veterans are frustrated and call for the VA to prioritize veterans' needs over its own interests. Senator Rob Portman (R-OH) has proposed legislation to ensure that veterans are not dismissed or

article: (CNN)Two years after she underwent a double mastectomy to cut her cancer risk, actress and U.N. envoy Angelina Jolie has had surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes for the same reason, she wrote in The New York Times on Tuesday. Jolie, 39, carries a mutation of the BRCA1 gene, which sharply increases her risk of developing breast cancer and ovarian cancer. Her mother was diagnosed with the latter at age 49 and died seven years later. In her New York Times op-ed Tuesday, Jolie said she
summary: Angelina Jolie, an actress and UN envoy, underwent surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes after being diagnosed with a genetic mutation that significantly increases her risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers. Jolie, who carried a BRCA1 gene mutation, shared her experience in an op-ed published in The New York Times. Her husband, Brad Pitt, was by her side during the surgery. The decision to undergo the surgery was made after doctors detected worrying markers, and Jolie's doctor recommended immediate consultation with a surgeon to check her ovaries. Jolie emphasizes that while not every woman with the same BRCA1 gene

article: (CNN)The BBC has suspended Jeremy Clarkson, the host of car show "Top Gear," following "a fracas with a BBC producer," the broadcaster said in a statement. "Jeremy Clarkson has been suspended pending an investigation," they said. "No one else has been suspended. Top Gear will not be broadcast this Sunday." Fans of the presenter expressed dismay at the decision. At the time of writing, more than 147,000 people had signed a petition seeking his reinstatement. Using the hashtag #BringBackClarkson,
summary: Jeremy Clarkson, the host of car show "Top Gear," has been suspended by the BBC after a fracas with a BBC producer. No one else has been suspended. The show will not be broadcast this Sunday. Clarkson apologized for using a racist term in May, but the BBC did not comment further.

article: (CNN)The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which is the largest sponsor of Boy Scout troops in the United States, says the church has strong measures in place to prevent the sexual abuse of scouts, as claims have been made it hasn't done enough. In the first interview about allegations of abuse in Mormon church-sponsored scouting troops, Church Elder L. Whitney Clayton told CNN that the church is at the forefront for prevention of child abuse. "We feel like there is really no other or
summary: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the largest sponsor of Boy Scout troops in the US, has strong measures in place to prevent child abuse. The church has a zero-tolerance policy and trains its leaders to prevent abuse. However, allegations of abuse have been made against the church and the Boy Scouts of America. The church has acknowledged that it did not do enough to prevent abuse, despite having a strong prevention program. A case involving

article: (CNN)Can't see Harry Potter's  Albus Dumbledore as gay? Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling has a terse message for you. Rowling revealed that the Hogwarts School headmaster was gay after "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows," the final book in the boy wizard series, was released in 2007. Fan Ana Kocovic started the exchange by asking the author, "I wonder why you said that Dumbledore is gay because I can't see him in that way." "Maybe because gay people just look like ... people?" Rowling wrote i
summary: J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, revealed in 2007 that the Hogwarts School Headmaster, Albus Dumbledore, was gay. A fan, Ana Kocovic, asked Rowling if she saw Dumbledore as gay and Rowling replied, "Maybe because gay people just look like ... people?" The response sparked a conversation on Twitter between fans and Rowling. Many praised Rowling's honesty and others were curious about her reasons for revealing Dumbledore's sexuality.

article: (CNN)The reported kidnapping of a Vallejo, California, woman for ransom this week was nothing but a hoax, police said. Vallejo police Lt. Kenny Park went as far as to call it a "wild goose chase" that wasted department resources. Denise Huskins and her boyfriend Aaron Quinn, who reported the kidnapping Monday, are no longer cooperating with police, Park said. Huskins was found safe on Wednesday, more than 400 miles away in Huntington Beach. Officers from the Huntington Beach Police Department ta
summary: A woman, Denise Huskins, who was kidnapped in Vallejo, California, for ransom, was actually just a hoax. She was found safe after missing her abduction. The police were frustrated because the woman wasn't cooperating and wasn't answering their calls. They were looking into whether anyone had done anything wrong.

article: (CNN)As a youngster, Rohana Rozhan had a nickname that summed her up perfectly: "Rohana the Piranha." Even as a little girl growing up in Malaysia, the future CEO of a $4.6 billion media company was small but deadly. "I was born independent, fiercely so," 51-year-old Rozhan told CNN's Kristie Lu-Stout. "I always had a chip on my shoulder that I had to prove to everyone that I'm independent." Today she's proved it -- and then some. Rozhan heads Astro Malaysia, one of the biggest media and enterta
summary: The article highlights the success story of Rohana Rozhan, the CEO of a $4.6 billion media company in Malaysia. As a young girl, she was known as "Rohana the Piranha" due to her independent spirit and fierce determination. Rozhan attributes her success to her upbringing as a Muslim, Malay girl who learned the importance of respect and hard work. Today, she heads Astro Malaysia, which produces over 9,000 hours of original content annually, with a focus on promoting gender equality among its employees.

article: (CNN)Actor Jon Hamm, who plays hard-drinking Don Draper on the hit AMC show "Mad Men," has recently completed a 30-day stint in rehab for alcohol abuse, TMZ reports. The celebrity-news site says Hamm checked himself into the high-end Silver Hill Hospital in New Canaan, Connecticut, at the end of February. "With the support of his longtime partner Jennifer Westfeldt, Jon Hamm recently completed treatment for his struggle with alcohol addiction," said representatives for Hamm in a statement to TMZ
summary: Actor Jon Hamm, known for his role as Don Draper on the popular AMC show "Mad Men," recently completed a 30-day stint in rehab for his battle with alcohol addiction. Hamm checked himself into Silver Hill Hospital in New Canaan, Connecticut, at the end of February. His long-time partner, Jennifer Westfeldt, supported him during his recovery. This news comes just two weeks before "Mad Men" finishes its final eight-episode run on April 5, with filming completed months ago.

article: (CNN)Creflo Dollar is hoping a few folks will see fit to bless him. The minister, known for being a prosperity preacher at his Atlanta-area World Changers Church International, is seeking "200,000 people committed to sow $300 or more (to) help achieve our goal to purchase the G650 airplane." The figures were presented Friday in a nearly six-minute video on the Creflo Dollar Ministries website and total more than $60 million needed to buy the Gulfstream G650, which goes for a reported $65 million
summary: Creflo Dollar, a wealthy preacher known for his prosperity gospel, is seeking $60 million to purchase a $65 million Gulfstream G650 jet. The jet will be used to transport himself and his wife Taffi to various parts of the world to spread the gospel.

article: (CNN)The next time someone accuses you of acting like a Neanderthal, don't be offended.  Just say "thank you." A new study published this month suggests Neanderthals were more "cognitively advanced than we give them credit," Kansas University's David Frayer said in a release. Frayer, a professor emeritus of anthropology, was a part of the study published in the journal PLOS ONE that looks at eagle talons found in present-day Croatia. The talons are among the thousands of human remains, animal bo
summary: A new study has revealed that Neanderthals were more advanced than previously believed, suggesting they were capable of creating jewelry from eagle talons. This discovery challenges the traditional image of Neanderthals as simple-minded creatures, and opens up new avenues for understanding their cognitive abilities and social behavior.

article: (CNN)One is a former high school cornerback who also loves baseball. The other is a football  fan who also played competitive golf. The two University of Oklahoma students at the center of a racist fraternity video have more than sports in common. They're both under fire since the nine-second clip showed them making racial slurs against blacks. In it, students at the now-disbanded Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity clap, pump their fists and laugh as they hurl racial slurs and make a reference to ly
summary: University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, have faced backlash over a nine-second video that showed them making racial slurs against blacks during a football game. Both students were expelled due to their alleged leadership role in the racist chant. Rice, originally from Dallas, played cornerback on the football team and baseball in high school. He apologized for the incident, describing himself as a charismatic and good person with a good soul and spirit despite his actions. The expulsion of both students highlights the need to address racism and promote diversity and inclusion within collegiate communities.

article: London (CNN)A British mother is standing by her decision to let her son, 11, wear a "Fifty Shades of Grey" costume to his school's World Book Day celebration. "Fifty Shades of Grey" tells the tale of a naive college graduate's energetic trysts with a billionaire -- Christian Grey -- who has a penchant for bondage. The Manchester Evening News reported that Liam Scholes arrived at Sale High School in northwest England dressed as Grey, complete with cable ties and an eyemask on Thursday. The school
summary: A British mother is defending her decision to allow her 11-year-old son to wear a "Fifty Shades of Grey" costume to their school's World Book Day celebration. The costume was criticized as inappropriate, but the mother argues that it was meant to be tongue-in-cheek and harmless, and that it was only a small issue compared to the school's high standards in terms of student behavior and safety.

article: (CNN)Call it "The Most Interesting Traffic Ticket in the World." A Washington state trooper caught a driver using a cardboard cutout of Jonathan Goldsmith, the Dos Equis beer pitchman known as "The Most Interesting Man in the World." The driver, who was by himself, was attempting to use the HOV lane. "The trooper immediately recognized it was a prop and not a passenger," Trooper Guy Gill told the New York Daily News. "As the trooper approached, the driver was actually laughing." Gill sent out a
summary: A Washington State trooper caught a driver using a cardboard cutout of Jonathan Goldsmith, the famous "Most Interesting Man in the World" beer pitchman, while driving in the HOV lane. The driver, alone and attempting to use the lane, was identified as being part of a prop rather than a passenger. The trooper issued a $124 ticket to the driver, who had been previously caught violating the HOV lane law but expressed creativity in choosing a less recognizable face for the prop. The incident took place near Fife, Washington, on Interstate 5.

article: (CNN)Cleanup crews on Thursday started assessing the damage caused by storms that slashed across Oklahoma on Wednesday, killing one person and injuring about two dozen others across the state. A reported tornado ravaged a mobile home park, destroying dozens of trailers just west of Tulsa in the suburb of Sand Springs. summary: Cleanup crews are assessing damage caused by storms that hit Oklahoma on Wednesday, resulting in one death and injuries to about 20 people. A tornado destroyed a mobile home park near Tulsa, and a gymnasium in Sand Springs collapsed. The storm also caused damage in the Tulsa metro area and Moore, with a massive tornado hitting Moore two years ago. Governor Mary Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties and requested assistance from federal agencies.

Our highest priority during the ongoing budget debate should be undoing the damage caused by defense sequestration and the hundreds of billions of dollars of defense cuts made by the Obama administration. For its sheer size, this one is a monster, stretching from New Mexico to southern New England. If you're keeping track on your maps at home, that's 2,000 miles of snowy misery and 94 million people under some sort of winter weather warning, watch or advisory. It has resulted in cancellations and delays at airports, such as Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, where 640 and 540 flights were cancelled on Wednesday and Thursday respectively. The storm has also affected highways, with areas like Oklahoma City reporting up to 6 to 10 inches of snowfall. In addition, the storm has caused flooding issues in certain regions. Despite

article: (CNN)Police in Detroit made a gruesome discovery Tuesday. A bailiff performing an eviction on a home on the east side of Detroit called 911 after discovering the body of a female child inside a freezer.  While investigating the body, authorities found a second body, a male, according to a release from the Detroit Police Department. Both bodies were inside a plastic bag, Detroit Police Chief James Craig said. There are tentative plans to begin the autopsy tomorrow said Ryan Bridges, spokesman for
summary: A 14-year-old girl and a 11-year-old boy were found dead in a freezer in Detroit, Michigan, along with their mother. Police arrested the mother for child abuse and are now conducting an autopsy to determine the cause of death. The children were living in a home with other family members who have been placed in protective custody. Authorities are seeking public assistance to investigate the case.

article: Moscow (CNN)Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in public Monday for the first time in about 10 days as he met with Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev in the Russian city of St. Petersburg. Putin isn't generally one to shy away from the limelight -- posing with a (tranquilized) tiger, riding a horse while shirtless, earning a karate black belt. So his unexplained absence fueled speculation about his health, grip on power and even his love life. Although the Kremlin and the Russian state m
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin was seen in public for the first time in about 10 days during his meeting with Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev in St. Petersburg on Monday. Putin's absence from public view fueled speculation about his health, grip on power, and love life. However, his appearance before the press reassured the public that he is healthy and in charge of the country. Putin ordered the Northern Fleet to be placed on full combat alert for snap checks, and several other military units were also on alert.

article: (CNN)It turns out that Jupiter may be more than just an enormous ball of gas spinning a few hundred million miles farther out in the solar system. We earthlings might have the giant planet to thank for our very existence. Two scientists are suggesting that the inner solar system once played host to a bunch of "super-Earths" -- planets that were larger than our own but smaller than Neptune. Jupiter, however, put an end to those early occupiers of the inner orbits, bulldozing in and sweeping them
summary: Jupiter's violent journey through the solar system, starting from a distant position and then moving closer to the sun, has been responsible for shaping our solar system, particularly the formation of Earth and the other planets. Scientists believe that during Jupiter's inward migration, it captured a large amount of planetesimals and dragged them towards the sun, causing these smaller planets to fall into the sun at a faster rate. This process is believed to have created a gap between the inner and outer planets, which led to the formation of the mass-depleted terrestrial planets in our solar system. The Grand Tack scenario, proposed by Batygin and Laughlin

article: (CNN)An Army National Guard member and his cousin have been arrested in Illinois for allegedly conspiring to provide material support to the terrorist organization ISIS, federal prosecutors said Thursday. The alleged plot included a plan to attack a U.S. military installation in Illinois. In the past 18 months, the Justice Department's National Security Division has prosecuted or is prosecuting 32 cases of people attempting to travel abroad to join or providing support to terrorist groups. London (CNN)At the time it probably seemed like fun: Jeremy Clarkson and a crew from the top-rated BBC TV show Top Gear driving a Porsche in Argentina. The only problem was that the car's registration plate, H982 FLK, appeared to refer to the 1982 Falklands War between the UK and Argentina, fought over a remote British colony off the coast of Patagonia, which both countries claim. The conflict, which claimed the lives of 655 Argentinian servicemen and 255 Britons, ended with a British victory. C

(CNN)When Walter Isaacson's biography of Steve Jobs came out in October 2011 -- less than three weeks after Jobs' death -- it crystallized many popularly held perceptions of the Apple co-founder. Yes, Jobs was brilliant. And yes, Jobs also could be a bastard. Isaacson's book contained numerous examples of Jobs' cruel behavior, such as verbally abusing employees whose work didn't meet his exacting standards. Now a new book is presenting a kinder, gentler portrait of the mercurial tech exec. "Beco
summary: The book "Becoming Steve Jobs" presents a more balanced and humanized portrait of the late Steve Jobs, providing fresh insights into his personal life and career. The book, authored by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli, features interviews with those who knew Jobs during his later, successful years, when his behavior had softened. Apple CEO Tim Cook praised the book, stating that it presented a more accurate depiction of Jobs, unlike Isaacson's biography, which was seen as unfair and biased. However, early reviews of the book were mixed, with some critics suggesting that it does not adequately capture the full scope of Jobs' personality.

article: (CNN)Actress Taraji P. Henson is apologizing for claiming her son was racially profiled during a traffic stop in Southern California last year. The Glendale Police Department released dash cam video of the encounter Friday, which contradicted her son's claims. Police released the footage after Henson commented about the alleged profiling in  an Uptown Magazine interview published last month. In her interview, the star of the hit television show "Empire" said her son, Marcell Johnson, 20, was rac
summary: Actress Taraji P. Henson has apologized for her controversial claims about her son being racially profiled during a traffic stop in Southern California last year. The incident sparked controversy when she stated that her son, Marcell Johnson, had been stopped and searched by police for having his hands in his pockets at both a school and university. However, police later released dash cam video that contradicted her claims. Henson's comments led her to send her son to Howard University in Washington, D.C., instead of the University of Southern California. Following the incident, Henson retracted her accusations and publicly apologized to the Glendale Police Department,

article: (CNN)When we asked our viewers to tweet their questions about the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, we received hundreds of responses. We put them  to our experts and here are answers to six of the most interesting ones. 1. " Does the rate of descent tell you anything? If co-pilot was determined to crash, why would he set it so slow?" 2.  "New cars can stop themselves before a crash. Why isn't there tech to prevent a plane from landing anywhere but the runway?" 3. "Why don't we have live cameras
summary: Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed in the French Alps after a pilot apparently triggered the plane's emergency system by setting the rate of descent too low. Experts say the descent rate is not an indicator of how badly the plane was damaged. They also discuss the possibility of hacking, but believe the pilot was likely the one behind the crash. The plane was carrying a lot of fuel, and there were no signs of a fire on the wreckage. There is a chance that the pilot may have been under the influence of drugs or medications.

article: (CNN)Gareth Bale scored twice for Wales as they beat Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualification, taking them to the top of their group and on course for a first major finals since the 1958 World Cup. The Real Madrid striker dominated the game in the northern city of Haifa, setting up Arsenal's Aaron Ramsay for the first goal before scoring twice in the second half to help Wales easily beat an Israel team who had been early pacesetters in the group. Club v country . Much of the build up had focused on
summary: Wales' Gareth Bale scored twice to help his side beat Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualification, taking them to the top of their group and on course for a first major finals since the 1958 World Cup. Bale dominated the game and helped Wales easily beat an Israel team that had been early pacesetters in the group.

article: (CNN)African safaris conjure up images of four-wheel drive cars trundling through games parks carrying tourists with binoculars clamped to their eyes. But if you want to get a bit closer to some of nature's most beautiful beasts then heading out on four legs, not four wheels, might be your best bet. Venturing into the continent's game reserves on horseback may seem a little daunting but is one of the best ways to experience the environment, says Philip Kusseler, co-owner of Wait A Little horse s

The horses are trained and well-disciplined, making them suitable companions for travelers who wish to venture into the wilderness. The article concludes that horseback safaris offer a safer experience than driving in a four-wheel

"I feel like I've let the fans down, but I can't do this anymore," he told the UK's outlet The Sun. He said that he had been feeling uncomfortable in recent months and that his departure was best for everyone concern
summary: Former One Direction member Zayn Malik, who left the group, apologized for causing pain to fans. He stated that he feels uncomfortable in recent months and that his departure is necessary for everyone's happiness. Malik is currently working on a solo project and is getting along well with the other members of the band. The group will continue as a foursome after Malik's departure.

article: (CNN)James Bond's latest mission has been revealed in the first trailer for "SPECTRE" which was released Friday. Daniel Craig reprises his role of everyone's favorite spy in the 24th Bond film, scheduled for release November 6. Christoph Waltz, Léa Seydoux, Monica Bellucci, David Bautista and Andrew Scott also star in director Sam Mendes' second Bond film. The acronym stands for Special Executive for Counter-intelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion, a fictional global terrorist organizatio
summary: The first trailer for James Bond's latest film, "SPECTRE," reveals that the film will be directed by Sam Mendes and stars Daniel Craig as the iconic spy. The trailer includes a mysterious message from Bond's past, a cryptic acronym, and hints at a sinister organization called SPECTRE, which is attempting to infiltrate MI6. The film is set for release on November 6.
