article: Tunis, Tunisia (CNN)Thousands of demonstrators marched in Tunisia's capital Sunday, protesting against terrorism less than two weeks after gunmen attacked a museum and killed more than 20 people there. "We came to express our support and to fight this danger that's threatening our society and our stability," said Rafik Abdessalem, Tunisia's former foreign minister, who was among the crowd. "Fortunately, all Tunisians are united here today. We will be able to defeat terrorism, which is threatenin
summary: In Tunisia's capital city of Tunis, thousands of demonstrators gathered to protest against terrorism, less than two weeks after a series of attacks in the region. The protesters, led by former foreign minister Rafik Abdessalem, demanded to defeat terrorism and protect their society from its threats. President Beji Caid Essebsi accompanied the demonstrators as they marched to the Bardo Museum, where a deadly attack took place earlier this month. The event was marked by chants of "We are not afraid" and "Je suis Bardo," symbolizing unity and determination to fight terrorism.

Because this isn't any ordinary commission: the casket will be the final resting place of one of Ibsen's distant relatives, Richard III, who died more than 500 years ago. article: (CNN)Kentucky is so awesome right now you are probably watching the NCAA men's basketball tournament to see who is going to get second. The undefeated Wildcats were scary good Thursday night in crushing West Virginia. The score was so lopsided the game was over before the first television timeout. summary: The Kentucky Wildcats won their 37th straight game, beating West Virginia 78-39 in a blowout. summary: Lewis Hamilton started the Malaysian Grand Prix in pole position after dominating qualifying under torrential conditions, beating Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel into second place and taking a front-row spot away from countryman Nico Rosberg. Rosberg also expressed his disappointment with how he performed, while Verstappen's debut performance in his first race for Toro Rosso earned him a sixth-place starting position.

article: Sanaa, Yemen (CNN)In just a few weeks, good relations with neighbors have become a matter of survival for Yemen's President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi. On Saturday, he joined his allies in Egypt, while battles raged on in his country. After Houthi rebels occupied the capital Sanaa weeks ago, his government fled. summary: Yemen's President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi is seeking support from neighboring countries to fight off the Houthis who seized control of the capital Sanaa. Saudi-led airstrikes have been targeting military assets and weapons caches, but have also hit civilian areas. The international community is divided over whether to intervene militarily, with some members expressing concerns about civilian casualties and potential threats to neighboring countries. Despite Hadi's call for military intervention, there is still uncertainty about the outcome of the conflict.

The collision happened at about 10:45 a.m. near Exposition Boulevard and Watt Way when an eastbound Hyundai turned north onto the tracks as an eastbound light-rail Metro train approached, said Sgt. summary: A commuter train collided with a car and derailed near the University of Southern California campus in Los Angeles on Saturday, resulting in 21 injuries. The incident occurred when a westbound Hyundai turned north onto the tracks as an eastbound light-rail Metro train approached. The accident caused the train to dislodge, and ten people were transported to hospitals for treatment. One person was in critical condition and another in grave condition. The derailment is expected to cause traffic problems for the 6:30 p.m. Saturday soccer game between Mexico and Ecuador at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

article: (CNN)There were screams. Then the sounds of a commercial jetliner slamming into the mountainside. And finally silence. Deathly silence. The passengers did not see the pilot in the cabin, but they noticed the descent and the growing distance between the plane and the Alps. summary: Germanwings' first officer, Andreas Lubitz, locked out the captain, put the plane into a steep descent, and waited calmly for it to crash. This act is similar to others who have combined suicide with mass murder. The reason this is both fascinating and horrifying is due to the contradiction between what we expect from flying (stringently professional activity) and the reality of pilots being human.

article: March 30, 2015 . Monday on CNN Student News: Find out what issues were on the minds of Nigerians, as voters in Africa's largest democracy went to the polls. Discover how an astronaut on a 340-day mission to the International Space Station will become one of the experiments being conducted. And lend your ears to an invention that aims to extinguish fires with low-frequency sound waves. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Student News
summary: In Nigeria, students learn about important issues and events happening in their country, while astronauts conduct experiments on the International Space Station. The show also features an invention that uses sound waves to put out fires.

article: (CNN)Manchester United and skipper Wayne Rooney significantly boosted its own chances and delivered a probable knockout blow to Tottenham Hotspur's hopes of Champions League qualification with 3-0 home win Sunday. First half goals from Marouane Fellaini, Michael Carrick and Rooney effectively ended the EPL match as a contest, with the win leaving United in fourth spot, but only two points adrift of second-placed Manchester City.  Tottenham is seventh, six points adrift of the top four. Rooney's
summary: Manchester United secured a 3-0 home win against Tottenham Hotspur, lifting their Premier League table position to fourth place and reducing the gap to second-placed Manchester City to just two points. This result significantly improved United's chances of qualifying for the Champions League, while Tottenham's hopes of securing a Champions League spot were dashed. The victory also marked a significant boost for Louis Van Gaal's team, who faced mounting pressure due to recent underwhelming performances. Despite this, Tottenham remained in sixth place, six points behind the top four.

article: (CNN)Thousands of Singaporeans gathered in pouring rain Sunday to bid farewell to Lee Kuan Yew, the Southeast Asian city-state's founding prime minister who charted its spectacular economic rise. Draped in the national flag, Lee's coffin was taken on a solemn procession through the sodden streets of the tropical city, where crowds of mourners defied the downpour to pay their last respects. The funeral service was attended by dozens of foreign dignitaries, including former U.S. President Bill Cli
summary: Singapore's founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, passed away on Monday at the age of 91. Thousands of people gathered in the pouring rain to say goodbye to him. He led Singapore to become a rich and successful country after it became independent from Malaysia in 1965. People remember him for his work but also criticize him for limiting freedom of speech and treating some people unfairly.

article: Sanaa, Yemen (CNN)Rebels seized an international airport in Yemen Sunday as a U.N. envoy warned that the country was at "the edge of civil war." Houthi militants took over the airport in Taiz as they swept through the city and surrounding province, two officials with the Taiz provincial government said. One civilian was killed and 82 others wounded when the rebels fired at local residents protesting their presence, the officials said. The rebels have also seized security and intelligence buildin
summary: In Yemen, rebels seized an international airport in Taiz, prompting a U.N. envoy to warn of potential civil war. Rebels also took control of security and intelligence buildings, setting up checkpoints in the region. The United Nations Security Council expressed support for President Hadi but called for all parties to engage in peaceful dialogue. Peace talks have been unsuccessful thus far, leading to escalating violence and fears of terror group infiltration.

article: (CNN)The white-haired woman's face beams as the camera gets closer to her face. She's sitting on a couch, with a University of Oklahoma shirt draped behind her and a rap song playing in the background. Suddenly, the words spew from her pink-painted lips: "Ni****, ni****, ni****, ni****, ni****, ni****, ni*****!" The release of the Vine video, featuring the house mother of the campus' Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter, couldn't come at a worse time -- just days after video surfaced of frat members sing
summary: A white-haired woman, house mother of the campus' Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter, released a Vine video singing the word "ni****" while listening to a rap song. She denies being racist and claims the song played in the background was a Trinidad James track. Black alumni, William Bruce James II and Jonathon Davis, defend her and say she is not a racist. The Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter was suspended after video surfaced of frat members singling about excluding black students and alluding to lynching.

article: (CNN)Marine biologists at the South Carolina Aquarium are treating a rare, 475-pound leatherback sea turtle that washed up Saturday on a nearby beach. The episode marks the first rescue of a leatherback sea turtle in South Carolina and is believed to be only the fifth live rescue of this species in the United States, according to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources. The endangered turtle was found stranded on the Yawkey-South Island Preserve, a wildlife refuge near Georgetown, Sou
summary: A rare 475-pound leatherback sea turtle was rescued from a beach in South Carolina and treated by marine biologists at the South Carolina Aquarium. This is believed to be the first live rescue of a leatherback sea turtle in the US, making it only the fifth such rescue in the country. The turtle, named Yawkey, was found stranded on a wildlife refuge near Georgetown, South Carolina. Biologists are working with the state's Department of Natural Resources to determine the best location and timing for releasing the turtle back into the ocean, where it is believed to be a juvenile. Leatherback turtles are the largest turtles on Earth

article: (CNN)ISIS apparently claimed responsibility Thursday for the deadly terrorist attack at a landmark museum in the heart of that country's capital, a mass shooting that has shaken the birthplace of the Arab Spring and stirred questions about militants in the country. In an audio statement posted online Thursday, ISIS identified two men -- Abu Zakariya al-Tunisi and Abu Anas al-Tunisi -- it said used "automatic weapons and hand grenades" to kill and injure what it called "crusaders and apostates" i

Lausanne, Switzerland (CNN)Nuclear talks intensified Sunday between world powers and Iran, but key sticking points remained unresolved as the countries tried to reach a deal to curb Tehran's nuclear program ahead of a Tuesday deadline. As the negotiations entered their fourth day, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned the agreement coming together is worse than Israel's deepest fears. The talks had hit a snag on Saturday, with diplomats describing Iran as refusing to budge, but as the

(The Hollywood Reporter)Good artists borrow. Great artists steal. On Tuesday, a California federal jury delivered its own message to artists everywhere that inspiration can rise to copyright infringement. The verdict was reached after eight days of trial testimony examining whether Robin Thicke's and Pharrell Williams' "Blurred Lines," one of the most successful songs of the young century, was improperly drawn from a soulful hallmark from the prior one — Marvin Gaye's 1977 hit "Got to Give It Up

(CNN)For the first time in history over half the world's population live in cities -- more than 54% of us did in 2014. Mass urbanization is proving to be "the single most important transformation" the world is seeing in the 21st century, according to Jamal Saghir, director of sustainable development at the World Bank, and it shows no signs of letting up. By 2050, the U.N. predicts 66% of us will call a city our home. It is generally accepted that cities are the engines of economic growth, and no
summary: This news article discusses the rapid urbanization of the world, particularly focusing on the increasing number of people living in cities. According to the World Bank's Jamal Saghir, mass urbanization is one of the most significant transformations of the 21st century. By 2050, it is estimated that 66% of the global population will reside in cities. Urbanization is seen as a driving force behind economic growth, and Africa's cities, especially those in North Africa, are experiencing significant growth due to their young and diverse populations. The report from PwC ranks Africa's top "Cities of Opportunity" based on

article: (CNN)"The Daily Show" is getting a new host. On Monday, the show announced that comedian Trevor Noah will take over for Jon Stewart, who announced in February that he was leaving after 16 years. Stewart himself succeeded Craig Kilborn and saw the news program's popularity skyrocket. Jon Stewart to sign off 'Daily Show' "You don't believe it for the first few hours," Noah told the New York Times from Dubai, where he's on tour. "You need a stiff drink, and then unfortunately you're in a place wher
summary: Trevor Noah, a comedian from South Africa, is taking over as the new host of the popular TV show "The Daily Show" after Jon Stewart left due to health issues. Stewart, who had been hosting the show for 16 years, praised Noah's talent and experience, and Noah is excited to take on the role.

article: Lagos, Nigeria (CNN)It's a unique world where friendships are forged, deals struck and more than the occasional argument breaks out. Welcome to Nigeria's free readers associations -- where mostly young men gather around newspaper vendors to read the headlines and debate the issues of the day. They are called "free" because nobody actually buys the newspapers they are reading. Discussions among the free readers are loud and furious and have only intensified as Nigeria goes to the polls to decide
summary: In Nigeria, free readers associations have become popular, where young men gather to discuss and debate news topics. These gatherings, known as "free" associations, attract a large audience and are particularly lively during election periods. Newspaper vendor John Mgbachi, who sells free newspapers, believes that these discussions help his business and encourages him to raise prices slightly higher during peak times like football tournaments or election campaigns. Despite concerns about the decline in newspaper sales due to the growing popularity of online news, Mgbachi suggests that the association's popularity is a positive sign for the future.

article: (CNN)India's highest court has reversed a controversial law that gave the authorities sweeping powers to arrest and potentially jail people for comments posted on social networks and other Internet platforms. The Supreme Court ruled that Section 66A of the 2008 Information Technology Act was "unconstitutional" and "hit at the root of liberty and freedom of expression, the two cardinal pillars of democracy." Under Section 66A, alleged offenders could face up to three years in jail for posting mat
summary: The Supreme Court in India has ruled that a controversial law that gives the authorities power to arrest and imprison people for comments posted on social networks and other internet platforms is unconstitutional. The court stated that the language used in Section 66A of the Information Technology Act is vague and could be misinterpreted, leading to concerns over the right to freedom of expression. This decision has sparked a debate about curbs on freedom of speech in India, where laws like Section 66A and the intermediary guidelines have been implemented.

article: Los Angeles (CNN)Three area residents were arrested and charged Wednesday for allegedly operating four Southern California schools for Korean and Chinese students who never attended classes and lived in other states on student visas in a "pay-to-stay" scheme. The three educators collected as much as $6 million in annual tuition from an enrollment of about 1,500 foreign students who were largely from South Korea and China, said federal prosecutors. The arrests came after a federal grand jury indi

(CNN)Enjoy the latest pictures of the former Kate Middleton. They're the last you'll see for a while. The Duchess of Cambridge made her last official appearance Friday at a variety of spots across London, enjoying tours of a learning center and a church that hosts a youth charity. The former, the Stephen Lawrence Centre, is named for an aspiring architect who was stabbed to death at age 18 in 1993. His mother, Baroness Lawrence, escorted Catherine and her husband, Prince William, around the faci
summary: The Duchess of Cambridge, now known as Kate Middleton, visited various locations in London on Friday, including a learning center and a church that hosts a youth charity. She enjoyed tours of both places with her husband, Prince William. The Stephen Lawrence Centre, named after an aspiring architect who was murdered at age 18, was visited by Catherine and her husband. This visit marks the last official appearance she will make before giving birth to their second child.

article: (CNN)As relatives and friends mourn the loss of their loved ones aboard Germanwings Flight 9525, the world community is stunned by the sequence of events that led to co-pilot Andreas Lubitz purposely crashing the plane into the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board. I happen to have several personal connections to this tragedy: a recent graduate of Drexel University -- where I teach -- and her mother were on the ill-fated flight, I lived in Germany for 18 years and I am a psychologist who
summary: A Germanwings Flight 9525 plane crashed in France, killing all 150 people on board. Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, who was responsible for the crash, was found to have deliberately destroyed the plane because of a personal grievance. This incident raises questions about the reliability of human pilots and the need for more rigorous psychological screening and testing for pilots. It also highlights the importance of understanding the psychology of terrorists, such as Richard Reid and Eric Rudolph, who have shown that a single person can carry out acts of terrorism.

article: (CNN)The "Fifty Shades" series will have to handcuff a new director. Sam Taylor-Johnson, who directed "Fifty Shades of Grey," told Deadline.com that she won't be back for the sequel, "Fifty Shades Darker." "Directing 'Fifty Shades Of Grey' has been an intense and incredible journey for which I am hugely grateful," she said in a statement to the site. "While I will not be returning to direct the sequels, I wish nothing but success to whosoever takes on the exciting challenges of films two and thr
summary: Sam Taylor-Johnson, the director of the movie "Fifty Shades of Grey," has decided not to direct the sequel, "Fifty Shades Darker." She expressed gratitude for the experience of directing the first film but wished others well in their future endeavors.

article: (CNN)He may be suffering from the effects of a dislocated shoulder -- but golf legend Arnold Palmer has vowed that won't stop him from hitting his ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters in Augusta next month. The 85-year-old, speaking to reporters at the Trump Doral resort where he was opening a villa named after him, said he would look forward "to being out on that tee even if I fan it." Palmer's injury happened when he had a fall at the Father-Son Challenge in Florida shortly before Christ
summary: Arnold Palmer, 85, is planning to play in the Masters in April despite a dislocated shoulder, which occurred during a fall at the Father-Son Challenge in Florida shortly before Christmas. Despite his injury, Palmer plans to hit his ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters, stating, "Oh yeah, I plan on it," and that he won't be limited by his doctor's restrictions on swinging a club.

article: (CNN)A nuclear deal with international powers on Iran's nuclear program is within reach and achievable, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani told reporters Saturday. Rouhani said negotiators from both sides have found new common ground in recent days, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The President believes that "clinching a general deal is easy," according to the IRNA story, but hammering out agreements on certain details "will be a very tough and complicated job." Iran has been l

Chao Hu, Anhui, China (CNN)Six-year-old Lu Yiming is a handful. One minute, he's on the concrete roof of his two-story house, the next he's fiddling with fireworks. Now, he's skating down an alley. "Come back here!" yells his grandmother. "I have such a headache raising this child," 72-year-old old Tang Xinying confides. Lu's mother abandoned him after he was born and his father works as a carpenter in Shandong province hundreds of miles further north. He comes back perhaps once a year. In China
summary: A six-year-old boy named Lu Yiming lives in a village in China where his father works far away, while his mother left when he was born. Many children like Lu are called "left-behind children" because they don't have both parents with them all the time. These kids face challenges like not going to school, having more trouble with their minds, and having more problems behaving. This is because their parents have to go to different places for work, leaving them behind. There are many left-behind children in China, and experts worry about the long-term effects on society.

article: (CNN)The first official visit of Afghan President Ashraf Ghani to Washington comes as excitement mounts over the possibility that direct peace negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban are imminent. The visit, which began Sunday, offers the opportunity for discussion and progress on a number of fronts, the coming face-to-face talks with the Taliban almost certainly among them. But while the start of such talks would certainly be a positive development, it would hardly be a sign
summary: President Ashraf Ghani's visit to Washington marks a pivotal moment for Afghan peace talks, with the potential for direct negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban. While the prospect of an agreement is encouraging, it's important to recognize that achieving such a deal is unlikely to happen immediately due to several challenges facing the negotiations, including the Taliban's military strength, the Afghan government's inability to effectively govern, and the rise of splinter groups. The United States should continue to support these talks by promoting conditions that could make the possibility of success more likely, such as the Afghan government's demonstrated ability to govern and a clear strategy against the Taliban.

article: (CNN)Iraqi forces say they've captured key areas in their offensive to take back Tikrit, which has been under ISIS control since June. The security forces, backed by Shia militias, raised the Iraqi flag over the governorate and the main hospital buildings in the city Monday night, a security official with the forces in Tikrit told CNN. The gains, according to the official, came after a slow advance into the city as the forces dealt with more than 300 improvised explosive devices planted in the c
summary: Iraqi forces have taken control of important areas in their effort to reclaim Tikrit, a city under ISIS control since June. Supported by Shia militias, the forces raised the Iraqi flag over the governorate and the main hospital buildings in the city on Monday night. Security officials confirmed the capture of four neighborhoods in southern Tikrit, with at least 26 militants killed in the operation. The Iraqi federal police announced earlier that the forces had liberated four neighborhoods in southern Tikrit, while ISIS adjusted its positions in and around the city. The renewed push into Tikrit comes after U.S.-led airstrikes targeted ISIS targets around the city, paving the

article: (CNN)Hillary Clinton is back in the middle of an unfolding controversy. The revelation that as secretary of state she maintained a private email account, and that she had a private computer server in her New York home, sent shock waves through the world of politics last week. Questions arose about whether Clinton conducted her official business on private email, possibly violating regulations that were written to ensure that the activities of government officials remain accessible to the public.

(CNN)Swedish prosecutors have asked Julian Assange's legal representatives whether the WikiLeaks founder would consent to be interviewed in London and have his DNA taken via a swab. Assange has been holed up in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since June 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden, where prosecutors want to question him about 2010 allegations that he raped one woman and sexually molested another. Swedish prosecutors have previously balked at coming to Britain to question Assange. Howeve
summary: Swedish prosecutors have requested that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange agree to an interview in London and provide his DNA sample. Assange has been holed up at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since 2012, avoiding extradition to Sweden due to alleged sexual assaults. Swedish prosecutors have previously refused to come to Britain to question Assange, but a statute of limitation for certain charges expires in August 2015. Assange's legal team believes this request is positive, but acknowledges that time is of the essence.

article: (CNN)New Zealand are on course for a first ever World Cup title after a thrilling semifinal victory over South Africa, secured off the penultimate ball of the match. Chasing an adjusted target of 298 in just 43 overs after a rain interrupted the match at Eden Park, Grant Elliott hit a six right at the death to confirm victory and send the Auckland crowd into raptures. It is the first time New Zealand has ever reached a World Cup final, and it will play either Australia or India on Sunday. Te pai
summary: New Zealand won the World Cup semifinal against South Africa after a thrilling match, securing a first-ever World Cup title. Grant Elliott hit a crucial six off the penultimate ball to confirm victory, sending the Auckland crowd into raptures. This victory marks New Zealand's first time reaching a World Cup final, and they will face either Australia or India on Sunday. Te pair will then play each other in Sydney on Thursday.

article: Beijing (CNN)Five years ago, Beijinger Robert Zhao went on a trip to Tibet. What he encountered left him confused but intrigued. A science graduate from China's elite Tsinghua University, he had been taught to mistrust superstition and religion, but in the culture and devotion of the Buddhists he met he found something worth knowing. Now 25, he is considering giving up his job and becoming a monk. "It means I will have to give up everything of the ordinary world," he told CNN. While Buddhism has
summary: Five years ago, Beijinger Robert Zhao visited Tibet, where he discovered Buddhism, a practice he finds spiritually fulfilling despite challenges posed by modern life. Today, he considers becoming a monk, influenced by his encounter with Tibetan Buddhism's teachings, especially its emphasis on compassion and mindfulness. Despite potential conflicts with his job and relationships, Zhao sees Buddhism as a source of inner peace and support, helping him navigate personal struggles and maintain connections with others.

article: (CNN)An explosive-laden truck blew up at a camp for Egyptian security forces Tuesday morning, killing a civilian and injuring 44 people, state-run media reported. The attack took place in Al-Arish, in the country's North Sinai province, tha Al-Ahram news agency reported, citing the local health ministry. As the truck headed toward the camp's gate, guards shot at it, and the truck exploded. The injured included 42 Egyptian soldiers and two civilians. The driver of the truck was also killed, Al-Ah
summary: An explosion occurred near a security force camp in Al-Arish, Egypt, resulting in the death of a civilian and injuries to 44 others. The incident happened when an explosive-laden truck approached the camp's entrance, where guards fired shots at it, causing the truck to explode. The injured consisted of 42 Egyptian soldiers and two civilians, with the driver of the truck also being killed. The attacker, however, has not yet been identified. This incident is part of a larger wave of violence in North Sinai, which has seen numerous deaths and injuries due to militant attacks by Islamist groups. The Egyptian military is engaged in a

article: Mogadishu, Somalia (CNN)Islamic militants with the extremist group Al-Shabaab mounted a bloody attack Thursday on government administration offices in Baidoa, Somalia. Initial reports to police indicate that nine people, including four attackers, were killed after gunmen in military uniforms attacked the house of the former Somali parliament speaker and current president of the newly established southwest regional administration, said Col. Mahad Abdi, a Somali police officer. The attack began wh
summary: Somali government officials say 9 people, including 4 attackers, were killed in a violent attack by Islamic militants called Al-Shabaab. They attacked the house of a former Somali parliament speaker and the regional president of a new region in the country. This happened in a place called Baidoa, about 250 kilometers away from the capital Mogadishu. The militants tried to use bombs and guns to hurt the people inside the building. Somali police said that the attack started with a bomb at the entrance of the building. The African Union's special representative for Somalia condemned the attack and said that the troops working together with

article: (CNN)It's Canada's ultimate pairing. World No.7 and Wimbledon runner up Eugenie Bouchard posted a photo of herself on Twitter with compatriot and heartthrob Justin Bieber as they teamed up for a game of tennis. Bouchard credited the pop star's "nice serve" and once said the "Baby" singer would be her ideal date during an awkward on-court interview at 2014's Australian Open. Bieber courts a lot of interest on social media with a Twitter following of 61.3 million  -- roughly the entire population
summary: Canadian tennis player Eugenie Bouchard and Justin Bieber, a popular Canadian singer, played a game of tennis together. Bouchard thanked Bieber for his nice serve and even said he was her dream date at a big tennis competition. Bieber hasn't responded to Bouchard's tweet yet. They played a doubles game at a fun event called the Desert Smash. This event helps people who have cancer get scholarships.

article: (CNN)The Iran nuclear negotiations in Lausanne, Switzerland, reportedly have made substantive progress, inching closer toward a provisional agreement between the P5+1 and Iran. While the talks continued to unfold this week, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu restated his concern about an agreement with Iran, vowing "to continue to act against any threat." If an agreement is reached, the international spotlight will turn to Israel, in anticipation of its possible reaction. Israeli Defense
summary:
The Iran nuclear negotiations in Lausanne, Switzerland, have shown significant progress, bringing them closer to an agreement between the P5+1 and Iran. This progress comes amidst concerns raised by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has vowed to continue taking action against any potential threats posed by Iran. Should an agreement be reached, the implications for Israel would be immense, leading to questions about how it could respond effectively.

In the event of a deal being signed, Israel's leaders would need to carefully consider the potential consequences of their decision. For instance, a successful military strike on Iranian nuclear facilities might temporarily reduce Iran's nuclear capabilities, but it

article: (CNN)If you were the lucky recipient of a bunch of fragrant roses this Valentine's Day, it's likely that they came from Kenya. The country is the third largest exporter of cut flowers in the world, accounting for around 35% of all sales in the European Union. Famed for being long-lasting, Kenya's roses, carnations and summer flowers are also popular in Russia and the U.S. where last week several growers showcased their blooms at the World Floral Expo in Los Angeles. The event is one of the indus
summary: Kenya is the third largest exporter of cut flowers in the world, accounting for around 35% of all sales in the European Union. The country is known for producing long-lasting roses, carnations, and summer flowers, which are popular in Russia and the US. Kenya's flower power is attributed to its sunny climate, which allows for high-quality blossoms to be grown year-round without the need for expensive greenhouses. The country's flower industry has been a significant contributor to the economy, generating around $600 million in revenue last year and employing nearly 500,000 people. However, some activists

article: (CNN)Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson had a way better weekend than you. The actor hosted "Saturday Night Live" and rocked out in some memorable sketches, including a live-action "Bambi" remake with some of the "SNL" cast portraying actors from the "Fast and Furious" franchise. "Whan I was a boy, they took away my mother," Johnson said in character as a muscle-bound, gun-wielding Bambi. "And now it's time for them to pay ... dearly." He also transformed, Hulk-style, into "The Rock Obama" in a sketch in
summary: Actor Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted "Saturday Night Live" and performed a live-action "Bambi" remake, spoofing WWE and taking part in Wrestlemania 31 alongside UFC champion Ronda Rousey.

article: (CNN)Vatican City is accustomed to welcoming millions of visitors to its grounds each year, but Thursday a very special tour group got a look inside. Approximately 150 homeless people were divided into three groups and ushered through the Petriano entrance next to St. Peter's Square, according to Vatican paper L'Osservatore Romano. "The poor, who usually see only the steps outside the colonnade of St. Peter's Square, will also have a chance to enjoy the Vatican's artistic patrimony," the paper w
summary: A special tour group of 150 homeless people visited Vatican City on Thursday, including visits to the Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, Domus Sanctae Marthae, piazzale della Zecca, and Cancello di Gregogio, all led by Archbishop Konrad Krajewski. This was part of the Vatican's initiative to provide a glimpse of the Vatican's artistic patrimony for the poor.

article: London (CNN)Previously secret correspondence between Britain's Prince Charles and government officials is to be made public after a Supreme Court ruling Thursday. The Guardian newspaper had been fighting for the communications to be released since 2005. Charles is next in line to the British throne and as King would constitutionally be required to maintain strict political neutrality. Some commentators say letters to officials suggest he could be a "meddling king," attempting to influence politi
summary: The Prince of Wales, who is next in line to the British throne, has been secretly communicating with government officials since 2005. This correspondence, previously kept secret, is set to be released publicly due to a Supreme Court ruling. The Guardian newspaper, led by editor-in-chief Alan Rusbridger, fought for the letters' release since 2005. Prince Charles is known for his neutrality, but the letters suggest that he may be influencing politicians. The government, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, acknowledges that the letters were kept secret and will now consider revising the law to allow future releases.

article: (CNN)"The Law of the Jungle, which never orders anything without a reason, forbids every beast to eat Man." I still remember the first time I read the passage from "The Jungle Book," heart racing beneath my pajamas covered with The Six Million Dollar Man. "The real reason for this is that man-killing means, sooner or later, the arrival of white men on elephants, with guns, and hundreds of brown men with gongs, rockets and torches. Then everybody in the jungle suffers," Rudyard Kipling wrote. I p
summary: The article discusses the impact of human population growth on wildlife conservation, particularly the challenges faced by the tiger population in India due to increasing human activity. The author shares their experience of encountering tigers in the wild after reading the famous quote from Rudyard Kipling's "The Jungle Book." They explore the reasons behind the high number of tigers in captivity compared to those in the wild and discuss the issue of tiger-human conflict, where farmers often mistakenly believe tigers are a threat to their livestock. Despite this, conservation efforts such as tiger conflict mediation and anti-poaching campaigns have shown promising results in recent years. However, the author also

article: (CNN)When Indiana Gov. Michael Pence signed his state's Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), he apparently did not anticipate the resulting uproar.  Many of Indiana's businesses fear that the law could be used to allow store owners to deny service to gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) persons. The NCAA has expressed concern about the Final Four, which Indianapolis is hosting this weekend, and other companies have threatened to move their businesses outside of the state. But, when
summary: Indiana's Governor, Michael Pence, signed a Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) that allows businesses to refuse service to LGBTQ individuals. However, businesses fear this law could be used to discriminate against them. Some companies, including the NCAA and others, have threatened to move their businesses outside of the state. Governor Pence initially claimed the law was not about discrimination but rather about protecting religious freedom. Members of the Indiana legislature pledged to "fix" the law, but Governor Pence later suggested a fix might be necessary. However, if a fix were to be made, it would likely involve adopting state-wide nondiscrimination laws or amending the RFRA

article: (CNN)Jordan Spieth has Rory McIlroy and the world No.1 spot firmly in his sights after winning the Valspar Championship on Sunday. Spieth won a three-way play-off with a 28-foot birdie on the third extra hole to become only the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before turning 22. It is a feat that not even McIlroy mastered with Tiger Woods, Sergio Garcia and Robert Gamez the only players to have achieved that particular accolade in the past 75 years. But it is the Northern Ir
summary: Jordan Spieth clinched the Valspar Championship and secured the No.1 spot on the PGA Tour by winning a three-way play-off, becoming the fourth player since 1940 to win twice before turning 22. The Northern Irishman is focused on chasing Rory McIlroy and ultimately aiming to become the best in the world.

article: April 1, 2015 . A trip around the world starts things off this Tuesday, with coverage of events in Nigeria, Switzerland and West Africa. Then, at the start of Financial Literacy Month, we're taking a look at wages in the U.S. and how they're hampering the economy. And could cyborg cockroaches give pests a new role as rescuers? Discuss the ethics, the debate and the science from today's show! On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Studen
summary: CNN Student News started on April 1, 2015. It covers events happening in Nigeria, Switzerland, and West Africa. During Financial Literacy Month, it talks about wages in the US and how they affect the economy. There's also an interesting discussion about cyborg cockroaches and their potential use as rescuers. The show aims to educate students by considering Common Core State Standards, national standards, and state standards.

article: (CNN)Britain's Lewis Hamilton made the perfect start to his world title defense by winning the opening race of the F1 season in Australia Sunday to lead a Mercedes one-two in Melbourne. Polesitter Hamilton controlled the race on the Albert Park street circuit to win from teammate Nico Rosberg of Germany. Four-time world champion Sebastian Vettel took the final podium position for his new team Ferrari, holding off Felipe Massa in the Willams. It was the 34th career victory for two-time world cham
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the first race of the Formula One season in Australia, leading a Mercedes one-two behind teammate Nico Rosberg. Sebastian Vettel took the final podium spot for his new team Ferrari. Hamilton won his seventh race from eight starts and Mercedes dominated as he and Rosberg pulled clear of their nearest challengers. It was Britain's first world title defense win since 2008.

article: (CNN)Michael Douglas' son Dylan had a run-in with anti-Semitism -- and the actor wants to do something about it. In an opinion column for the Los Angeles Times, the producer and "Wall Street" Oscar winner described an incident last summer in an unidentified country in "southern Europe." The older of his two children with actress Catherine Zeta-Jones, 14-year-old Dylan, came to his father in tears. "A man at the pool had started hurling insults at him," Douglas writes. It wasn't because of anythi
summary: In an opinion piece for the Los Angeles Times, Michael Douglas discusses a run-in with anti-Semitism involving his son, Dylan, and describes the incident in an unidentified southern European country. Douglas attributes the incident to someone who was offended by Dylan's wearing a Star of David. Douglas believes that anti-Semitism has become more prevalent due to various factors such as income inequality, religious extremism, and hatred of Israel. He emphasizes the importance of confronting anti-Semitism whenever it occurs and denouncing it as a way to prevent its spread. Douglas urges all individuals and societies to work together to stop anti-Semitism and ensure that Dylan and future generations are protected from its dangers

article: London (CNN)It might sound like a really old wives' tale, but a thousand-year-old Anglo-Saxon potion for eye infections may hold the key to wiping out the modern-day superbug MRSA, according to new research. The 10th-century "eyesalve" remedy was discovered at the British Library in a leather-bound volume of Bald's Leechbook, widely considered to be one of the earliest known medical textbooks. Christina Lee, an expert on Anglo-Saxon society from the School of English at the University of Notting
summary: A thousand-year-old Anglo-Saxon potion called "eyesalve" has been discovered in a leather-bound volume of Bald's Leechbook, which is widely considered to be one of the earliest known medical textbooks. The ancient remedy contains ingredients such as garlic and onion/bile, which are currently being investigated for their potential antibiotic effectiveness. Researchers from the University of Nottingham, led by Christina Lee, recreated the recipe to test its effectiveness against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), a type of staph bacteria that does not respond to commonly used antibiotics. The scientists were surprised to find that the eyesalve

article: Jerusalem (CNN)Within 48 hours of his election night victory, Benjamin Netanyahu rolled back his pre-election comments that there would be no Palestinian state if he were Prime Minister, but the damage may already have been done to relations with the two other major players in the negotiations: the United States and the Palestinians. In an interview with NBC, Netanyahu said, "I haven't changed my policy, I never retracted my speech six years ago calling for a demilitarized Palestinian state that
summary: In the wake of his election, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed support for a Palestinian state, but his pre-election rhetoric and actions have damaged relations with the United States and the Palestinians. Netanyahu has called for a demilitarized Palestinian state, while Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas refuses to recognize Israel and Hamas has formed a pact with the Islamist group. The United States has reassessed its relationship with Israel, but the potential for a lasting peace remains uncertain due to the lack of trust between both sides.

article: (CNN)It was nothing if not predictable. Take combustible issues like religion and sexuality, stir in a new law and talk of a boycott, then -- boom! -- the debate on social media explodes. And so it has proved with Indiana's new "religious freedom" law, signed Thursday by Gov. Mike Pence. The new law could allow businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers if serving them would contravene the business owner's religious beliefs. Supporters of the bill say it protects their right to believe as
summary: Indiana's new "religious freedom" law allows businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers based on their religious beliefs, sparking a heated debate on social media. Supporters argue that it protects their right to believe as they choose, while opponents see it as bigotry dressed up as liberty. The law has sparked reactions ranging from calls for a boycott to assurances that businesses will not discriminate, with some businesses pledging to continue serving all customers.

article: (CNN)From an iconic marble statue of a heavily pregnant disabled artist to the more recent giant blue cockerel, London's Fourth Plinth art project has always provided a controversial modern twist to the traditional landmarks around London's Trafalgar Square. The latest offering, "Gift Horse," which took up residence in the Square's northwest corner Thursday, looks set to continue the tradition with a work that explores the link between power, money and history, according to organizers. Unveiled
summary: London's Fourth Plinth art project has unveiled a new sculpture called "Gift Horse," created by German artist Hans Haacke. The sculpture is a skeleton horse with a ticker showing live market data from London's Stock Exchange, making it a commentary on the relationship between art, commerce, and history. The piece is a nod to the original equestrian statue planned for the plinth, but never realized.

article: (The Hollywood Reporter)The skies over Gotham City might become bright once again in 2016, with Adam West and Burt Ward promising a return to their career-high roles of Batman and Robin as part of an upcoming animated project next year. The comments took place at the Mad Monster Party in Charlotte, NC this weekend, with Ward somewhat uncertainly telling the crowd that they "can look forward to a new animated "Batman" full length, 90-minute feature, coming out on the 50th anniversary." (That woul
summary: Actor Burt Ward says there could be a new animated Batman film released in 2016, featuring him and actor Adam West as Batman and Robin. They are both 50 years old and were part of the original Batman TV series.

article: Lausanne, Switzerland (CNN)Talks to reach a deal on a framework agreement on Iran's nuclear program will be extended an extra day, U.S. officials said Tuesday. "‎We've made enough progress in the last days to merit staying until Wednesday. There are several difficult issues still remaining,"‎ State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf said. White House press secretary Josh Earnest said the talks in Lausanne would continue another day as "long as the conversations continue to be productive." Diploma

(CNN)The BBC's director-general, Tony Hall, has allegedly received death threats days after "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson was dropped. "Police in Westminster are investigating an allegation of threats to kill," the Metropolitan Police confirmed to CNN in a statement. The allegation was reported to the police on Wednesday. "The threat was made by email," the police added. "The content of the message suggests (it was sent) from outside the UK." The alleged threats come shortly after Hall took th
summary:
- BBC director-general, Tony Hall, allegedly received death threats days after "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson was dropped.
- Alleged threats were sent via email and suggest the sender is outside the UK.
- The threat was made by a person claiming to be from outside the UK.
- BBC released a statement confirming the allegations and stating they will not renew Clarkson's contract.
- Hall announced he made the decision after carefully considering the facts and meeting both Clarkson and producer Oisin Tymon.
- The BBC will look into finding a new host for "Top Gear" in 2016.

article: (CNN)I was deeply moved watching Julianne Moore win the Oscar for "Still Alice," a movie I was proud and privileged to be an executive producer on. Julianne gives a harrowing performance as a brilliant 50-year-old college professor who loses her brain and herself to early-onset Alzheimer's disease. This is a huge moment for Julianne -- and a huge moment for all of us who have been trying to focus public attention on this staggering disease. Witnessing Alzheimer's progress on the big screen is as

(CNN)A Canadian tourist was killed after a small inflatable tour boat collided with a whale off the coast of Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, authorities said Thursday. The victim was identified as Jennifer Karren, 35, according to the Baja California Sur Prosecutor General's Office. Karren is a Canadian from Calgary, Alberta, according to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Two other people aboard the Cabo Adventures' vessel were injured in the incident that happened Wednesday a quarter-mile from the
summary: A Canadian tourist named Jennifer Karren, who was traveling on a small inflatable tour boat near Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, unfortunately lost her life during a collision with a whale. This incident occurred when Karren fell into the water while trying to avoid the whale, prompting her tour group to take action. Despite immediate assistance, including CPR by a tour guide and a nurse, Karren did not survive. The tour boat captain and other passengers were injured, and the incident resulted in a serious accident investigation by the Mexican Federal Attorney General's Office for the Protection of the Environment.

article: (CNN)A court in Ivory Coast has sentenced former first lady Simone Gbagbo to 20 years in prison, the official AIP news agency said. Gbagbo was convicted Monday for her role in carrying out crimes against humanity following post-election violence in 2010 which left more than 3,000 people dead. Her husband, former president Laurent Gbagbo, is in the custody of the Hague-based International Criminal Court awaiting trial over similar charges. The charges stem from the aftermath of Gbagbo's husband's
summary: A judge in Ivory Coast has sentenced former first lady Simone Gbagbo to 20 years in prison for her role in the post-election violence in 2010. She was found guilty for being an "indirect co-perpetrator" with her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, who is currently awaiting trial at the International Criminal Court. The charges stem from the 2010 presidential election aftermath, when Laurent Gbagbo refused to step down and sparked months of violence between supporters of the two sides, resulting in thousands of deaths.

article: (CNN)With a little bit of help from Donald Trump, Rory McIlroy was re-united with the golf club he famously threw into the lake at Doral -- but probably wished the golf-loving tycoon had not bothered. Never one to miss a media opportunity, Trump, the owner of the Blue Monster course in Florida, got a scuba diver to retrieve the 3-iron club which world No. 1 McIlroy had thought he had seen the last of during Friday's second round at the WGC-Cadillac Championship. The 68-year-old American entrepre
summary: Donald Trump helped Rory McIlroy retrieve his lost golf club at the WGC-Cadillac Championship. However, Trump's intervention led to McIlroy making another mistake by throwing his 3-iron into the water, resulting in a double bogey six and tying for ninth place. Despite the incident, McIlroy promised to return the club to Trump after the round.

article: Lagos, Nigeria (CNN)With partial results reported in the Nigerian presidential election, it appears opposition candidate Muhammadu Buhari is leading incumbent President Goodluck Jonathan. Reuters, which has collated results from three-quarters of Nigeria's states as they're broadcast live on state TV, reported that Buhari has so far obtained 11.5 million votes, Jonathan 9.5 million. Electoral officers from each of the 36 states are taking turns declaring results from their respective states at t

(CNN)Reigning world champion Lewis Hamilton and teammate Nico Rosberg resumed where they left off last season as the 2015 Formula One season kicked off in Melbourne. The Mercedes duo, who took pole position in all but one of last season's qualifying sessions and won 16 of the 19 races, were dominant in first and second practice for Sunday's Australian Grand Prix. Rosberg, who won last year's GP at Albert Park, was fastest around the Melbourne street circuit on Friday, finishing 0.1 second ahead
summary: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, the reigning world champions, returned to form in their first practice session for the 2015 Formula One season in Melbourne. Mercedes dominated the first and second practice sessions, with Rosberg leading Lewis Hamilton by 0.1 second. Sebastian Vettel, driving for Ferrari, finished third, followed by Kimi Raikkonen for Williams. The remaining drivers, including Giedo van der Garde, struggled to compete with the Mercedes team.

article: (CNN)The HBO documentary "Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck" is already drawing rave reviews on the film festival circuit, including sold-out showings at both Sundance and the True/False fests before its television premiere on May 4th. However, anticipation for the film's soundtrack is about to hit fever pitch as director Brett Morgen revealed that the accompanying album will feature "a mind-blowing 12-minute acoustic Cobain unheard track," the filmmaker tweeted (via Loudwire). Kurt Cobain documentar
summary: HBO's documentary film "Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck" is gaining buzz with positive reviews at film festivals, and its soundtrack is expected to be released soon. The soundtrack will include a mind-blowing 12-minute acoustic track of Cobain's music, according to director Brett Morgen. No further details have been shared about the song, but it will be featured in the film's soundtrack.

article: (CNN)Before he was Jihadi John, he was little John -- a young version of the same Mohammed Emwazi who authorities say later became the English-speaking face of ISIS terror. His earlier, innocent image can be seen in video obtained from Britain's Channel 4. It shows a teenage boy in the schoolyard of a West London secondary school. He walks through a sea of fellow students in his zippered sweatshirt over his polo shirt, wearing a backpack and carrying a plastic bottle. At one point, a basketball
summary: The article discusses the transformation of Mohammed Emwazi, a former British schoolboy, into Jihadi John, an infamous ISIS terrorist. Emwazi started as a normal, friendly teenager, but later became more focused and involved in extremist activities. The article also highlights the confusion surrounding the identity of Jihadi John, as some believe he is Emwazi's father.

article: (CNN)The murder earlier this month of 27-year-old Farkhunda at the hands of a mob that beat her to death,  burned her body and tossed her into a river shocked Afghanistan, a country in which unspeakable things often hit the headlines. The young woman from Kabul was falsely accused of burning pages in the Holy Quran.  What followed was the horror of mob rule, all captured on video while bystanders looked on. Soon after the incident, the images of her brutal slaying went viral on social media, not

(CNN)North Korea has arrested what it claims are two spies who worked for South Korea's intelligence service, a North Korean official said Thursday on condition of anonymity. The men, identified as Kim Kook Kie and Choi Chun Kil, are accused of committing crimes of "terrorism" and bringing in "large quantities of forged currency," the North Korean source said. The official said Kim had made a declaration of guilt. CNN cannot confirm the authenticity of the declaration or whether, if Kim made one
summary: North Korea has detained two alleged spies working for South Korea's intelligence service, who are accused of committing crimes of terrorism and forging large amounts of currency. However, the North Korean official denying their authenticity, stating that they did not make a declaration of guilt. The South Korean National Intelligence Service denies the authenticity of the information provided.
hallucinated_entities: the south korean national intelligence service

article: (CNN)Things just got messy with that One Direction breakup. Just when folks were starting to heal from the shock of Zayn Malik's decision to quit the super-successful boy group on Wednesday, a social media dustup has fans all a-Twitter. Zayn Malik leaving One Direction . Music producer Naughty Boy got into a war of words with One Direction's Louis Tomlinson after the producer retweeted a user going by Naughty Boy/Zayn (@naughtyboymus). The tweet was captioned "The truth" and contained a video of
summary: One Direction member Zayn Malik announced his departure from the boy band on Wednesday, leading to a social media backlash. A Twitter dustup ensued between Zayn and music producer Naughty Boy, who had previously collaborated with him. Tomlinson, Zayn's longtime friend, criticized Naughty Boy for being disrespectful and unconsiderate. The incident sparked numerous hashtags trending on Twitter, including "Zaughty" and "masterofallwisdom." In response, Naughty Boy shared a demo song titled "I Wont Mind" from him and Malik.

article: (CNN)"A pilot called me last week, concerned he might have Marfan syndome," a health care provider told me recently at a meeting.  "But if I find he has the disease, do I have to report him to the Federal Aviation Administration?  And if so, should I call him first and tell him that?  Would he lose his job?"  She was totally unsure what to do.  Several other providers were present, and none of them knew, either. "You should definitely call him and tell him," a health care lawyer, who was present

(CNN)A swarm of insects tends to startle us -- chaotic yet organized, fascinating and beautiful. Take it one step further. Instead of bees hovering around a tree, imagine cheese balls. Solo cups in the place of birds, glow sticks as locusts. What seems like a figment of a wild imagination becomes reality in Thomas Jackson's "Emergent Behavior" series. Jackson grew up in Rhode Island and worked in publishing in New York for 13 years, ultimately landing his dream gig as an editor with Forbes magaz
summary: Thomas Jackson, an artist from Rhode Island, creates mesmerizing photographs that depict insects, birds, and other creatures as if they were floating in space. His work features unconventional arrangements of objects, often using them to create a sense of chaos and order. Jackson's photography has gained recognition and popularity, and his latest series, "Emergent Behavior," showcases his unique style of combining art and science. Through his installations, Jackson explores the concept of swarming behavior, which he finds intriguing and visually appealing. His photographs have been featured in various publications and online platforms, and he continues to push the boundaries of his creative expression through his innovative and captivating

article: (CNN)At first Raymond Goldstein thought he'd received a spam email. The message to the Cambridge University physicist was asking for help working out the dynamics of hair, specifically the shape of ponytails. Goldstein thought he'd "won the Nigerian lottery." Poised to click delete, he scrolled through the message one more time and discovered it was from global consumer goods giant Unilever. Curiosity piqued, he met with a company representative, and the rest, as they say, is history. Assembling
summary: This news article discusses the Ig Nobel Prizes, a humorous and satirical version of the Nobel Prizes, and highlights the contributions of various researchers in the field of science. It mentions the history and impact of the Ig Nobel Prizes, the criteria for selecting winners, and the process of choosing nominees. The article also provides examples of the humorous and often absurd research that has been recognized by the Ig Nobel Prizes, showcasing the blurred line between serious and ridiculous research.

article: (CNN)As an offensive guard for the Baltimore Ravens, John Urschel already has a lot on his plate. He regularly goes head to head with the top defensive players in the NFL and does his best to keep quarterback Joe Flacco out of harm's way. But besides his endeavors on the field, Urschel also keeps up another demanding pursuit that is rarely associated with NFL players: mathematical research. Not content with the respect of the locker room, he also seeks the esteem of top mathematicians around the
summary: John Urschel, an offensive guard for the Baltimore Ravens, is an accomplished mathematician who also plays football professionally. He holds a Bachelor's and Master's degree in mathematics with a 4.0 GPA and has published numerous papers in major mathematical journals. Urschel's latest contribution to the mathematical realm is a paper for the Journal of Computational Mathematics, titled "A Cascadic Multigrid Algorithm for Computing the Fiedler Vector of Graph Laplacians." Urschel's decision to continue playing football despite concerns about potential brain injury is driven by his passion for the game and the rush he gets from dominating opponents. He trains

article: Sanaa, Yemen (CNN)At any moment, Saudi troops could march through Yemen, heating up an already intense conflict that could have ramifications across the Middle East. On Monday, a Saudi-led coalition of nine countries continued airstrikes against Shiite Houthi rebels, who have captured key parts of Yemen and ousted that country's President, and who could spread Iran's influence in the region. And the notion of an Iranian proxy power in Yemen is unacceptable to many -- especially Iran's staunch ri

(CNN)An ancient ring has shed new light on the ties between Vikings and the Islamic world, more than a century after its discovery. The finger ring found in a 9th century Swedish grave is inscribed with Arabic Kufic writing. The letters appear to read "AL_LLH, researchers say, which they interpret as meaning "for/to (the approval of) Allah." In a paper published in the journal Scanning, the researchers say it is the only ring with an Arabic inscription ever found at a Scandinavian archaeological
summary: A ring from a 9th century Swedish grave has revealed that Vikings had strong ties with the Islamic world over a century ago. The ring, which was discovered in Birka, a key trading center during the Viking age, bears an Arabic inscription and is the only one of its kind ever found at a Scandinavian archaeological site. The researchers believe that the ring was passed down through several owners without much use, and suggests that there may have been direct contact between Vikings and the Islamic world, facilitating cultural exchange and trade.

article: (CNN)The Syrian military claims to have shot down a U.S. drone, state media reported Tuesday. "Syrian Air Defense systems shot down a U.S. UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle) north of Latakia Province," the state-run Syrian Arab News Agency said. The U.S. military lost contact with a MQ-1 Predator drone over Syria, a U.S. official said Tuesday. Claims that the drone was shot down by Syrian forces are still being investigated, the official said. The drone was believed to be conducting a reconnaissance
summary: A drone operated by the US has been shot down by Syrian forces, according to state media. The US military had lost contact with the drone, which was flying over Syria near the port city of Latakia. The US official investigating the incident stated that claims that the drone was shot down by Syrian forces were being investigated. This incident follows the use of drones by multiple countries around the world.

article: Sanaa, Yemen (CNN)The U.S. military is in the process of evacuating about 100 Special Operations forces members from the Al Anad airbase in Yemen due to that country's deteriorating security situation, sources in the region familiar with the situation told CNN. Those being evacuated are the last American troops stationed in the Arab nation, which is home to al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the terrorist group also known as AQAP. The United States closed its embassy in Sanaa last month, after H

(CNN)NATO jets scrambled to intercept Russian military aircraft as they neared Latvian airspace, officials said on Wednesday. Estonian radar detected the aircraft over the Baltic Sea on Tuesday night, NATO said. Other than the lead aircraft, NATO said, none of the other Russian military aircraft was on a flight plan. NATO sent jets to identify the planes and later reported that the military aircraft flew on into Russian airspace. NATO didn't say how many Russian aircraft were involved. The fligh
summary: Russian military aircraft have been spotted near Latvia's airspace, prompting NATO jets to scramble to intercept them. Estonia's radar detected the aircraft over the Baltic Sea on Tuesday night. NATO did not disclose the number of Russian military aircraft involved, but did state that none of the other aircraft were on a flight plan. The incident comes amid Russia's Northern Fleet placing itself on full combat alert for exercises involving nearly 40,000 troops and 50 warships. NATO has condemned the annexation of Crimea and is increasing its troop presence in the region.

article: Kano, Nigeria (CNN)Troops from Niger and Chad discovered a mass grave with more than 90 decomposed bodies near a northern Nigerian town recently retaken from the Islamic militant group Boko Haram, security sources from both countries said Friday. The corpses, some of them beheaded, were found in a shallow mass grave under a bridge just outside the Nigerian town of Damasak, near the border with Niger, the sources said. Troops from Niger and Chad took back the town from Boko Haram last week during
summary: Nigerian troops discovered a mass grave containing over 90 decomposed bodies near Damasak, a northern Nigerian town recently taken back from Boko Haram. The victims, some of whom were beheaded, were found in a shallow mass grave under a bridge near the border with Niger. The discovery was made during a joint operation between Niger and Chad, which took back the town from the Islamic militant group on Friday.

article: (CNN)"In order to attain the impossible, one must attempt the absurd," wrote Miguel de Cervantes, the Shakespeare of Spain. And the quest to find his remains has sometimes seemed both, even (dare one say it) quixotic in a time of recession. But forensic scientists have persevered, and appear to have triumphed. Almost 400 years after Cervantes' death, a team led by Francisco Etxeberria announced Tuesday that they were confident they had found Cervantes' coffin in the crypt of the Convent of the B
summary: Forensic scientists have identified the remains of Miguel de Cervantes, the renowned Spanish author, after searching for his coffin for over 400 years. Although the remains are not in sufficient condition for a definitive identification, the team believes they have found Cervantes' bones among the remains of 16 people in a common grave in Madrid. The team hopes to reinter Cervantes at the convent and build a new entrance to the crypt in time for the 400th anniversary of his death next year.

article: (CNN)Marvin Gaye's children have penned an open letter in the hope of "set[ting] the record straight on a few misconceptions" in the media's coverage of their successful lawsuit against the writers of Robin Thicke's 2013 hit "Blurred Lines." Nona Gaye, Frankie Gaye and Marvin Gaye III's joint letter mainly dives into the background and legacy of Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up," the 1977 single the court found to have been copied by Thicke and co-writer Pharrell Williams. Read more: Kendrick La

(CNN)On "Family Matters" we knew him as Eddie Winslow.  This week, as inmate 402282. Actor Darius McCrary was jailed on Wednesday for failure to pay child support. He wasn't behind bars long, McCrary was released before the day was over, according to Carrie Rudzki with the jail in Oakland County, Michigan. McCrary, 38, took to Twitter as news of his arrest spread. "All I'm trying to do is raise my son," he tweeted.  "#BeingDadIsNotAnOption" But critics were quick to recall when McCrary's Eddie c
summary: Actor Darius McCrary was arrested on Wednesday for failing to pay child support. He was released from jail before the day ended, but critics quickly pointed out his resemblance to Eddie Winslow, an actor who appeared on "Family Matters." McCrary defended himself, saying he had never been arrested and that he had been involved in numerous films and television shows.

article: (CNN)What happens when John Stamos shows up outside the "Full House" home that made him a star? Nothing, apparently. For reasons unknown to us, Stamos was recently lurking outside the popular San Francisco attraction when a group of tourists showed up. It appears they were too busy gawking at the house to realize "Uncle Jesse" was standing next to them. It appears that Stamos was amused and posted an Instagram of him standing next to them. The caption? "Boy, these youngsters have 0.0 idea what t
summary: John Stamos, who played the role of Uncle Jesse on the hit TV show "Full House," recently visited the popular San Francisco attraction where he starred, only to be spotted by a group of tourists. The visitors were so engrossed in their surroundings that they didn't notice Stamos standing nearby until he stepped forward. In response, Stamos took a photo with the tourists and posted it on Instagram, jokingly saying "These youngsters have no idea what they're missing." Despite the lack of fan reaction, Stamos continued to work on his career with guest roles in TV shows like "Two and a Half Men" and "Gal

article: (CNN)A severe solar storm created a stunning display of light in the night sky over parts of the United States, Europe, Australia and New Zealand early Wednesday morning, spotted by those lucky enough to be awake in the wee hours. Called aurora borealis in the Northern Hemisphere and aurora australis in the Southern Hemisphere, the lights were the product of large geomagnetic blasts from the sun that arrived Tuesday about 10 a.m. ET (1 a.m. Wednesday in Sydney). Both the aurora borealis and the
summary: A severe solar storm created a spectacular display of light in the night sky over various locations including the United States, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand, observed by people who were awake during the early hours. This occurrence was caused by large geomagnetic blasts from the sun, which sent charged particles towards the Earth, resulting in aurora borealis (Northern Lights) in the Northern Hemisphere and aurora australis (Southern Lights) in the Southern Hemisphere. These lights were formed due to collisions between these particles and oxygen in the Earth's upper atmosphere, producing vibrant colors. The strength of the storm led to a G4 level on the scale

article: Aberdeenshire, Scotland (CNN)In an exclusive interview ahead of his U.S. tour -- and ahead of his 10-year wedding anniversary -- Prince Charles paid tribute to the "brilliant" way his wife, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, has taken on the "real, real challenge" of defining her public role. "It's always marvelous to have somebody who, you know, you feel understands and wants to encourage. Although she certainly pokes fun if I get too serious about things. And all that helps," Prince Charles told CN
summary: Prince Charles, the Duke of Cornwall, spoke about his wife, Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, during an exclusive interview ahead of her 10-year wedding anniversary. He expressed gratitude for her ability to handle her public role with grace and professionalism. Charles believes that Camilla's commitment to her personal values and interests has helped change public perception regarding her status as queen. Despite initial opposition, public opinion has shifted significantly towards accepting Camilla as queen, with a majority now supporting her title.

article: (CNN)Windell D. Middlebrooks, the actor best known as the straight-talking Miller High Life delivery man, died Monday morning, his agent told CNN. Middlebrooks' family also posted a statement on his Facebook page Tuesday confirming the 36-year-old's death. No cause of death was provided. "The Middlebrooks, with sorrowed hearts, announce the passing of a young, black star. Windell took his final bow and with great joy exited stage left in the early morning of March 9th, 2015," the statement read.
summary: Actor Windell Middlebrooks, best known for playing the delivery man in the popular TV show "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia," passed away on March 9, 2015. His agent confirmed his death and his family released a statement expressing sorrow. Middlebrooks had appeared in other shows such as "Body of Proof" and "Scrubs."

article: (CNN)U.S. District Judge Terrence Berg is recovering from a gunshot wound after an apparent robbery attempt in Detroit. The FBI confirms he was shot Thursday night. CNN affiliate WDIV is reporting that the judge was shot in front of his home and that Detroit police say they think it "happened during a robbery attempt, which likely had nothing to do with his profession." Berg was nominated by President Obama to the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in April 2012. Berg also
summary: A U.S. District Judge named Terrence Berg was injured on Thursday night when he was shot while trying to protect himself from a robbery attempt in Detroit. The FBI confirmed the incident, and CNN reported that the judge was shot in front of his home. Police believe the shooting was not related to his job as a judge. Berg was previously an assistant U.S. attorney for over 20 years and was nominated by President Obama to the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in April 2012. He is married and has three children.

article: (CNN)Arsenal crashed out of the Champions League at the last 16 stage for the fifth time in succession after falling agonizingly short in Monaco. The Premier League side recorded a 2-0 victory on the night but went out on away goals after the tie finished level at 3-3 on aggregate. Monaco, which won 3-1 in the first leg, was overwhelmed for much of the contest and was fortunate to escape without being dumped out of the competition. Olivier Giroud's first half strike and Aaron Ramsey's 79th minut
summary: Arsenal were knocked out of the Champions League by Monaco after losing 3-3 on aggregate. Despite a 2-0 lead, Arsenal failed to score again in the second leg, ultimately exiting the competition. Monaco's 3-1 win in the first leg was enough to send them to the last eight, while Arsenal must now face Barcelona in the quarterfinals. This marks the fifth consecutive Champions League exit for Arsenal.

article: (CNN)The aircraft carrier USS Ranger, which saw action in the Vietnam War and Operation Desert Storm and had appearances in the movies "Top Gun" and "Star Trek IV," is on its final journey, a five-month cruise at the end of a tow cable from Bremerton, Washington, to a scrapyard in Texas. The 56,300-ton warship, which was launched in 1956, was decommissioned in 1993 but kept in storage for possible reactivation until March 2004 when it was stricken from the Naval Vessel Register and made availabl
summary: The aircraft carrier USS Ranger, launched in 1956, has completed its final journey from Bremerton, Washington, to a scrapyard in Texas. Launched during the Vietnam War and Operation Desert Storm, the carrier saw action in movies like "Top Gun" and "Star Trek IV." It was decommissioned in 1993 and remained in storage until 2004 when it was donated to a preservation group. However, it failed to meet government requirements, leading to its transfer to International Shipbreaking of Brownsville, Texas, where it will be scrapped.

article: (CNN)Could a simple blood test someday tell if you're genetically predisposed to post-traumatic stress disorder? That's what a team of international researchers is hoping after finding a genetic marker linked to PTSD in the blood samples of Marines stationed in conflict zones. "We'll draw the blood and have a way to do this very rapidly and start to tease apart who is a little more at risk and who is a little more resilient for PTSD," says principal investigator Dr. Dewleen Baker of the Universi
summary: A team of researchers, led by Dr. Dewleen Baker, has discovered a genetic marker linked to Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in the blood samples of Marines stationed in conflict zones. They hope that this discovery will lead to a simple blood test that can determine a person's genetic predisposition to developing PTSD. This finding is significant because it sheds light on the complex relationship between genetics, emotions, and trauma, and could potentially aid in the development of preventive measures and treatments for PTSD.

article: (CNN)Smoking Man, time to light another cigarette. Fox announced Tuesday that "The X-Files," the series about the paranormal that ran for nine seasons in the '90s and early '00s, is returning for a special six-episode "event." Stars David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson are both back to play Fox Mulder and Dana Scully, those FBI agents who always got a little too close to the truth. " 'The X-Files' was not only a seminal show for both the studio and the network, it was a worldwide phenomenon that
summary: Fox announced that the popular TV series "The X-Files" will return with six special episodes as part of an "event." The series, starring David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson, follows FBI agents Fox Mulder and Dana Scully who investigate paranormal phenomena and share their findings with the public. The series originally ran for nine seasons in the '90s and early '00s, and included memorable characters such as the Smoking Man. Chris Carter, who created the series, said the return of "The X-Files" is perfect because it coincides with a period of increased paranormal activity.

article: (CNN)Kids, being kids, like to climb on things. More often than not, that's OK. But when the thing in question is a war memorial? That's the question burning up online parenting groups and in family rooms after an amateur photographer snapped a picture of two children scampering on top of the Vietnam Women's Memorial in Washington.
