(CNN)Each week, Passion to Portfolio brings you inspiring profiles of people who dared to chase their dreams and turn their passions and hobbies into successful careers. Now we want to hear from you -- who do you think should be featured on our program? Is there someone you know of who took the plunge and made a career change that he or she pined for? The person you nominate could be featured on Passion to Portfolio. They don't need to be famous -- they can be a friend, relative or neighbor, as
summary: The article highlights a weekly feature called "Passion to Portfolio," which showcases individuals who have transformed their passions and hobbies into successful careers. It invites readers to submit nominations for potential featured individuals. The article mentions a previous feature showcasing interesting people who have made career changes based on their passions. Readers are encouraged to leave comments and provide information about the individuals they wish to see featured in the upcoming episode.

article: (CNN)I was finishing my studies when the war began four years ago. I had only two subjects remaining before I graduated from university with a degree in English literature. Since I was 10 years old, I have loved English and dreamed of becoming a teacher. I want to teach the younger ones, especially now, because children are the ones who will rebuild our country. They are Syria's future, and they deserve our significant investment. Three years ago, my family was forced to flee our home near Damas
summary: The author, who was studying English literature before the war started four years ago, fled Syria with his family due to chemical warfare and ended up in Jordan, where he faces numerous challenges such as financial difficulties, lack of employment opportunities, and isolation. Despite these obstacles, he remains hopeful about returning to Syria someday and becoming a teacher, believing that education is crucial for the development of a better future for both him and his fellow Syrians. He also emphasizes the importance of empowering children to speak up and advocate for their rights.

article: (CNN)"Good night Malaysian three-seven-zero." It was a routine sign-off, an all-is-well. On March 8, 2014, at 1:19 a.m., someone spoke those last words from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to air traffic controllers before the Boeing 777 vanished. A year later, searchers have no new clues as to where it went with 239 people on board. Radar and satellite reports have provided hints, but searchers still have nothing to hold in their hands. No wreckage seen floating at sea or beached on shore. No fuse

Peshawar, Pakistan (CNN)A former lawyer for the doctor who helped the CIA look for Osama bin Laden has been shot dead in northwest Pakistan, police said. Unidentified gunmen attacked the lawyer, Samiullah Afridi, in his car near the city of Peshawar on Tuesday, said Mian Saeed, a police superintendent in Peshawar. Two different militant groups claimed responsibility for the killing. The lawyer had represented Dr. Shakeel Afridi, who was convicted of treason in 2012 by a Pakistani tribal court an
summary: A lawyer representing a doctor who helped the CIA find Osama bin Laden was shot dead in Pakistan, according to police. The doctor, who was convicted of treason in 2012, was being held in a prison in Abbottabad, where bin Laden was killed in 2011. The lawyer, Samiullah Afridi, was killed along with a passenger in his car near Peshawar. There are conflicting reports about who carried out the assassination.

article: (CNN)Ryan Reynolds gave us a sneak peek at his new costume last week, and followed it up with a first look on video. The actor posed on a bearskin rug to show off how he looks as masked Marvel character Deadpool in a post that quickly got positive responses from fans on social media. The photo is a parody of Burt Reynolds' famous nude image from a 1972 issue of Cosmopolitan and is very much in keeping with Deadpool's wisecracking, tongue-in-cheek persona. (Here's the original, in case you were b
summary: Actor Ryan Reynolds has shared a parody of Burt Reynolds' naked 1972 Cosmopolitan cover, featuring himself wearing a bearskin rug and a Deadpool mask. This image is part of the upcoming superhero film 'Deadpool', where Reynolds will wear a similar costume to his iconic appearance in 'Wolverine'. The movie is set for release in 2016 and will feature Reynolds as the titular character, Deadpool.

article: (CNN)Deep within the Amazonian rainforest of Ecuador live the Huaorani. Photographer Trupal Pandya traveled about 30 hours by air, water and land to reach this native community and take their portraits. The Huaorani, which means "the people" or "human beings," are believed to have inhabited the rainforest for thousands of years. Until about the 1960s, they never had any contact with the outside world. Pandya said there is a contrast between the modernization of the younger generation, who travel
summary: Photographer Trupal Pandya spent 30 hours traveling to photograph the Huaorani, an indigenous group living deep within the Amazonian rainforest of Ecuador. He found a contrast between the modernization of the younger generation and the older generation's desire to maintain their traditional ways of living. Pandya believes that capturing the Huaorani's lifestyle before it changes is crucial, as it shows the transition from a closed-off society to one influenced by globalization. His photographs aim to showcase the Huaorani's daily life and cultural practices in harmony with nature.

article: (CNN)"Saturday Night Live" cast member Kate McKinnon got rave reviews for her impression of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton as she delved into the topic we're all wondering about. So, what does the fake Clinton have to say about her use of personal email address to conduct government business? "Those emails are clean as a whistle. This is not how Hillary Clinton goes down," McKinnon's wild-eyed Clinton said, laughing at the idea that the emails would be her undoing. "There will be no m
summary: Kate McKinnon played Hillary Clinton in Saturday Night Live, and the audience loved it. The actress pretended to be Clinton and talked about her email usage. Some people think her emails are really clean and won't cause problems, but others are worried. The actress also pretended to send an email to her husband, Bill Clinton, which might make some people think about mature relationships.

article: (CNN)As a well-traveled photographer, Pieter ten Hoopen is no stranger to refugee camps. But he never experienced any like the Mayo camp, which is outside the Sudanese capital of Khartoum. Ten Hoopen was at the camp to photograph a new medical clinic for Emergency, a humanitarian group from Italy. He also hoped to document what life was like for refugees there. His hopes were dashed, however, when he was told he couldn't photograph outside the hospital compound. "I had very, very hard restrictio

(CNN)A Delta airplane had a close call Thursday, skidding off a snowy runway and stopping within feet of icy waters. Any accident raises questions, and the National Transportation Safety Board is sending people to New York's LaGuardia Airport to investigate. Although the cause of the crash is not yet clear, officials will no doubt be looking at the conditions on the runway. Was it cleared and ready? Did the pilot have all relevant information? CNN aviation analyst Mary Schiavo breaks down the re
summary: A Delta flight in New York skidded off a snowy runway and stopped near icy water due to poor runway conditions. The National Transportation Safety Board sent investigators to the scene. Questions about the cause remain, but officials will examine factors such as runway friction and pilot visibility.

article: (CNN)"Attenzione, the wine!" That is an old punchline in the Weir home, thanks to plastic cups of Chianti, a low bridge and a gondolier named Marco. His concerned bark broke the spell as my wife and I smooched and gaped, moon-eyed dorks on our first night in Venice. When I told my dad I was taking my wife to Italy for our first anniversary, he snorted. "Where you gonna take her for your 10th? The moon?" He was right. It was perfect. Pigeons in San Marco, sunset over the Grand Canal, Bellinis and
summary: The Weir family's first trip to Venice was a memorable experience, but some visitors may not have realized the challenges faced by the city due to rising water levels and a growing population. Venice is sinking and experiencing higher water levels, and plans to install a system of gates to create a temporary sea wall are behind schedule and over budget. This has led to a mass exodus of native Venetians and a significant influx of tourists. The city faces potential threats like time, tide, and greed, and preservation efforts are needed to protect its beauty, history, and harmony.

article: (CNN)Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams didn't just blur the lines, they crossed them, a California jury ruled this week. Their song "Blurred Lines" ripped off the Marvin Gaye soul classic "Got to Give It Up," jurors found, ordering the performers to pay millions for copyright damages and infringement. It's not the first time singers have turned to the courts to settle an accusation of musical theft. Talk about getting blasted: Thicke and Williams were ordered to pay $7.4 million. Their song: .
summary: A California jury found that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams stole Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up" in their song "Blurred Lines." The jury ordered the singers to pay $7.4 million in damages for copyright infringement.

article: (CNN)A 17-year-old male fatally shot an Iraqi man watching his first snowfall in his new American hometown, targeting him and then continuing to fire as the immigrant rushed to get inside, Dallas police said Friday. Authorities don't believe the suspected shooter knew the victim, Ahmed Al-Jumaili, Dallas Police Maj. Jeff Cotner said reporters, nor do they believe he knew Al-Jumaili's ethnicity. And they haven't given any indication Al-Jumaili had anything to do with what led the teen to head out
summary: A 17-year-old boy in Dallas, Texas, shot and killed an Iraqi immigrant, Ahmed Al-Jumaili, after seeing him and his family in his new home. The teen believed he knew the victim and his family, but police believe they did not. They say the teen targeted Al-Jumaili and continued shooting as he ran away. The suspect is currently being held and may face charges as an adult.

article: Hong Kong (CNN)The search is on for China's teen top guns. China said Monday it has selected 16 high schools to offer pilot training as the country's armed forces seek to attract better qualified recruits. The schools, in 11 provinces across the country, will recruit 1,000 male junior high school students aged between 14 to 16, the China Daily reported. Successful applicants will receive flight training and "military standard" physical training in addition to their regular high-school studies. I
summary: China has selected 16 high schools to offer pilot training for 1,000 male junior high school students aged 14-16, as part of an effort to attract better qualified recruits for its armed forces. The pilot training includes flight training and "military standard" physical training, along with regular high-school studies. This marks another attempt by the People's Liberation Army's air force to recruit more talented pilots, as China continues to focus on developing advanced aircraft and improving its air and naval power.

article: March 18, 2015 . Israelis have voted in a globally significant election. U.S. aid workers who've been exposed to an Ebola patient are being monitored. ISIS terrorists have destroyed some of Iraq's treasured artifacts. A professional football player has walked away from a dream job over health concerns. And a roving camera in the shape of a bowling ball could depict the future of surveillance technology. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on th
summary: Israel held a significant election; U.S. aid workers monitoring Ebola patients; ISIS destroys artifacts in Iraq; professional football player walking away from dream job due to health concerns; and a roving bowling-ball-shaped surveillance camera depicted the future of technology.

article: Fall River, Massachusetts  (CNN)Shayanna Jenkins, the fiancee of former New England Patriots star Aaron Hernandez, revealed for the first time Monday she suspects marijuana was in a box she was instructed to remove from the couple's home the day after the slaying of Odin Lloyd in 2013. Hernandez has been charged with murder and has pleaded not guilty to orchestrating the death of Lloyd, the boyfriend of Shayanna Jenkins' sister and semipro football player who was found dead June 17, 2013. Hernan
summary: Shayanna Jenkins, the fiancee of former New England Patriots star Aaron Hernandez, revealed that she suspected marijuana was in a box she was instructed to remove from their home shortly after the slaying of Odin Lloyd in 2013. Hernandez has been charged with murder and has pleaded not guilty to orchestrating the death of Lloyd, the boyfriend of her sister and semipro football player. Hernandez has also pleaded not guilty to a gun and ammunition charge. Jenkins testified Friday that on the day after Lloyd's slaying, her fiance called her with instructions that it was important to discard the box. Jenkins has been accused of perjury charges

article: (CNN)This is what it's come to. Starbucks asked its local baristas to have conversations about race. Not the federal government or Congress. Not academia or the NAACP. But a national coffee shop chain waded into an area of social conflict that is as old as the slave ships and as modern as stop-and-frisk policing. Then people went crazy. Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz was accused of ruining that magic morning moment when customers fork over $4.15  for a "grande" coffee with warm skim milk and vanil

(CNN)There are two main ways visitors to Ho Chi Minh City cross the streets. One approach is to step with zen-like calm into the swirl of honking scooters and serenely stride across the road without breaking step. Like locals, they're part of the flow, part of the (exhaust-choked) stream of traffic. The other is to stand anxiously on the edge of the curb, toes curled like a diver's, waiting for a non-existent stoplight, then plunge into the melee while letting out a small yelp before slaloming a
summary: Steve Mueller, a South Carolina resident, started a company called Vietnam Vespa Adventures to provide two-wheel thrills on vintage Vespa scooters in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The tours include popular sights and offbeat locations, with experienced local drivers and guides adding context to the experiences. Mueller's business has grown, with longer trips available, such as to the Vietnam Highlands and coastal city of Nha Trang.

article: March 19, 2015 . From a terrorist attack in Tunisia to an election update from Israel to an upcoming eclipse over the Faroe Islands, today's show is taking you around the world. We're also featuring a Character Study on a 13-year-old who started working to fight hunger at age 4. And we're looking into the NCAA "March Madness" tournament and its effects on some athletes' class time. On this page you will find today's show Transcript and a place for you to request to be on the CNN Student News Rol
summary: The article discusses various events happening around the world, including a terrorist attack in Tunisia, an election update from Israel, and an upcoming eclipse over the Faroe Islands. Additionally, it features a character study on a 13-year-old girl who has been working to fight hunger since she was four years old. The article also delves into the NCAA March Madness tournament and its impact on athletes' class time. It provides a link to the transcript of the CNN Student News program and invites readers to participate in a roll call for being featured on the show.

article: (CNN)After enduring about four days at sea under stressful conditions, Tyke, an African elephant, escaped during a circus performance, crushing her trainer to death and injuring dozens of others while storming through the streets of Honolulu. Tyke suffered a slow and painful death after being hit by a barrage of bullets fired by police officers. That incident happened 20 years ago, but the welcome announcement last week by Feld Entertainment -- parent company to Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Baile
summary: Tyke, an African elephant, died after escaping from a circus performance in Honolulu and killing several people. The elephant had been aggressive and difficult to train before arriving, and the circus decided to send her there despite her history. It was reported that the elephant's trainers were beaten, chained, and deprived of food before being killed. The Feld Entertainment company, which owns Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, announced that it plans to retire elephants from its circuses by 2018. Critics argue that circuses are cruel to animals, and some countries have passed laws banning them. The Hawaiian Humane Society believes that

article: (CNN)While Boston and other New England cities have suffered through their snowiest seasons, other parts of the country have some unexpected good news to go along with the record-breaking winter conditions. All that cold air and a stuck weather pattern are keeping tornadoes to historic lows so far this year. March is typically a transitional month, where warm moist air from the Gulf of Mexico collides with cold Arctic air to produce severe thunderstorms and tornadoes. This year, however, the jet
summary: In March, the Northeastern part of the United States experienced unusually mild weather due to a persistent weather pattern that keeps the cold air and snow. This pattern suppresses severe weather, including tornadoes, resulting in only four tornado watches issued so far this year. The current weather pattern is unusual, as tornado counts are typically higher during this time of year. A weaker El Niño could potentially affect the occurrence of tornadoes, and while it is currently dry and calm, there is no guarantee that the rest of the season will remain quiet.

article: (CNN)Americans like to complain about the endless political gridlock in our capital. But if we're honest we need to look in the mirror too. Many of us abandoned the field by not voting in last year's midterm elections. Those of us who did vote elected more fire breathers than bridge builders to Congress. What's more, when we're invited to tell our representatives what we want, we can be as demagogic as they are. Remember the Town Hall meetings in the summer of 2009, which erupted in shouting mat

(CNN)The 1-0 scoreline that took Barcelona through to the Champions League quarterfinals made their clash with Manchester City all seem rather academic. Yet it was anything but as Lionel Messi's masterful first-half display had some purring once again about his status as the greatest footballer of all time. Meanwhile, the second half witnessed another masterclass as England international Joe Hart somehow kept City in a lively encounter with save after save. In between, the man that City usually
summary: Barcelona, led by Lionel Messi, secured a 1-0 win over Manchester City, qualifying them for the Champions League quarterfinals for the eighth consecutive year. Despite the scoreline appearing academic, Messi showcased his exceptional skills throughout the match, including impressive free-kicks and nutmegs. Manchester City's goalkeeper, Joe Hart, made 10 saves, playing a crucial role in keeping the tie close. Although they did not score the goals they desired, Barcelona managed to advance to the quarterfinals with a 3-1 aggregate win. This accomplishment surpasses the previous record set by Barcelona in 2009

article: (CNN)Well-off North Koreans really love baguettes -- and the country is dispatching citizens outside its borders to learn how to make them, says a report by a pro-North Korea newspaper based in Japan. According to the Choson Sinbo, a North Korean factory sent its staff abroad in an attempt to improve its food products -- which include baguettes and sweet potato cakes. No word yet on whether they've succeeded. But it's not the first time North Korea has sent its citizens into the world to seeking
summary: A North Korean factory sent its staff abroad to improve food products, including baguettes and sweet potato cakes. However, this initiative was unsuccessful, and there is no word on whether they have succeeded. Additionally, North Korea has also sent its citizens to France to learn cheese-making skills, but they were turned away. Despite these efforts, food security remains poor for most North Koreans, as the World Food Programme reported a severe food availability situation in 2018.

article: (CNN)It's called the Grand Renaissance Dam -- and the clue is in the name. With some 8,500 laborers working around the clock on its construction, the imposingly-named dam is surely one of Africa's most ambitious infrastructure projects, reaffirming Ethiopia's ambitions of becoming a big regional player and a major exporter of power. When completed, the project will generate around 6,000 megawatts of electricity for both domestic use and exports. The most striking aspect of the nearly $5 billion
summary: The Grand Renaissance Dam, a massive hydroelectric power plant under construction in Ethiopia, aims to generate approximately 6,000 megawatts of electricity for domestic use and export. Funded entirely by Ethiopia, the project has garnered international attention due to its ambitious scale and self-financing approach. While the dam's completion is expected to contribute significantly to Ethiopia's economic growth and energy independence, it faces opposition from neighboring countries like Sudan and Egypt over potential reductions in their Nile River water supply. Despite these challenges, the dam is expected to become one of the largest electricity exporters in Africa, particularly benefiting countries along the Nile River. Ethiopia's

article: (CNN)Hillary Clinton worked hard last week to put the "dead end" sign on the State Department email story by announcing there was nothing to find. But in her rush to control the narrative, Clinton may have (once again) missed the bigger picture: In politics as much as in business, authenticity matters. Her press conference had the familiar ring of a controlled performance -- the carefully parsed explanation, the combative posture -- that stretched our belief that what she's telling us is really

(CNN)On the heels of the magical success of Disney's live-action "Cinderella," the studio is eyeing another live-action retelling: "Mulan." Disney bought a script by writing team Elizabeth Martin and Lauren Hynek that centers on the Chinese legend of Hua Mulan, the female warrior who was the main character in Disney's 1998 animated film. Chris Bender and J.C. Spink ("We're the Millers) are producing the new project. From Cinderella to Elsa (and Back to Cinderella): The Evolution of Disney Prince
summary: Disney is planning to remake the Chinese legend of Hua Mulan into a live-action movie called "Mulan." This movie is based on a script written by two writers named Elizabeth Martin and Lauren Hynek. They want to make this movie after the successful live-action remake of "Cinderella." Disney also plans to remake "Beauty and the Beast" and "Maleficent."

article: (CNN)When photographer Richard Ross wants to talk to a child at a juvenile detention center, he knocks on their cell door. He asks them if he can come inside. The 67-year-old Californian is used to taking off his shoes when he enters homes, so he does the same in a cell. "Most of the kids, they've never had that kind of respect," he said. "But I give it to them, I give them the power. I sit on the floor so they're looking down on me." Ross doesn't begin by hammering them with questions. He wants
summary: Richard Ross, a 67-year-old photographer from California, visits juvenile detention centers to take photos of children. He believes in the power of empathy and patience, offering tenderness and understanding to the kids. The photos reveal the harsh realities of living in a juvenile detention center, showcasing the struggles and hardships faced by young individuals. Despite the emotional impact, Ross hopes his work can lead to immediate change within the juvenile justice system.

article: (CNN)It shouldn't come as a surprise that Yemen has collapsed -- again.  A country that has split and been pulled together before, has the youngest and fastest growing population in the region, is running low on oil and water, and possesses a "personalist" government rather than stable institutions, was on the top of every expert's list as the fragile state most likely to fail next. What is surprising is that U.S. policy ignored all of this and proceeded on the premise that simply drone-bombing
summary: Yemen, a country with young, rapidly growing population, unstable government and oil scarcity, is currently facing a catastrophic collapse due to internal conflict between the Houthis and al Qaeda terrorists. Despite initial U.S. attempts to stabilize the situation through targeted airstrikes, the ongoing civil war has led to the loss of the U.S. embassy and withdrawal of American troops. The lack of proper leadership, unity among elites, fair economic policies, and functioning economies have all contributed to the deteriorating situation in Yemen. The country now faces an all-out civil war between Iran-supported Shi'as and al Qaeda/ISIS-aligned Sunnis, making it difficult to

article: Atlanta (CNN)The daughter of the late singer Whitney Houston, in a medically induced coma after being found unresponsive in January, has been moved to a rehabilitation facility, a source close to the family said Friday. Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, had been treated at Emory University Hospital. No details about the transfer to a rehab facility were given. Brown, Houston's daughter with singer Bobby Brown, was found unresponsive January 31 in a bathtub at her home in the Atlanta suburb of Roswell. T
summary: Whitney Houston's daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown, was taken from Emory University Hospital to a rehabilitation facility due to her condition, which remains unknown. She was found unresponsive in a bathtub at her home in Atlanta, and doctors at Emory removed her breathing tube, allowing her to be ventilated through a hole in her throat. Police are treating the case as a criminal investigation, while Brown's boyfriend, Nick Gordon, has criticized the family's refusal to allow him to see his daughter.

article: (CNN)[Breaking news update, posted 9:04 p.m. ET] . The live stream from what is believed to be the wreck of the World War II battleship Musashi in the waters around the Philippines began at 9:03 a.m. local time (9:03 p.m. ET) Friday. An underwater camera showed various sections of the ship, which displaced 69,000 tons when it was built, putting it in the largest class of battleships at that time. [Previous story, posted at 7:47 p.m. ET] . It's a journey beneath the waves and back in time. Micros
summary: A team led by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen plans to live-stream an underwater tour of a wreck off the Philippine coast that's believed to be the remains of a long-lost World War II Japanese battleship called the Musashi. The ship was launched in 1940 and was one of the two largest warships in the world at that time. The ship sank on October 24, 1944, during the Battle of the Sibuyan Sea. The live-stream is scheduled to start at 9 a.m. Friday, Philippines time. The team hopes to show various parts of the ship, including

article: (CNN)Legendary fashion designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are in a public spat with pop music icon Elton John over some eyebrow-raising comments the pair made about gay parenting. Long against same-sex marriage, the Italian designers -- who are not only openly gay, but were once a couple -- took their counterintuitive rhetoric to the next level this weekend when Dolce said in an interview: . "You are born to a mother and a father -- or at least that's how it should be. I call children
summary: The famous Italian fashion designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have been involved in a public argument with pop star Elton John over their comments about gay parenting. They said that children born outside of marriage should be called "rented uterus, semen chosen from a catalog" and criticized John for having two children through IVF. The designers have taken the opposite stance, calling for boycotts of their products. While both parties have admitted to being against same-sex marriage, their language regarding gay parenting is controversial and has sparked debate.

article: (CNN)For four years, William Bruce James II called the University of Oklahoma's Sigma Alpha Epsilon his home. He walked its halls, bunked in its rooms, held office as one of its leaders, considered his fraternity brothers his dearest friends. He was proud to be SAE. Now that pride is tainted. A video shot this Saturday of party-bound shows SAE members clapping, pumping their fists and chanting in unison: "There will never be a ni**** SAE," they sing. "You can hang him from a tree, but he can nev
summary: William Bruce James II, an African-American member of the University of Oklahoma's Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity, was upset after seeing a video of his fraternity brothers chanting "There will never be a ni**a SAE" and singing the phrase. James believes that the fraternity, which he once called home, has lost its culture and values. He feels betrayed by his white friends who were once part of the fraternity and now support the actions of some of its members. The fraternity has been disbanded, and James hopes that the entire house will be punished for its actions.

article: (CNN)After weeks of controversy and the sudden departures of two co-hosts, "Fashion Police" is going on an extended break. The fashion commentary show on E! channel announced Tuesday that it will be on hiatus until September. "We look forward to taking this opportunity to refresh the show before the next awards season," it said in a statement. The announcement caps a rocky few months. Last week, co-host Kathy Griffin bid the show bye-bye after seven episodes, saying her style did not blend in wi
summary: The popular fashion commentary show, "Fashion Police," has taken a break due to controversies involving its co-hosts. Following the departure of Kathy Griffin, who left after criticizing the show's style, and Giuliana Rancic, who quit over a comment about Zendaya Coleman's dreadlocks, the show will resume its regular schedule in September. Melissa Rivers, the show's executive producer, stated that the hiatus was necessary to refresh the program before the next awards season.

article: Washington (CNN)A Florida "dream ticket," two nuggets about leadership questions in Congress and coming tests for Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich filled our final March trip around the "Inside Politics" table. 1.  Another "Draft Warren" movement? - Jeb Bush and Sen. Marco Rubio are on friendly terms, sparking speculation of a potential "dream ticket" between the two.

- Ted Cruz is trying to attract young conservatives, particularly at happy hours and fund-raising events.

article: Washington (CNN)There should be plenty of pent-up anticipation among cherry blossom fans in Washington this spring. Peak blooms are expected at the tail end of the three-week-long National Cherry Blossom Festival, which kicks off Friday and runs through April 12. The fluttering pink and white blossoms are expected to hit their peak between April 11 and April 14. Here are five things to know about the eagerly awaited D.C. blossoms: . The city's first cherry trees were destroyed . In 1910, 2,000 c
summary: The 2019 National Cherry Blossom Festival will take place in Washington from March 28 to April 12, featuring the blooming of cherry trees, the Blossom Kite Festival, and the return of the original trees' descendants to Japan. The festival is expected to attract cherry blossom enthusiasts with the peak bloom anticipated between April 11 and April 14.

article: (CNN)Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has been ordered to stand trial over her role in a controversial rice subsidy scheme that cost the country billions. The first court hearing will take place on May 19, a statement from Thailand's supreme court said. "This case falls under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court Criminal Division for Persons Holding Political Positions ... and the charges brought [against Yingluck] are accepted," the statement said. If found guilty, she could face
summary: Thailand's former prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra, is facing a trial for her alleged involvement in a controversial rice subsidy scheme that caused significant financial losses to the country. The first court hearing is scheduled for May 19th, where if convicted, she may face up to 10 years in prison. Critics argue that the scheme wasted public funds and hurt the country's economy, contributing to the protests that led to the military coup in 2014.

article: (CNN)Gov. Mike Pence unleashed a firestorm on Indiana last week when he signed the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. Critics of the law contend it could be used by individuals and businesses to discriminate -- particularly against the LGBT community of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals -- on the basis of religion. The ramifications for the Hoosier State are just starting to be felt in the form of boycotts, petitions and travel bans. As the controversy mushrooms, here's what got

summary: Duke's Christian Laettner apologizes for stepping on Kentucky's Aminu Timberlake during a crucial moment in the 1992 NCAA East Regional Final, sparking controversy and backlash from Kentucky fans and players alike. The incident, known as The Stomp, remains a divisive issue in college basketball history, with many attributing it to Laettner's desire for revenge against Timberlake. However, Laettner has since apologized publicly and acknowledged the impact of his actions on Timberlake's feelings. In response, Timberlake expressed his gratitude towards Laettner and his commitment to the game, stating that it reminds him of

article: (CNN)The end of "Jinx," the six-part HBO documentary about real estate heir Robert Durst, has launched a debate about whether some potentially incriminating statements Durst made while in the bathroom to a microphone may be used in his criminal prosecution. Durst, as you probably heard, is charged with murder in a killing in California 15 years ago, and he has been suspected, but never charged, in the disappearance of his first wife in New York. Whether or not the taped words of an accused perso

(CNN)John Isner could not keep the United States in the Davis Cup on Sunday, so it was likely small consolation that his incredible tennis milestone remained unbeaten. While the American lost to Andy Murray in Scotland, putting Great Britain into the quarterfinals of the prestigious teams event, halfway across the world an absorbing battle was playing out between two of South America's most bitter rivals. In the end it didn't come close to matching Isner's 11-hour marathon against Nicolas Mahut
summary: In a thrilling match, Argentine and Brazilian tennis stars Leonardo Mayer and Joao Souza fought for six hours and 43 minutes, setting a record for the longest singles match in tennis history. They ultimately won the match, sending the tie to a deciding rubber between Federico Delbonis and Brazil's Thomaz Bellucci. This victory gave the British team a crucial 3-1 lead in the Davis Cup series, ensuring a home quarterfinal clash with France on July 17-19. Meanwhile, the United States faced a tough challenge against Andy Murray in the Davis Cup, but John Isner couldn't overcome him,

article: (CNN)Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop says the government is seeking to confirm reports that an Australian teenager has carried out a suicide attack on behalf of ISIS in Iraq. "I can confirm that the Australian government is currently seeking to independently verify reports that 18-year-old Melbourne teenager Jake Bilardi has been killed in a suicide bombing attack in the Middle East," she told reporters. "If these reports are confirmed, this is another tragic example of a young Australi

(CNN)A lot of people have ventured to Paraguay over the years in search of some sort of a dream. My great-great-grandfather, Jean Bourdain, was one of them. I've looked for this mysterious ancestor before -- in Uruguay, with my younger brother Chris. We were disappointed when our trail ran cold. We were left with a cryptic reference to the news that Jean had died in Asuncion, Paraguay. Which raised the questions: "What the hell was he doing in Paraguay?" And "Where is Paraguay, anyway?" Roots: O
summary: This news article talks about a man named Jean Bourdain who lived in Paraguay, which is a country far away from where most people live. He wasn't able to find out much about him, but his story has inspired a TV show called "Parts Unknown". The show explores Paraguay and the man's family history.

article: (CNN)The story of the Jews in the United States is a testament to "American exceptionalism" and stands in contrast to a long history of discrimination and pariah status in Europe and Muslim lands. In fact, the economic prosperity and social standing of America's Jews shows that generally they have fared better than many other minorities. This positive record is a fulfillment of the assurance given to the Newport, Rhode Island, Hebrew Congregation in 1790 by President George Washington: "It is no

(CNN)Indiana is declaring a public health emergency in one county due to an epidemic of HIV. Gov. Mike Pence issued the order Thursday for Scott County, which has 79 confirmed cases of HIV since mid-December. The county averages about five new cases a year. "Scott County is facing an epidemic of HIV, but this is not a Scott County problem; this is an Indiana problem,"  Pence said in a news release. All the cases in the current outbreak are linked to injection drug use, primarily of the prescript
summary: Indiana Governor Mike Pence declared a public health emergency in Scott County due to an HIV epidemic caused by injection drug use, primarily involving Opana. The declaration requires various organizations to collaborate on a response plan, including hospitals, health care providers, and the CDC. The CDC plans to provide support through a short-term needle exchange program and a public awareness campaign focusing on safe sex, needle disposal, addiction services, and HIV testing and treatment.

article: Omoa, Honduras (CNN)Alexis González walks slowly and with some hesitation, using the outside wall of his house for balance. "I'm getting used to the prosthesis," the 16-year-old says. He tries to smile, but an expression of sadness quickly returns to his face. When he was 15, González made a decision that would forever change his life -- to leave Omoa, an impoverished village in Honduras  -- with dreams of getting to the United States. At the end of the trek -- about 2,500 kilometers (1,500 mile

(CNN)An Indiana jury sentenced a woman who says she had a miscarriage to 20 years in prison. In 2013, Purvi Patel showed up at a hospital emergency room suffering from severe vaginal bleeding.  According to court documents, at first she denied that she had been pregnant but later told doctors that she had a miscarriage and delivered a stillborn fetus which, she said, she placed in a bag in a dumpster. Patel was later charged with feticide and felony neglect of a dependent, though these charges a

(CNN)On October 24, 1944, U.S. warplanes swarmed at the Leviathan of battleships, Japan's Musashi, splashing down torpedoes or dive bombing it. It took them four hours and more than 25 direct hits to put one of the two largest war ships in World War II to the bottom of the Philippines' Sibuyan Sea. This month, Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen and a team of researchers found a sprawling undersea wreck after an eight-year search for the Musashi. Japanese maritime expert Kazushige Todaka is 90% sure
summary: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's team found the huge, sunken Japanese battleship, the Musashi, in the Philippine's Sibuyan Sea. The team used special equipment to discover it, and they are sharing videos of the underwater wreck with the world.

article: (CNN)Lewis Hamilton has conquered the world of Formula One but becoming a global superstar is a far bumpier ride. Sporting ability has been transformed into lasting celebrity by footballers like Pele and David Beckham and NBA star Michael Jordan. At the age of 30 -- and with the fastest car in the world at his fingertips -- Hamilton is at the peak of his powers. During Sunday's season-opening Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne, millions of hardcore Hamilton fans will bite their fingernails and h

(CNN)They're some of the toughest athletes on the planet, saying goodbye to loved ones for almost a year, as they traverse the globe's oceans. Hardened Volvo Ocean Race sailors must sleep in four-hour shifts, and survive on little more than freeze dried food and chocolate bars, if they hope to win the event. The prestigious competition kicked off from Alicante, Spain, in October last year, and will finish nine months later in Gothenberg, Sweden. Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing skipper Ian Walker, spoke a
summary: The Volvo Ocean Race is a grueling sailing competition that lasts nearly a year, with sailors enduring long hours, extreme conditions, and minimal supplies. Skipper Ian Walker shares his experience, emphasizing the importance of teamwork, commitment, and respect for the ocean. Despite the challenges, the team aims to win the race and complete their historic voyage around the world.

article: (CNN)He's a Rolls Royce footballer who honed his game in his parents' garage. And even at the age of 40, former Juventus star Alessandro Del Piero is still purring along, showing no signs of running out of gas. The record-breaking striker is currently enjoying an Indian summer to his football career, completing stints at Sydney FC in Australia and more recently at the Delhi Dynamos in the inaugural Indian Super League. Inevitably, the time will come when he finally decides to hang up his boots b

(CNN)Fox's smash hit series "Empire" had its season finale on Wednesday night, and the ratings once again grew. According to Deadline, the drama reached 16.5 million viewers, up 10% from the 14.9 million who tuned in the week before. The show has managed to grow its total audience every week since its premiere, a rare feat in the television landscape. Deadline notes that it's the best showing for a new series in a decade. Most fans were not disappointed with Wednesday night's season finale. As t
summary: The popular TV show "Empire" had its season finale, which reached 16.5 million viewers, up 10% from the previous week. It is the highest number of viewers for a new series in a decade. The show has grown its total audience weekly since its premiere. The series is about the Lyon family and their record label, and it has been praised for its social consciousness and emotional depth. The show's soundtrack topped Billboard's top 200 album chart.

article: (CNN)Israel's ruling Likud Party pulled off a victory in Tuesday's election -- and it was a stunning one. During the campaign, incumbent Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had come in for heavy criticism from across the political spectrum, for reasons ranging from concerns over his frosty relationship with the White House, to his fixation on the Iran nuclear issue, to allegations over Netanyahu's household expenses. Yet despite this unpromising backdrop, Likud is on course to win 30 seats in the
summary: In the latest Israeli election, the Likud Party won a significant victory, securing 30 seats in the Knesset, six more than the main opposition Zionist Union. Despite facing criticism from various political factions, including concerns over Netanyahu's personal relationships and domestic policies, Likud emerged as the clear victor. The election results reflect a rightward shift in the electorate, with voters increasingly prioritizing national security and economic issues. While Netanyahu will continue to address housing and land reform, he may struggle to achieve significant structural reforms in the near future. Additionally, Netanyahu will likely maintain a cautious approach towards national security, focusing on the status quo

article: Moscow (CNN)Kim Jong Un is expected to attend World War II anniversary celebrations in Moscow at Russia's invitation, a Russian official speaking on condition of anonymity said Thursday. North Korea accepted Russia's invitation, but Russia is waiting on Pyongyang to make the official announcement about the May trip, the official said. This would mark Kim's first official foreign trip since inheriting the leadership in late 2011. "The invitation was sent to Kim Jong Un. North Korea accepted the i
summary: Kim Jong Un, the leader of North Korea, is expected to attend World War II anniversary celebrations in Moscow, according to a Russian official speaking on condition of anonymity. This would mark his first official foreign trip since inheriting the leadership in late 2011.

article: (CNN)Growing up in Germany, everything Felix von der Osten learned about Native Americans came from the books of 19th-century German writer Karl May. May's most beloved characters, a noble Apache leader named Winnetou and his cowboy blood brother Old Shatterhand, are said to be more popular today in Germany than the works of Thomas Mann, the 20th-century Nobel Prize-winning author of "Death in Venice." It wasn't until von der Osten drove through South Dakota last year, bearing witness to modest
summary: Felix von der Osten, a 25-year-old German photographer, discovered a deep interest in Native American culture while driving through South Dakota last year. He began researching Native American history and found that his perception of the subject was one-dimensional. After presenting his idea to the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation in Montana, he returned to the reservation to capture the good, bad, and ugly aspects of Native American life. Von der Osten chose a Pentax 67 medium-format roll film camera to create focused, thoughtful photographs. He gained a close relationship with the tribal leadership and learned of the harsh realities of life on the reservation

article: (CNN)Formula One star Fernando Alonso returned to work at McLaren on Wednesday following his freak accident in winter testing. The Spanish double world champion was ruled out of the opening race in Australia by doctors treating him for the effects of a high speed crash. Alonso has been training hard for his planned comeback at the Malaysian Grand Prix in nine days' time and used the McLaren simulator to hone his mental preparations. The CNN-sponsored team announced the news on Twitter, showing M
summary: Ferrari driver Fernando Alonso returned to work at McLaren on Wednesday, having previously been sidelined by an accident in winter testing. The Spanish double world champion was injured during the crash and underwent treatment for concussion, before being allowed to return to training and focusing on mental preparation. Alonso will be making a comeback at the Malaysian Grand Prix in nine days' time.

Except this is 2015 and "Who squeezes them in Harelbeke?" is the poster strapline for the elite E3 Harelbeke competition in Belgium, accompanied by that gloved cyclist's hand poised to pinch a woman's bottom. Hoping to impress the Yale admissions committee, a student writes an essay about the time she was so engrossed in a discussion with a French teacher she admired that she urinated on herself instead of interrupting the teacher or leaving the room. Looking to give their child an edge, parents hire a college admissions consulta

(CNN)Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser has died. He was 84. "It is with deep sadness that we inform you that after a brief illness John Malcolm Fraser died peacefully in the early hours of this morning," according to a Fraser family statement sent to Australian media. The office of current Prime Minister Tony Abbott confirmed Fraser's death to CNN. Fraser was Australia's 22nd prime minister, from 1975-1983. He began his mandate as a caretaker prime minister amid a constitutional cr
summary: Australian former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser passed away at age 84 due to a brief illness. He was the 22nd prime minister of Australia from 1975-1983 and is known for his significant impact on changing relations between Commonwealth countries and shaping ties with East and Southeast Asian nations.

article: (CNN)Early Intervention changes lives. Respite care keeps families together. Both save states money over time. Alas, both -- along with a huge swathe of other vital services -- are under attack by the administration of Bruce Rauner, the new Republican governor of Illinois. This is happening for two reasons. (CNN)For the second time in his career, Madison, Wisconsin, police Officer Matt Kenny is being investigated for using lethal force. But the cases and their circumstances are different, very different. Friday's death of Tony Robinson, an unarmed biracial 19-year-old, has made Madison the latest epicenter of protests of black males killed by white officers. Eight years ago, it was a different story. Kenny shot and killed a man who pointed a pellet gun at him. He was exonerated of any wrongdoing an
summary: Madison police officer Matt Kenny is being investigated for shooting and killing a 19-year-old man named Tony Robinson, who was unarmed. This is different from the first time Kenny was accused of using deadly force, as the first case involved a white man. People are protesting because they feel that black people are being unfairly targeted by police.

article: (CNN)You think March Madness is all about basketball? Think again. Sure, millions will be watching the 2015 NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament to see whether Kentucky's bid for an unbeaten season can be quashed or whether a 14 seed can make it to the Final Four. summary: March Madness, the annual college basketball tournament, brings together millions of people to watch and participate in various aspects of the game. While many are focused on the basketball aspect of the tournament, there are also other aspects that attract attention. The tournament generates billions of dollars in revenue, including from HDTV upgrades and increased sales of fast food products. Additionally, the tournament has a significant impact on college applications and endowments, particularly for Cinderella teams. It is also known for its high viewership, with an estimated 1.15 billion people tuning in to watch the games. However, it also has negative effects on productivity, as

article: (CNN)ISIS' recent video showing a child shooting a man whom the extremist group claimed was an Israeli spy is the latest example of how the militants exploit children in their propaganda. As ISIS encourages foreign fighters to bring their families into the parts of Syria and Iraq where it imposes its brutal rule, the catalog of children taking part in shocking acts is grim and growing. The deeply disturbing cases shine a light into the range of ways the militants are using children to further th
summary: A child in ISIS propaganda video shoots a man who the group claims is an Israeli spy. This is one of many ways ISIS uses children to promote its violent activities. The militants are encouraging families from other countries to join them in Syria and Iraq, and they use children to train as fighters and perform dangerous tasks. ISIS has also promoted videos of young boys learning weapons and military tactics. ISIS has taken over schools and uses them to indoctrinate children. They recruit children from around the world, even in the UK, and use social media to spread their message.

They have been friends for many years, but there were rumors that Chris fathered a baby with another woman while being with Tran. This made Tran upset and she deleted a tweet she sent earlier. article: Washington (CNN)Ted Cruz is back in his favorite place: the spotlight. As the first candidate to quit the charade of "exploring" a presidential run and actually jumping in, the Texas Republican senator presented an image Monday of decisiveness and vision -- all before an auditorium of mostly supportive young evangelicals. Senate President pro Tempore Kevin de León said the legislation will include two bills that will speed up contracting funds to "manage the drought and strengthen our infrastructure." It will allocate $128 million to assist workers and affected communities, while $272 million will be directed towards safe drinking water initiatives and maintenance of water recycling infrastructure. article: (CNN)Its a high stakes game of stick or twist with billions of dollars at stake. Traditionally at this time of year, a clutch of nervous owners in charge of struggling clubs in England's top flight grapple with the prospect of relegation, and the enormous hole it threatens to blow in their finances. Do they stick by a floundering manager hoping he can regroup and lead his team out of the mire, or do they get rid and hope the appointment of new coach can transform its fortunes? Kampala, Uganda (CNN)Gunmen on a motorcycle have shot and killed Uganda's lead prosecutor in the 2010 bombings that killed 76 people who were watching the World Cup finals. Joan Kagezi stopped at a roadside produce stand in a Kampala suburb Monday evening to buy some fruit when her assailants approached, according to police. "Criminals riding on a motorcycle ... stopped next to the parked car she was driving and shot her twice in the neck and shoulder through the window on the driver's side," Ka
summary: Uganda's lead prosecutor, Joan Kagezi, was shot and killed by gunmen on a motorcycle during a road stop in a Kampala suburb. Kagezi was the lead prosecutor in the 2010 bombings that resulted in 76 deaths and was responsible for the International Crime Division. The incident occurred at an Ethiopian restaurant and a rugby center while spectators watched the World Cup finals. The police inspector general vowed to hunt for the attackers and restore order in the country.

article: (CNN)Italian fashion designer Stefano Gabbana and Elton John are in a war of words on social media, calling for boycotts of each other's work. The argument stems from comments about in-vitro fertilization in Panorama magazine, in which Gabbana and longtime collaborator Domenico Dolce spoke about "synthetic" children born from "rented" wombs. "No chemical children: life has a natural course, there are things that shouldn't be modified," the magazine says in a quote attributed to both designers. T
summary: Italian fashion designer Stefano Gabbana and Elton John are in a heated battle over social media, with Gabbana accusing John of discriminating against IVF children and calling for a boycott of his fashion line. John responded by pledging to boycott Gabbana's brand, while Gabbana defended his right to express his opinions.

How can football serve as a tool of socialization when it remains the domain of young boys and men? Algeria coach Christian Gourcuff, who has a coached a number of Ligue 1 clubs, notes that for a long time, women's football "was a sport totally marginalized." Former player Jean-Michel Moutier agrees, stating that women's football has improved in quality. article: (CNN)Golden beaches and grand hotels can all be found in Mauritius, but there is much more to this island paradise. The country, located some 500 miles east of Madagascar, has been attracting global investors for decades. Mauritius is also a place where entrepreneurs and business owners thrive. One example is SKC Surat, a company that supplies fresh food to the market. The founder, Sooklall Surat, started his business as a farmer and later became the first person to grow strawberries and artichokes in Mauritius. Today, his son, Suren Surat, runs the company. article: (CNN)A Black Hawk helicopter that went down in waters off the Florida Panhandle three days ago -- killing 11 service members -- had aborted a training mission due to bad weather before it crashed, a military official said Friday. As officials continue to investigate why the aircraft went down in thick fog Tuesda

Washington (CNN)Democrats who have gleefully watched Republican infighting for years are about to feel some heat of their own. As the party works to retake control of the Senate in 2016, Democrats are looking at a Senate landscape that could feature titanic intraparty clashes starring big personalities who have been waiting years for a shot at the big time.
